urn:contentItem:5X68-9BV1-JBG3-6172-00000-00Do We Need to Break Up Facebook?2019-10-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisOPINIONDo We Need to Break Up Facebook?Spencer Bokat-Lindell

Elizabeth Warren has squared off with Mark Zuckerberg.

Elizabeth Warren has squared off with Mark Zuckerberg.

This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

Senator Elizabeth Warren extracted an unwitting advertisement for her presidential campaign from Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, on Tuesday. A Warren administration would “suck for us,” he said in leaked audio of a July meeting, referring to Ms. Warren’s proposal to break up big tech companies. “If she gets elected president,” he said, “then I would bet that we will have a legal challenge, and I would bet that we will win the legal challenge.”

“What would really ‘suck,’” she tweeted, “is if we don’t fix a corrupt system that lets giant companies like Facebook engage in illegal anticompetitive practices, stomp on consumer privacy rights, and repeatedly fumble their responsibility to protect our democracy.”

“Zuckerberg Hates Warren’s Plan to Break Up Facebook. She Doesn’t Care.”

The debate: Does Facebook need to be broken up?

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW

Last April, Mr. Zuckerberg, donning his best “I’m sorry suit,” testified before Congress and apologized for “   a big mistake.” The big mistake was in fact several big mistakes, including   exposingup to 87 million users’ data to Trump campaign consultants (a privacy breach for which Facebook would be fined   $5 billion); concealing an organized Russian effort to   interfere in the 2016 election; and continually failing to   regulate genocidal hate speech.

To Ms. Warren, the litany of errors proves that tech giants hold “too much power over our economy, our society and our democracy” and need to be broken up. In March, she proposed a plan that would reverse Facebook’s acquisitions of Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014. Ms. Warren suggests that users wouldn’t much notice these changes. But for the company, Mr. Zuckerberg says, the threat of such a policy is “existential.”

[The big debates, distilled. This guide will put in context what people are saying about the pressing issues of the week. Sign up for our new newsletter, Debatable.]

WHAT PEOPLE ARE SAYING

Facebook is too powerful

The anti-monopolist spirit that animates Ms. Warren’s policy has found an unlikely vessel in Chris Hughes, who created Facebook with Mr. Zuckerberg when the two were roommates at Harvard. In a nearly 6,000-word Op-Ed for The Times, Mr. Hughes argues that Mr. Zuckerberg, whom he considers a “good, kind person,” simply has more influence over how businesses and people relate than any individual should. (   Here   are five takeaways from his piece.) “Mark’s power,” he says, “is unprecedented and un-American,” and must be curtailed. He writes:

Facebook has earned the prize of domination. It is worth half a trillion dollars and commands, by my estimate, more than 80 percent of the world’s social networking revenue. It is a powerful monopoly, eclipsing all of its rivals and erasing competition from the social networking category.

Mr. Hughes contends that Facebook’s dominance prohibits would-be entrepreneurs from creating alternative social networks, suffocating innovation and restricting consumer choice. The damage extends to industries beyond tech, including journalism, whose business model was broken by Facebook’s and Google’s capture of digital advertising revenue. In warning about the dangers of Facebook’s monopolistic ambitions, Mr. Hughes cites Tim Wu, a Columbia Law School professor and the author of “The Curse of Bigness,”   who told Wired’s editor, Nicholas Thompson:

Mark Zuckerberg wrote an email when he was acquiring Instagram that was disclosed in the New York Post, and it suggests he was buying Instagram because he saw it as a competitive threat. Now, it is a felony under U.S. law to buy companies that you believe are competitive threats to you. … The American way is that we believe in competition and that companies should fight it out, not buy each other when there’s serious competition.

But the most pernicious aspect of Facebook’s hegemony, Mr. Hughes says, is Mr. Zuckerberg’s “unilateral control over speech.” He points as an example to Mr. Zuckerberg’s 2017 decision to stop Facebook Messenger from being used in Myanmar to spread calls for the ethnic cleansing of Rohingya Muslims. At the same time, United Nations investigators and human rights groups said that the company didn’t do nearly enough and, in its negligence, actively facilitated what has since been deemed a genocide.

“Mark knows that this is too much power,” Mr. Hughes writes.

Breaking up Facebook isn’t a silver bullet

Breaking up Facebook isn’t enough, as even Mr. Hughes admits, since it won’t address some of society’s greatest grievances with the platform, argues Evelyn Douek in Slate. On the issue of election security, she writes:

If we’re worried about Russia or other foreign powers using Facebook and other social media platforms to influence elections — as Sen. Elizabeth Warren mentions when making her case for breakup — then we also need to acknowledge that these influence campaigns are often sophisticated, cross-platform operations that require well-resourced, expert and coordinated responses. No one has made a good case for how breakup and competition would aid these efforts.

Ms. Douek also agrees with Mr. Hughes that Mr. Zuckerberg’s control over speech is deeply troubling. But she fails to see how increased competition would have helped in Myanmar, where the military purposefully spread violent propaganda. Authoritarianism and ethnic hatred are not problems the market can solve, nor are “the most intractable issues about how to moderate speech on any individual platform.”

User privacy, Shira Ovide argues in Bloomberg, is another issue that breaking apart the Facebook platform from Instagram and WhatsApp wouldn’t fix. She writes:

Does a core Facebook with perhaps 1 billion users have less ability to harvest information such as people’s web-surfing habits and physical locations as they roam around with smartphones? No, it doesn’t.

Both Ms. Douek and Ms. Ovide are open to breaking up Facebook to keep markets competitive, but they see trustbusting as somewhat beside the point of regulation and democratic oversight. They share this perspective with the tech journalist Kara Swisher, who has called in The Times for a national privacy   law as well as increased funding for the agencies already charged with regulating the tech sector.

Dipayan Ghosh, a co-director of the Platform Accountability Project at the Harvard Kennedy School, goes one step further, claiming that Facebook should be treated as a public utility, like water and electric companies. He writes in the Harvard Business Review, “Facebook and firms like it have become natural monopolies that necessitate a novel, stringent set of regulations to obstruct their capitalistic overreaches and protect the public against ingrained economic exploitation.”

Facebook is being vilified

Reports of Facebook’s monopoly are exaggerated, writes Bloomberg’s     editorial board. Dominance in a market, it says, should not be mistaken for a lack of competition:

As successful as Facebook is, there’s little stopping other companies from doing things better. In fact, they already are: Nearly all of Facebook’s constituent services — messaging, video sharing and so forth — face competition from apps around the world.

Facebook’s chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, has argued that the company faces a great deal of competition from Chinese tech companies, which would benefit from a policy like Ms. Warren’s. “You could break us up, you could break other tech companies up, but you actually don’t address the underlying issues people are concerned about,” she said in May.

What’s more, writes CNBC’s Matt Rosoff, calls to break up Facebook or regulate it like a public utility ignore the fact that it isn’t strictly necessary to modern life as water and electricity are:

Hughes and others have cited historical precedents such as the government’s breakup of Standard Oil and AT&T as a justification for stricter antitrust regulation against tech giants. But these companies not only had clear monopolies with pricing power that hurt consumers, they also offered products that were vital to the economy. … Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp are only three of many ways people can communicate digitally, and while many people spend hours every week using them, they are replaceable and inessential.

In the end, writes Jim Geraghty for National Review, the fault is not in our tech overlords, but in ourselves:

The best way to get Facebook to be more responsive to user concerns about privacy is for users to be loud about their concerns or to turn away from the product, not to make the product less attractive by forcing the company to sell off its other most popular apps.

WHAT TO WATCH

Even if elected, Ms. Warren wouldn’t be able to break up Facebook by herself. As Margaret Harding McGill and Steven Overly report for Politico, “the antitrust review process is meant to be a regulatory and legal one.”

In some ways, however, that path is already being paved. Mr. Zuckerberg’s comments were leaked less than a month after attorneys general of eight states — four Democrats and four Republicans — and the District of Columbia announced that they would follow the Federal Trade Commission in opening an antitrust investigation into the company.

Do you have a point of view we missed? Email us at debatable@nytimes.com. Please note your name, age and location in your response, which may be included in the next newsletter.

MORE PERSPECTIVES

Evan Osnos profiles Mark Zuckerberg and asks whether he can fix Facebook before it breaks democracy. [The New Yorker]

The business columnist Kevin Roose suggests “a better way to break up big tech.” [The New York Times]

Sheelah Kolhatkar recounts how Elizabeth Warren came up with her plan. [The New Yorker]

Ingrid Burrington asks whether Facebookcould be tried for human rights abuses. [The Atlantic]

Jack Nicas, Karen Weise and Mike Isaac detail how each big tech company may be targeted by government regulators. [The New York Times]

WHAT YOU’RE SAYING

Here’s what readers had to say about the last debate: Should college athletes be allowed to get paid?

John from California commented: “There is no argument that can justify paying mostly white executives millions of dollars while the diverse collection of student athletes struggle to eat.”

And Carlos from Switzerland commented: “As an outsider, the way American colleges treat sports has always seemed ridiculous. Investment in professional-grade sports infrastructure seems disproportional to the mission of educating people, and sports scholarships are not often in the best interests of maintaining academic standards. A correction is long overdue.”

urn:contentItem:40RY-R220-009B-G4KB-00000-00Dow Falls 8.48 to 10,804.27; Nasdaq Climbs 28.49 to 4,274.67; Diageo Agrees to Sell Pillsbury to General Mills2000-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30BusinessSHOW00071700V19Dow Falls 8.48 to 10,804.27; Nasdaq Climbs 28.49 to 4,274.67; Diageo Agrees to Sell Pillsbury to General MillsWillow Bay, Stuart Varney, Susan Lisovicz, Fred Katayama, Greg Clarkin, Bob Beard, Jim Moret, Allan Dodds Frank, Allan Chernoff, Steve Young, Bruce Francis

The Dow Jones industrial average Monday fell 8.48 points to 10,804.27 while the Nasdaq climbed 28.49 to 4,274.67. The Nasdaq gained ground for the fourth-straight session today, and the index has ended higher every day since Yahoo! wowed Wall Street last Tuesday night with a strong profit report.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight on MONEYLINE, dog days of summer? Not for the Nasdaq. Today it scored the fourth winning session in a row, now up 35 percent in just eight weeks.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: A manic Monday for mergers that'll mean an all-out supermarket makeover. The "Doughboy" joins forces with Betty Crocker while Brawny teams up with Sparkle.

BAY: Tobacco stocks: burnt again. Wall Street wrestling with the $145 billion question: Can cigarette makers beat history's biggest damage award?

VARNEY: And you think the fight over Napster's been nasty? There's a new high-stakes battle over swapping movies over the Internet.

ANNOUNCER: This is the MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR, live from New York and Los Angeles.

BAY: Good evening, everyone. I'm Willow Bay.

VARNEY: And I'm Stuart Varney. Welcome to MONEYLINE.

Our top story tonight: just what a struggling tech investor likes to see, a Nasdaq winning streak. The Nasdaq gained ground for the fourth-straight session today. In fact, it's ended higher every day since Yahoo! wowed Wall Street last Tuesday night with a blowout profit report. And investors are hoping more blowout profit reports to come this week will help the index extend a much-needed comeback. It's now at its best level in more than three months.

Susan Lisovicz reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Technology stocks clocked a fourth-straight session of gains with investors pinning their hopes on a second week of stellar corporate earnings and a less aggressive Federal Reserve.

MICHAEL CARTY, NEW MILLENNIUM ADVISORS: We seem to be off to a roaring start. These are stocks that basically have been beaten down and now they're starting to turn around. We realize that the economy is not going to die. The Fed seems to have become less aggressive and hopefully won't be aggressive in the late August meeting. And now it seems that earnings are coming out very, very strongly.

LISOVICZ: On the strength of earnings expectations and actual results, the Nasdaq closed at 4,274, up 28 points. The composite index was lifted by JDS Uniphase. Shares of the fiber optic company rose after its competitor Corning, which trades on the NYSE, posted quarterly results that substantially beat "Street" estimates.

And shares of Qualcomm jumped on news that the European and Japanese patent offices had upheld three of Qualcomm's patents, making the company's technology more competitive overseas.

Investors also bought up semiconductor and biotech issues.

FRED SEARS, INVESTOR CAPITAL FUNDS: Well, I'm very happy to see that the estimates for the S&P are going up. I think that's mostly a result of what's happening in the technology today. And I think that by far the best place to be invested is the semis right now, because the earnings are -- are going to blow through expectations.

LISOVICZ: Over on the big board, attention focused on a flurry of merger announcements in the paper, consumer foods, and financial industries. But caution over tomorrow's Consumer Price Index, a key inflation indicator, kept the Dow virtually unchanged. The blue chip index closed at 10,804, down eight points.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LISOVICZ: The majority of companies has yet to report second- quarter results, but analysts say profits are looking so strong that investors are expecting the momentum to carry over into the third quarter. If so, Wall Street could enjoy an Indian summer rally -- Stuart.

VARNEY: And wouldn't that be nice?

LISOVICZ: That's optimistic.

VARNEY: Got it. Thanks, Susan.

Taking a closer look at some of the biggest stock movers today: First off is BroadCom. That stock soared nearly 11 1/2, closing just under 261 1/2. That's a new 52-week high there.

Sycamore Networks soared almost 12 after jumping more than 10 points Friday. And Lycos gained more than eight. BroadVision and Brocade Communications both higher as well.

Check some of today's biggest losers -- they are there. Commerce One sank more than 5 1/2. Aetna down four and change. ING would not comment on reports that it was the leading bidder for Aetna's financial services unit.

Financial stocks also took it on the chin today after recent gains: Morgan Stanley, for example -- Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, that is, down four, and Merrill Lynch lost 3 1/2. Charles Schwab, by the way, down more than three points.

BAY: Two megadeals announced today that would bring together some of the best-known brands at the supermarket. Up first, a bid to create one of the world's largest food companies. General Mills said it will pay nearly $5 1/2 billion in stock for Diageo's Pillsbury unit, plus debt. But investors seemed less than enthused. Shares of General Mills fell nearly 2 3/4 today. In New York trading, Diageo shares gained more than a half.

Fred Katayama has more.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED ACTOR: Oh, I've always wanted to do that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FRED KATAYAMA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The Pillsbury Doughboy agreed to walk down the aisle with Betty Crocker, but shareholders on Betty's side of the aisle are not giggling. Her parent, General Mills, will pay $5.4 billion in stock and take on more than 5 billion in debt to buy Pillsbury from Britain's Diageo. Together General Mills and Pillsbury will boast sales of nearly $13 billion, making it the U.S.'s third-largest food company and a powerhouse in snacks and quick-prep foods.

STEVE SANGER, GENERAL MILLS: When you add together our product line and Pillsbury product line, you will have -- about 80 percent of those products will either be ready to eat or quick preparation. That's preparation of 15 minutes or less. And that is exactly what consumers today are looking for.

KATAYAMA: But shareholders didn't buy into the deal, sending the stock down nearly 8 percent.

BAY: Stuart, still to come on MONEYLINE, first it was music, now Hollywood is fighting over its flicks: a new high-tech battle over swapping movies on the Internet, when MONEYLINE returns.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: He has already shattered all the records for spending in a Senate race, and now Jon Corzine may be able to spend a lot more in his quest for a New Jersey Senate seat. The former top executive at Goldman Sachs has filed to sell more than 411,000 Goldman shares, and that's nearly 10 percent of his total holdings, currently worth about $42 million. A campaign spokesman says that the motivation behind Corzine's move is to -- quote -- "diversify his financial risk." Corzine spent more than $36 million during the primary, winning the Democratic nomination. Goldman Sachs stock closed off more than 3 points today at 101 1/8.

BAY: The battle over downloadable music took a back seat to a different Web war today. Fearful of another Napster, Hollywood is trying to stop distribution of a software program that helps turn DVD movies into files that can be swapped. The dispute moved to U.S. District Court in Manhattan today.

Bruce Francis has more.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Meet Hollywood's newest bogey man. Sixteen-year-old Jon Johamsen wrote software that cracks the code that encrypts DVDs. The Norwegian teen says he did it so that he could watch movies on his Linux-based PC.

JON JOHAMSEN, SOFTWARE DEVELOPER: We wanted to add DVD support, playback support to unsupported operating systems. At that time, only Microsoft Windows could play DVDs.

FRANCIS: But when Internet hacker journal "2600" posted the software, Hollywood studios, including the entertainment division of Time Warner, the parent of CNN, sued the publisher. The goal: to avoid another Napster, which allows users to swap free music.

LEON GOLD, PLAINTIFF'S ATTORNEY: That's exactly one of the main things that we're worried about, because there are already up on the Internet file-swapping operations asking for people to swap movies, and that has already started and that will grow pretty quickly.

PROTESTERS (shouting): Save free speech!

FRANCIS: But the man behind "2600" says he has a right to publish the code.

EMMANUEL GOLDSTEIN, EDITOR, "2600" MAGAZINE: The right to publish is what we exist for. So when someone comes up to you and says, you don't have the right to publish this, you don't have the right to talk about this, you don't have the right to figure this out, that's something that all publishers feel very deeply.

FRANCIS: While the case invites comparison to the suit against Napster, it's far more difficult to get a DVD movie ready to swap. To Napsterize a movie you first have to obtain a copy of Jon Johamsen's DECSS software. You'll also need other programs, including Leech FTP 207 and MIRC 3.71.

Then, to get the file ready to swap, you have to convert it to another format called DIVX. You do that by stripping out the video signal, then the audio signal, and then resynchronize the sound and image. Point, click, and grab the popcorn, it's not.

(on camera): The first witness in the case, a Carnegie-Mellon University professor who, at the request of the film studios, tried to copy a movie from DVD and get it ready to swap over the Internet. It took him and his assistant some 20 hours.

At U.S. District Court, Bruce Francis, CNN Financial News, New York. (END VIDEOTAPE)

VARNEY: And up next, "Ahead of the Curve," some of what you need to know tonight before those markets open up again tomorrow.

You're watching MONEYLINE.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Checking some of what could make news on Wall Street tomorrow, as we mentioned, second quarter earnings season heats up in earnest with Dow components Honeywell and Philip Morris expected to report a 12-percent profit jump over last year. General Motors is forecasted to post earnings of $2.80 a share. Tech heavyweights Microsoft and Intel are also on tap to report tomorrow. Investors expect Intel profits to nearly double. Also watch for results from Apple Computer.

On the economic front, the consumer price index for June is due out. Economists are forecasting a rise of .4 percent and expect the core rate, which excludes food and energy, to edge up .2 percent.

To stay a step ahead of the markets, tune into "AHEAD OF THE CURVE" every day at 5:00 a.m. Eastern on CNN.

VARNEY: And finally tonight, economic advice from the "Seven Million Dollar Man," at least that's what the publishing world is calling Jack Welch, the chief executive superstar of General Electric, who last week landed a record $7.1 million to chronicle his life and career.

This weekend, he gave "New York Times" columnist Maureen Dowd a sneak preview of some topics he might cover, even weighing in on the controversial debate over whether there is a new economy. Welch's answer? "There's no new economy. It's the same old economy with new technology." Not such a surprise considering that Welch has taken the oldest company on the Dow and souped up its business with Internet ventures.

Now, tomorrow on MONEYLINE, another legendary executive with a similar take on the new economy: an in-depth "Headliner" profile of Andy Grove, that on Intel's 32nd birthday.

BAY: That is MONEYLINE for this Monday. I'm Willow Bay in Los Angeles.

VARNEY: And I'm Stuart Varney. Good night from New York. "CROSSFIRE" is next.

urn:contentItem:429N-S7P0-009B-G2V6-00000-00Dow Falls 10.70 to 10,946.72; Nasdaq Tumbles 56.67 to 2,607.82; Productivity Gains Beat Expectations2001-02-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30Paul O'Neill, Brian FinnertyBusinessSHOW01020700V19Dow Falls 10.70 to 10,946.72; Nasdaq Tumbles 56.67 to 2,607.82; Productivity Gains Beat ExpectationsWillow Bay, Stuart Varney, Allan Chernoff, Wolf Blitzer, John King, Lisa Leiter, Terry Keenan, Fred Katayama, Steve Young, Myron Kandel

The Dow Jones industrial averge Wednesday fell 10.70 points to 10,946. 72 while the Nasdaq tumbled 56.67 to 2,607.82. Productivity, one of the linchpins of the economy's record expansion, rose more than expected last quarter. U.S. workers continued to pick up their productivity in the final months of 2000, but at a slower pace than in the previous quarter. Output rose at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in the fourth quarter, down from three. For the entire year it was up 4.3 percent, the fastest pace since 1983.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight, a perilous plunge in Cisco drives the Nasdaq under. Is this year's tech comeback in jeopardy?

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: One-on-one with the treasury secretary; Paul O'Neill's take on tax cuts, the recession threat, and America's role in the global economy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PAUL O'NEILL, SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY: I think it is important that we not accept the idea that we are the world's fireman.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: A day trading sensation gets his comeuppance -- Tokyo Joe out to settle with regulators.

VARNEY: And, today's frightening drama at the White House: the very latest on the shooting outside the south lawn.

ANNOUNCER: Live, from coast to coast, this is MONEYLINE.

BAY: Welcome to MONEYLINE. I'm Willow Bay in Los Angeles.

VARNEY: Hello Willow, and hello everyone. I'm Stuart Varney in New York.

Our top story tonight: the Cisco skid on Wall Street. The Nasdaq took a wild ride after the networking giant, Cisco Systems, shocked investors last night with a rare profit letdown. Cisco's stock tumbled, wiping out more than $30 billion worth of market value. The Nasdaq plunged well over a hundred points at its low; it recovered most of those losses, then dipped again ending down 56 points at 2,607.

The Dow took its own ride, pushing back above 11,000 once again, only to end down 11 points at 10,946. The S&P fell 11 points, to close just under 1,341.

BAY: Stuart, as you noted, the Nasdaq had cut some of its losses by day's end and so did Cisco. But it wasn't enough to prevent the stock from closing at an 18-month low, on volume that was one of the biggest ever for any U.S. stock, more than 280 million shares traded. Cisco shares are now trading at levels not seen since the summer of '99.

As Allan Chernoff reports, Cisco created a storm that battered tech stocks across the spectrum.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ALLAN CHERNOFF, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The Cisco cyclone caught nearly all tech stocks and shredded their prices. The storm so powerful because few technology companies are as highly regarded and influential as Cisco Systems. So, when Cisco catches a cold it's contagious.

MICHAEL PALAZZI, CIBC WORLD MARKETS: Cisco has a lot of businesses that touch a lot of different sectors in the technology area. And the feeling is now that at Cisco, has had bad performance in the past quarter and it doesn't look good in the next couple of quarters, what does that tell you about the sector?

CHERNOFF: Cisco fell to 31 1/16. Network Appliance dropped to a new 52-week low as other competitors sank in sympathy.

The data networking gear that Cisco builds is packed with components. Cisco warned its inventories are heavy, bad news for suppliers like Vitesse Semiconductor, which gets about 10 percent business from Cisco. Applied Micro Circuits dependent on Cisco for 15 percent of sales; and PMC-Sierra, relying on Cisco for 30 percent of sales by some industry estimates.

JIM WAGGONER, SANDS BROTHERS & COMPANY: A lot of the companies that've been standing by, gearing up production, maintaining production to supply Cisco, will have to slow down.

CHERNOFF: A slow down looms for companies making components for high speed networking data connections, like Brocade, QLogic, and Emulex. And for makers of programmable logic devices, like Lattice, Altera, Actel, and Xilinx.

Cisco's declining growth rate carries psychological weight as well. It raises concerns that the best days of the technology boom may be past, a prospect some traders fear Wall Street may not have fully discounted.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CHERNOFF: An illustration of Cisco's fall from grace today. Yesterday, Cisco was the second most important stock on the Nasdaq, accounting for 6.6 percent of the price-weighted index. Today, Cisco has fallen to number 3, behind Microsoft and Intel. Cisco's stock accounts for 5.9 percent of the composite right now -- Willow

BAY: Allan, and boy, what a storm it caused. Allan Chernoff, thanks.

We'll have more on the tech outlook later in the broadcast, with Brian Finnerty, head of Nasdaq stock trading at CE Unterberg Towbin. VARNEY: An Indiana man accused of firing a handgun outside the White House is in stable condition tonight, more about that now from Wolf Blitzer, in Washington. Wolf?

WOLF BLITZER, CNN ANCHOR: Thanks, Stuart. Federal prosecutors say they'll decide by tomorrow how to charge Robert Pickett. He's the Indiana tax accountant who allegedly opened fire outside the White House today. Just before noon, reports of a man with a pistol near the south lawn sent Secret Service agents racing to cover the grounds. Fot the details on what happened, our John King is standing by now at the White House -- John.

JOHN KING, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Wolf, that scene you saw inside the White House compound -- agents rushing around the compound to make sure there was no intruder on the grounds, triggered by a very simple but startling alert they heard over the radio system. Shots fired outside the White House gate; that was at 11:22 a.m. this morning.

You see here the scene outside, uniformed Secret Service officers -- it was they who responded to the scene and after ten minutes of urging the man to drop his handgun and surrender, one uniformed Secrets Service officer shot him in the knee. There you see the shooting site outside the south perimeter of the White House. The compound some distance away, but, of course, extraordinary steps taken inside the compound as well, just to guarantee the president security.

President Bush was in the building at the time -- he was in the White House residence exercising. Vice President Cheney was in his office in the West Wing. Both were immediately told that there was indeed a security incident near the campus, but the White House says, both just kept about their business.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ARI FLEISCHER, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: During this time, the president was in the residence, was never in any danger; the vice president was working in his West Wing office, also was never in any danger at any point.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KING: Now, the man in custody tonight -- the investigation just beginning, we're told by sources Secret Service officials did have a brief conversation with Mr. Pickett during the ambulance ride to a hospital here in Washington. They of course want to interview him again as they try to figure out why he was just outside the White House brandishing a handgun, but they say, at no point, did he try to get on to the White House grounds and during that police scene around him, that he was suicidal, mentioning that he wanted to kill himself -- Wolf.

BLITZER: John King at the White House, thank you very much.

Pickett was rushed to George Washington University Hospital, where doctors are operating on his knee. He's also undergoing psychiatric evaluation. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. YOLANDA HAYWOOD, GW UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL: It is part of a standard evaluation under these circumstances.

QUESTION: What circumstances?

HAYWOOD: The circumstances of someone who sustained a gunshot wound outside the White House.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BLITZER: Doctors say Pickett was unusually calm for someone with such a severe wound, and I'll have much more on this story and the rest of the day's news on "WOLF BLITZER REPORTS," that's 8:00 p.m. Eastern, 5:00 on the west coast -- Willow.

BAY: Wolf, thanks. We'll see you then.

The incident at the White House happened shortly after President Bush hosted another event, pushing his $1.6 trillion tax cutting plan. Mr. Bush surrounded himself on the south lawn with families that he met on the campaign trail, "real live Americans, " as he put it, who would benefit from his version of tax relief.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEORGE W. BUSH, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: When we have surpluses, we must remember who pay the bills in America. And it's these folks who pay the bills in the country. And they deserve relief, and so I call upon Congress. When they think about tax relief, to think about the members of our tax family who represent all people of our country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAY: Many Democrats insist that average Americans won't be the big winners under the Bush plan, but wealthy Americans will be. The tax fight will begin in earnest tomorrow when the president is expected to send his proposal to Congress.

VARNEY: A key player who'll help Mr. Bush lead that fight: Paul O'Neill. Next up on MONEYLINE, a candid, one-on-one talk with the new treasury secretary: just how bad is the economy? His outlook on that and much more.

Plus, DaimlerChrysler confirms what everyone feared: that the year 2000 was one big washout in terms of profits. And, will Murdoch get his hands on a media industry jewel? The latest on the story you heard here first last night: the race to grab Direct TV.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: President Bush all week has been selling Main Street on his tax cutting plan. And today, his treasury secretary Paul O'Neill took on Wall Street, making the rounds in Manhattan. The former head of Alcoa toured J.P. Morgan after having breakfast with top Wall Street executives, investment bankers and fund managers.

Earlier, I sat down with the treasury secretary and began by asking him if the Bush administration was 100 percent behind making the proposed tax cut retroactive.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PAUL O'NEILL, TREASURY SECRETARY: Absolutely. The president has said that we should have changes in the marginal rate structure for every tax paid in America, and the other day when he articulated exactly what he wanted to be in that package, he said he thought it made sense to make it retroactive to the first of January, 2001, so you bet, we are going to do everything we can, we are going to mount every argument that we know how to mount, to cause this policy to be implemented, hopefully very quickly.

VARNEY: Are we in recession now, as some economists say?

O'NEILL: No

VARNEY: We're not? Zero growth like Mr. Greenspan says?

O'NEILL: Well, I take my economic advice in a certain way from Mr. Greenspan, and if he says the growth rate is about zero, I don't think there is a basis for saying it is worse than that at the moment; I don't see any data that convinces me it is worse than zero or maybe even .5 percent real growth in the economy right now.

VARNEY: Is the economy getting worse? Are we sliding still?

O'NEILL: I think the evidence is really very conflicting at the moment. We are not operating at the level we have been for the last four or five years, but it doesn't seem to be eroding further and there are even some signs -- conflicting signs, I would say -- a narrow range but not an acceptable rate of real growth.

VARNEY: In Mexico, in Asia, and in Russia, when those economies were in collapse or near collapsing, America responded with what amounted to a large bailout and that became essentially the policy of America to deal with this kind of situation for many, many years. Is that policy going to change?

O'NEILL: I think it is important that we not accept the idea that we are the world's fireman. Now, I think it is not particularly brilliant for either the U.S. or the international financial institutions to bail out people who dug their own ditch. I do think it makes sense to help people who are victims of circumstances beyond their control, but I would rather not be a party to a process that is focused on heroic firefighting efforts as contrasted from a long- headed collection of information and data and policy initiative that avoids the need to be heroic firefighters.

VARNEY: So you see, stepping in before the collapse really starts.

O'NEILL: Absolutely. VARNEY: Take some action, either advisory or financial, in advance of the catastrophe happening; that's your policy?

O'NEILL: I think that is a fair characterization, but it also seems to me we need to be careful about not becoming the world's meddlers -- that is to say interfering in the issues of sovereign states, but to the degree that sovereign states expect us and the international institutions to be there in the event that they are a victim of circumstance beyond their control, then they need to be working on these underlying problems, because I really don't think it makes sense for we or the rest of the world with financial means, to save people from themselves when they have effectively deliberately caused their financial system to fall in to a state of disarray.

VARNEY: With Japan, what will you offer, advice, expertise, maybe threats, maybe jaw-boning, how would you characterize the economic relationship you want to establish with Japan?

O'NEILL: Over time, I think we need to develop a process that helps Japan to realize the full economic potential they have for the benefit of their people. First of all, I think it is really important if you were to put yourself in the position of the people of the leadership in Japan or any other country you want to name, and then say to yourself, if you were in that position, how would you like it to have Americans, or anyone else for that matter, giving you unsolicited advice about how to run your society.

You would probably say thank you very much, why don't you go home, and stop bothering us. So if you look at it from their point of view, I think they don't need gratuitous advice from us, but they need -- they may need ideas and help from us, and I think we need to be saying to them, we assume that you would like for your society to advance at a faster rate than what you have been doing and we may have some ideas, but what we would like to know is how can we be helpful to you in moving up to that higher rate of real growth, rather than giving them lectures about how we would do it.

urn:contentItem:415S-HXH0-009B-G51K-00000-00Dow Falls 25.16 to 11,195.49; Nasdaq Tumbles 82.06 to 3,896.35; Crude Oil Hits $35 a Barrel2000-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisCNN STREET SWEEP 15:59Ken Tower, Sam Brownback, Paul Keegan, Marlene DanielleBusinessSHOW00091100V61Dow Falls 25.16 to 11,195.49; Nasdaq Tumbles 82.06 to 3,896.35; Crude Oil Hits $35 a BarrelJan Hopkins, Rhonda Schaffler, Allan Chernoff, Greg Clarkin, Lou Waters, Lisa Leiter, Pat Kiernan, Stuart Varney

The Dow Jones industrial average Monday fell 25.16 point to 11,195.49 while the Nasdaq tumbled 82.06 to 3,896.35. The price of oil rose to $35.05 a barrel in response to news that OPEC has agreed to increase production by only 800,000 barrels a day.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

JAN HOPKINS, CNN ANCHOR: You're looking at live pictures from the New York Stock Exchange. We're less than 60 seconds away from the closing bell. Good afternoon. I'm Jan Hopkins.

Let's find out how the markets are doing in this last minute of trading.

RHONDA SCHAFFLER, CNN CORRESPONDENT: The Dow industrials set to close lower, tripped up by "Big Blue." I'll have details.

ALLAN CHERNOFF, CNN CORRESPONDENT: The Nasdaq composite suffers a turnaround, big caps pulling the index lower.

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: And OPEC increases oil production, but the price of oil soars in New York trading. I will tell you why.

HOPKINS: Do makers of violent media target kids under 17 and do retailers do little to restrict access? We'll hear from both sides.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: This is like now and forever they're going to be there -- here, now, forever.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HOPKINS: The curtain has fallen on Broadway's longest and most profitable musical. You can have a piece of "Cats." We'll find out from the only original member of the cast about how.

It's Monday, September 11th. Live from the New York Stock Exchange, this is STREET SWEEP.

We are waiting for a news conference from the players at Indiana University about the firing of basketball coach Bob Knight. We will bring that to you live as it happens. But first, let's look to see what happened on Wall Street. Technology stocks pushing the Dow Jones industrial down.

Rhonda Schaffler has been covering the action here on the floor of the Exchange, and we join her now -- Rhonda. SCHAFFLER: That's right, Jan. The Dow really was bouncing all over the place for much of the day, but starting to trend lower due to losses in two of its main technology components: Hewlett-Packard, which is in talks to buy a technology consultant business from an accounting firm, and IBM as Goldman Sachs lowered earnings estimates on the company by a couple of pennies, citing the weak euro. So we had a lot of weakness in these tech components. At the same time, the financials across the board showed strength.

Talk of another deal: Goldman Sachs involved this time. It's buying Leeds & Kellogg. So, that sort of brought up all the merger talk again. And also the oil stocks performed quite well, as oil prices, which Greg made reference to, continued to climb in New York -- Jan.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Rhonda Schaffler, here on the floor of the Exchange.

Jitters over third-quarter earnings sending technology stocks lower. Allan Chernoff joins us now from the Nasdaq, where that was scene of the downfall for technology -- Allan.

CHERNOFF: OK, Jan, at the Nasdaq marketsite, we've got some screens to show you exactly what's been happening over the past five trading sessions. Have a look. Last Friday, the Nasdaq composite at 4,234, one, two, three, four, five trading days. We are off 337 points. My quick calculation, approximately 7 percent or so: 10 percent is what's considered a correction on Wall Street.

Let's have a look inside of the marketplace and look at some of the five big stocks that moved the market today. All of these stocks at one point were in positive territory.

Cisco down more than 2; Intel down a fraction; Oracle down 3 1/8; Sun Microsystems, a big hit, down 5 1/2; JDS-Uniphase, down 4 9/16. Add all those five stocks up together, you've got more than 20 percent of the Nasdaq composite. That's the story, Jan.

HOPKINS: Thank you. OPEC ministers saying yes to more oil output yesterday, but the decision, expected to cool off the price hike, seems to have had the opposite effect. Major airlines forced to add a $20 fuel surcharge on round-trip tickets because of high oil prices.

Greg Clarkin has been covering the action in the oil market today. He joins us from our New York studios.

So, Greg, you would expect more oil output, lower prices. But in fact, prices went higher.

CLARKIN: Caught a lot of folks off-guard today, Jan. OPEC agreeing to increase oil production by 800,000 barrels a day. But still, in New York trading this morning, there was no selling. It was just buying. We saw the price of oil rising sharply, and by the end of the trading session it was up a $1.42 a barrel, trading at over $35, $35.05 to be exact. The bottom line here, traders say, that yes, there were some technical factors involved in the trading today, such as short covering, but still a lot of folks now believe that that 800,000 barrels a day really is not going to make a dent in the world demand for oil. And a lot folks here in the U.S. are saying that this country now remains poorly positioned for the winter heating season.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PETER BEUTEL, CAMERON HANOVER: I think we're going to be looking at one of the most volatile winters that we have ever seen. If the weather becomes bitterly cold at any point, we are going to see prices of heating oil, I would expect, over $2 in some locations. We will see spot outages. We'll see terminals in various states just run out of oil for a day or two, if it gets very, very cold.

You know, I mean, the squirrels are better prepared for the winter this year than we are. I mean, it's really pathetic.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CLARKIN: And keep in mind, by the time that oil is retrieved and processed, it will be too late to have an impact, at least on the beginning of the winter heating season.

Jan, back to you.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Greg Clarkin, at our New York bureau.

Joining us now, our guest host for the hour, Ken Tower of UST Securities.

So, Ken, these higher oil prices, are they part of the sell-off in technology stocks?

KEN TOWER, UST SECURITIES: I think so. In the last week, the degree of increase in oil has taken people by surprise. Last week, the 10-year Treasury made a new low for the year. Now, it's popped up a little bit, sort of a countertrend move. The insurance stocks, the bank stocks are all cooling off while interest rates go up, and the oil, especially oil services, small oil stocks are hot.

Just a countertrend move, taking a pause from the summer rally.

HOPKINS: So you would take advantage of some of the sell-off to buy some of these technology stocks a little cheaper?

TOWER: Technology stocks, bank stocks, insurance stocks, a bunch of insurance stocks popped back and up made new highs today, so you're not getting a whole lot of weakness there. But still, that's definitely where we'd be going. Even the oil service and the smaller oils, as I say -- the big oils aren't moving.

But yes, technology stocks and the others that are selling off here, we're looking to buy them. HOPKINS: I was talking to my fuel oil supplier last week, and he was saying that every day they get a fax saying what the price should be. Prices are going up 5 cents a gallon a day. I mean, this is really going to impact people's pocketbooks.

TOWER: That's right. The Federal Reserve is not going to have to raise interest rates because all of this money is getting drawn out of the economy to pay for higher oil, especially in the Northeast, and gas prices. So, that's going to cool the economy off without higher interest rates. That's where you've seen interest rates going down and making new lows for the year.

HOPKINS: Thanks very much, Ken Tower.

The student presser has been expected from Indiana University; it has been canceled, though. The story is far from over. So let's check in with Lou Waters for that and the rest of the day's headlines.

Lou, what happened.

LOU WATERS, CNN ANCHOR: Hello, Jan. Thousands of Indiana University students rallied behind the basketball coach, Bob Knight, after the school fires him: 10 students were arrested at a protest yesterday that stretched into the early morning hours. The stepfather of the freshman who accused Knight of grabbing his arm says his son is receiving threats.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK SHAW, KENT HARVEY'S STEPFATHER; I understand these people who are very, very upset. I know they love the coach. I know there are a lot of good things about Bob Knight. So I want them to know that their remarks to me, I'm not going to take personally.

I would ask, however, that they use some caution with regard to Kent and to his brothers and these boys, because they did nothing wrong. This is not about them. It's about the coach. And I would ask them to use some hesitation in terms of what they have to say.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATERS: Knight says he will tell his side of the story within the next few days.

The Clinton administration accuses Hollywood of aggressively marketing violent forms of entertainment to children. A Federal Trade Commission study concludes entertainment companies routinely target youngsters with movies, videogames, and music intended for people age 17 and older.

President Clinton says such marketing mocks the ratings systems. He says the government may intervene if the industry does not fix the problem on its own.

Next on STREET SWEEP, the author of the legislation which called for the FTC study, Senator Sam Brownback of Kansas. Also, Paul Keegan, a writer from the videogame industry.

Two pilots are killed when their planes collide in Florida. Today's collision happened near Fort Pierce. One of the planes was a single-engine aircraft, the other a twin-engined craft. After the collision, both planes crashed into an orange grove.

It's busy day for the Space Shuttle Atlantis. Two crewmembers, an American and a Russian, have successfully completed a space walk outside the International Space Station. Later today, the crew plans to enter the station to unload the supplies.

More news anytime. I'm Lou Waters. Now back to Jan Hopkins in New York.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Lou. Ahead on STREET SWEEP, we will check the after-hours trading with Pat Kiernan at Instinet. Plus, as Lou was telling you, we will have a debate about kids' access to violent media. We'll talk to a senator and a man who covers the videogame industry.

And later, you can get a piece of Broadway history from the "Cats" garage sale. Details from an original "cat, Marlene Danielle, coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HOPKINS: The government turning up the heat on the entertainment industry today: the Federal Trade Commission slamming the industry for routinely and intentionally targeting children in the marketing of movies, music and videogames that are meant for adults.

An FTC study found that 80 percent of R-rated movies target kids under 17; 70 percent of Mature-rated videogames are aimed at kids under 17. In addition, 85 percent of kids between 13 and 16 are able to buy music with explicit lyrics -- or violent video games -- while 50 percent were allowed into R-rated movies.

For more on both sides of the debate, we'll hear from Republican Senator Sam Brownback, and Paul Keegan, a freelance writer who has covered this topic extensively.

First, Senator Brownback, who believes the industry should regulate itself first and retailers and movie theaters should more strictly enforce age restrictions. Joining us from Topeka, Kansas, with more is Republican Senator Sam Brownback.

So the industry hasn't done a very good job of regulating itself up to this point. Why would you think that, all of a sudden, it would do a better job?

SEN. SAM BROWNBACK (R), KANSAS: Well, maybe the light finally shining on them -- and the study saying that clearly and conclusively they are marketing inappropriate properties to children might cause them to just do the right thing. What I hope is we can keep a focus on the industry and hopefully shame them into saying: Look, we shouldn't be putting these products out for kids and then target- marketing them for kids. We will clean up our act. Maybe now they will do that.

HOPKINS: But if the industry doesn't, say in a certain period of time, are you prepared to propose legislation that would actually regulate the situation, like the tobacco industry?

BROWNBACK: Well, I'm opposed to censorship. But I must say that this industry, the entertainment industry, is going down the very same track as the tobacco industry. They have become hooked to sex and violence in their products, like tar and nicotine. They're now marketing a product to kids, like Joe Camel was. And they are going to keep getting more and more pressure from the legislative bodies if they keep going down this road.

Why don't they just stop? Just do the right thing. You can make money without target-marketing the kids, and being just addicted to hyper-violence and sexual-vulgar activity. You can make money another way. Just don't do it.

HOPKINS: How do you -- but how do you mean target? What do they really do in order to target to those kids under 17?

BROWNBACK: Well, a number of the -- in the FTC study, they were going through marketing plans -- that what they were doing within the industry to market their product within publications, on shows that primarily teenage audience was watching and consuming. And they were saying in their marketing plans: We are going to market this aggressively to teenagers.

That was explicitly stated in a number of their marketing plans. And just think about it for a minute. How many shock rock fans are there over the age of 18? There's just not many. And yet the lyrics in there are hyper-violent, suicidal. It's a really -- ugliness…

HOPKINS: Let's hear the other part of the debate. Thanks very much, Senator Sam Brownback of Kansas.

Let's bring in freelance writer Paul Keegan, who has covered the issue essentially. He comes to us from CNNfn's New York bureau.

So you've heard the case for maybe shaming the industry into doing more. Is it a First Amendment case or is the industry really doing something wrong to target these kids under 17?

PAUL KEEGAN, FREELANCE WRITER: Well, it's clearly a First Amendment case. As to why -- I think, Senator Brownback said why don't they stop. There's six-billion reasons why they don't stop in the videogame and computer-game industry. That six-billion dollars worth of revenue this year, and $7.5 million in Hollywood. It's a tremendously lucrative enterprise. And they are going to market to kids, because it is a huge market.

And the question is: Can the government, and should the government get into the business of regulation, which is a form of censorship? Even though it is only the advertising and only that level now, it's only a matter of time before that opens the door to the content as well. HOPKINS: But we've already heard from the senator that he hopes the industry regulates itself. Do you believe that the government should step in? Is it out of control?

KEEGAN: I personally don't. That's my personal opinion. Everyone has to make up their minds on their own. And this is a very difficult subject, because, on the one hand, videogames in particular are probably the most violent form of mass entertainment ever invented. They're really quite astonishing. And kids who play the games are not just watching Arnold Schwarzenegger blow somebody up. They're actually pulling the trigger themselves.

And they're entering a very graphic, realistic, three-dimensional environment. So it does raise some very troubling questions.

HOPKINS: But…

KEEGAN: In a way, we're very similar to where we were at the advent of television, where the technology was new, people kind of didn't really know much about the effect it had. But then later, there were a lot of studies -- 40 years now -- showing…

HOPKINS: Clearly, this is going to something that we are going to continue to debate. So thanks for joining us, Paul Keegan, freelance writer, and also Senator Brownback.

Just ahead: What do you do with 18 years of props and costumes? The Broadway musical, "Cats," is finished. We'll tell you how you can keep its memory alive. The only original cast member joins us with details.

Plus…

LISA LEITER, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Lisa Leiter at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, where the closing bell just rang. I will have the final numbers for you and what it could mean for stocks tomorrow morning on Wall Street -- when STREET SWEEP continues.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HOPKINS: Eighteen years and hundreds of millions of dollars later, all that's left from the Broadway musical, "Cats," is the props and the costumes. Final curtain for the longest-running Broadway show went down last night at the Winter Garden Theater. Now everything must go in the biggest garage sale Broadway has ever seen.

Joining us now is the only original cast member from "Cats," Marlene Danielle.

So you must have some kind of aftershock or something that this week, you are not going to be making yourself up, putting on this wig…

MARLENE DANIELLE, BROADWAY ACTRESS, "CATS": Right.

HOPKINS: … and going back to this performance that you've been in…

DANIELLE: Right.

HOPKINS: … every week for 18 years.

DANIELLE: Right. I can be human again.

HOPKINS: So are you looking forward to not doing "Cats"?

DANIELLE: Um, I'm looking forward to the hereafter in a way. And I'm going to miss the show and my family there tremendously, yes.

HOPKINS: For 18 years, you were employed…

DANIELLE: Yes.

HOPKINS: … every week, Broadway actress, really unheard of.

DANIELLE: Exactly.

HOPKINS: But you have a lot of financial wherewithal now. Did you invest your money well, so that you would have a bright future?

DANIELLE: Well -- exactly, you know. And I think this is a good omen: here at the stock exchange the day after the show closes. Yes, I tried to. I tried to put that money away and invest it so I would be able to continue to work and feel comfortable.

HOPKINS: Into what you want to do.

DANIELLE: Yes.

HOPKINS: What about the props? How can people take part in this garage sale?

DANIELLE: Well, there's two ways. There's going to be a sale at the Winter Garden Theater on Saturday, September 16 from 10:00 to 6:00. It's an auction. All the proceeds go to Broadway Care/Equity Fights AIDS. For those people who cannot be there, but would like to bid and get something, they can go online -- and there's www.amazon.com -- same thing: Broadway Care/Equity Fights AIDS.

And they can bid on -- starting September 12 through the 29th.

HOPKINS: Thanks very much. Thanks you for joining us. And good luck to you in your afterlife.

DANIELLE: Thank you. You're welcome.

HOPKINS: Now for a preview of how the stock market may open tomorrow's session, let's bring in Lisa Leiter. She's tracking S&P futures action at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange -- Lisa.

LEITER: Hi, Jan.

Well, S&P futures, the December contract closing two points above fair value, which at this point, would indicate a higher opening tomorrow morning for the Dow on Wall Street if this holds up. We have got a little post-trading session next to me. That's what all the noise is. The Nasdaq 100 futures finishing lower, down 87 points there, the Nasdaq really building on last week's 6-percent drop, really extending those losses, and it wasn't looking good for tech stocks today.

Jan, back to you.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Lisa.

Now let's look at some of the big board movers and rejoin Rhonda Schaffler here on the floor of the exchange -- Rhonda.

SCHAFFLER: Hi there, Jan.

There were a couple of weak technology stocks here during the regular trading session, including IBM. Big Blue got its earnings estimates cut by a couple of pennies by Goldman Sachs, which also lowered its revenue growth outlook for Big Blue, and it cited the weak Euro. But the analysts at Goldman keep the recommended rating on the stock, and in fact, it's not projecting out for IBM for 2001. In other words, the currency problem might be a short-term issue there.

Hewlett-Packard, the Dow's other big tech component fell sharply today, that on talk it's interested in buying a technology consultant business from PriceWaterhouseCooper, it would make Hewlett-Packard a little bit more like IBM. And one other stock on the move here, Goldman Sachs, a strong gain for that stock and many other financials, Goldman buying Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, the biggest specialist firm on the trading floor, and that is a way for Goldman, it says, to get closer to some retail customers -- Jan.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Rhonda.

Let's go to Nasdaq and bring in Allan Chernoff, he can tell us about movers there -- Allan.

CHERNOFF: OK, thanks, Jan.

In spite of that big decline we have on the Nasdaq composite, the B2B stocks -- they had a very nice day, and thank that to Covisint, that is the auto parts exchange that is planned over the Internet, and Commerce One is one of the companies very involved, a B2B company, you see the stock up 3 3/4. Genzyme took a big hit, that's because the company did a deal to buy GelTex, and GelTex is a company that makes dialysis drugs and also drugs to lower cholesterol, the acquiring company taking a hit, GelTex was actually up 16 percent today. And finally, JDS Uniphase, you see, trading down 4 percent, a lot of volatility there, it had been in positive territory this morning. There is a lot of debate on Wall Street right now as to whether there is a glut of fiber-optic cable coming down the road, and JDS Uniphase one of the giants in fiber-optics.

Back to you.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Allan.

And now let's go to Pat Kiernan, he is monitoring after-hours trading at Instinet -- Pat.

PAT KIERNAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, earnings just after the bell from Solectron, the NYSE ticker symbol SLR, the stock is trading up a dollar and a quarter on this news, 48 3/4, earnings were a penny better than Wall Street expectations. The -- a company, PRI Automation is held right now, trading has halted, they just came out with an earnings warning, said that Q4 will be below expectations. And on the other side, we had Oakley, the maker of sunglasses coming up after the bell, saying that it expects its third quarter to be above expectations, it's a bit higher here at Instinet.

Jan, back to you.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Pat.

Now let's see what's on "MONEYLINE" tonight, bring in Stuart Varney -- Stuart.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Thanks very much, Jan.

Coming up tonight on MONEYLINE: the September slump for tech stocks. Yes, the Nasdaq once again heads South after last week's disappointing performance. We're going to talk to top tech money manager Roger McNamee, find out what he is buying now and also what he is selling. We'll also have all the day's business headlines, including this tremendous rally in the oil markets. Plus, a new technology hitting the market that gives new meaning to the term "wireless world." They call it BlueTooth, and Web surfers may be in for the ride of their life. It's all about very easy access anytime, anywhere. All that is on "MONEYLINE" tonight at 6:30 Eastern -- Jan.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Stuart.

We'll have more with our guest host, Ken Tower, when we come back.

And our trivia question for today: How much has the Broadway blockbuster "Cats" grossed over the past 18 years? The answer, when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HOPKINS: The answer to our trivia question: How much has the Broadway blockbuster "Cats" grossed over the past 18 years? Since 1982, box-office gross for "Cats" in New York, more than $400 million.

Joining us now with some final thoughts, our guest host, Ken Tower. Interesting, 1982, the beginning of the bull market, was the beginning of "Cats," any relationship?

TOWER: I don't think so, but it's interesting to point out anyway.

HOPKINS: The market today, more advancers than decliners, even though the market was down.

TOWER: That's right. All the news that we're hearing is about the big stocks that went down today, and that is the story, but the underlying tone in the market is very positive. You've had about five or six days now where you've had in -- you've been in this correction, there's still only about 1 percent of issues traded making new lows, that's a real sign of strength in the markets right now.

HOPKINS: So which ones would you pick at this point?

TOWER: I think you're buying the big brokerage stocks, big banks, the money-center banks like Citicorp, that kind of thing, as well as oil services and smaller oil companies. But financials in general -- and then the biotechs, and the tech stocks, they're short- term plays because they are very volatile and they're not cheap, but they're fun stocks to buy.

HOPKINS: Thanks, Ken Tower.

That's all for this half hour of STREET SWEEP. "SHOWBIZ TODAY" will wrap up last night's Emmy awards, next on CNN. And on CNNfn, how stock trading in dollars and cents put some extra coin in investors' pockets.

I am Jan Hopkins. Thanks for watching.
