urn:contentItem:41H5-6BX0-009B-G40C-00000-00Dow Falls 66.59 to 10,326.48; Nasdaq Tumbles 190.22 to 3,229.57; AT&T Announces Breakup; Investors Punish Nortel for Revenue Disappointment2000-10-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30Michael Armstrong, Erik Gustafson, Todd EberhardBusinessSHOW00102500V19Dow Falls 66.59 to 10,326.48; Nasdaq Tumbles 190.22 to 3,229.57; AT&T Announces Breakup; Investors Punish Nortel for Revenue DisappointmentWillow Bay, Terry Keenan, Susan Lisovicz, Steve Young, Wolf Blitzer, Kelli Arena, Greg Clarkin, Peter Viles, David Haffenreffer, Myron Kandel

The Dow Jones industrial average Wednesday fell 66.59 points to 10,326. 48 while the Nasdaq tumbled 190.22 to 3,229.57. AT&T has unveiled a sweeping plan to split up the company. The breakup is supposed to be a rescue effort for AT&T's slumping stock price.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight on MONEYLINE, a Wednesday wipeout on Wall Street. Worries over the tech and telecom sectors take a 5 percent chunk out of the Nasdaq.

TERRY KEENAN, CNN ANCHOR: Sparking the turmoil: a sales miss from Nortel Networks that sent the Canadian company and the fiber- optics high-flyers plunging.

BAY: And another wrong number for AT&T. The stock sinks on a profit warning as the company announces plans to break up again. We'll talk to AT&T's boss, Michael Armstrong.

KEENAN: Plus, with the next generation of PlayStation about to hit U.S. shores, we'll check out how one company is looking to score big time.

ANNOUNCER: This is MONEYLINE. In Los Angeles, Willow Bay, and from New York, Terry Keenan.

BAY: Good evening and welcome to MONEYLINE. I'm Willow Bay.

KEENAN: And I'm Terry Keenan, sitting in for Stuart Varney.

We begin tonight on Wall Street and with the Nasdaq's biggest point drop in five months. A rout in fiber-optics equipment makers dragging down the Nasdaq for the third-straight day. The index plummeted 190 points or more than 5 1/2 percent, finishing out the day at 3,229. Volume was very heavy, over 2 billion shares traded.

The Dow's losses weren't as severe, but it broke a four-day winning streak. The blue chip index fell more than 66 points to close 10,326. Volume in the Big Board also heavy, more than 1.3 billion shares. Nortel pulling down the telecom stocks on the Big Board. The S&P 500 index lost more than 33, a decline of more than 2 percent.

Susan Lisovicz joins us now from the New York Stock Exchange with more on today's punishing session -- Susan.

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Terry, the culprit for today's huge slide a stock that had been largely immune from tech weakness. Nortel's earnings after-the-bell yesterday beat the Street by a penny, but its quarterly revenue growth, up nearly 90 percent, was not good enough.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

LISOVICZ (voice-over): The Nasdaq's ninth-worst point loss ever is largely blamed on a stock that doesn't even trade there. Telecom equipment-maker Nortel has been a darling on the New York Stock Exchange. But its disappointing revenue report precipitated an almost indiscriminate sell-off in tech stocks.

Nortel, the most actively traded issue on the Big Board, lost more than 29 percent of its value. But investors also punished optical networking companies on the Nasdaq, including SDL and JDS Uniphase, which are in the midst of a merger. But the damage didn't stop there. Shares of chip manufacturer Applied Micro Circuits plummeted 25 percent. Sycamore Networks more than 20.

LARRY WACHTEL, PRUDENTIAL SECURITIES: These are like the stocks that have been asleep at the switch. These stocks have made enormous gains. And people sit around with these enormous gains and say, give me more. And you know, you can't do that.

LISOVICZ: Investors also took it out on blue chip techs. Sun Microsystems shed more than nine points. Dow Component Hewlett- Packard dropped more than five. AT&T's warning that its long-distance business was declining even more than expected put pressure on the Dow. But buying in drug and financial stocks limited the damage. One lone tech bucking the sell-off, Amazon.com, which was rewarded on word that the Internet company was not losing as much money as had been expected.

ANGEL MATA, LEGG MASON: I think really what's happened here is that we probably went up a little bit too fast. There was a lot of money on the sidelines, a lot people feeling out, you know, if we weren't at the bottom, we were near the bottom. Then we saw explosion on Thursday and all day Friday, and it continued on Monday, and I think what happened was basically we got a little bit of a hangover here.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LISOVICZ: Dallas Federal Reserve Bank President Robert McTeer warned today that investors may also have a headache on Friday when the third-quarter GDP figures are released. He says those numbers could show a fairly dramatic slowdown, re-enforcing fears of a hard landing -- Terry.

KEENAN: Yes, and those comments also a negative factor today. Thank you, Susan.

And while the Nasdaq's losses were brutal today, the impact north of the border even more severe. Nortel stock accounts for almost one- third of the Toronto Exchange composite index. The TSE 300 plunged 840 points, That was a record one-day point drop. In percentage terms, it was the second-largest loss ever, a decline of more than 8 percent. BAY: Terry, accounting for a third of the Dow's losses today: AT&T. The stock plunged as the company warned its fourth-quarter profits, and 2001 profits, will fall short of analysts' forecasts because of prices for its long-distance services. That news as AT&T reported profits for the third quarter today of 38 cents a share, 2 cents better than Wall Street was looking for.

Investors had even more to digest, though. AT&T today also finally unveiled a sweeping plan to split up the company. The breakup is supposed to be a rescue effort for AT&T's slumping stock price, but investors clearly were not sold. The stock fell 3 1/2 or 13 percent, near a 52-week low.

Steve Young reports on AT&T's big plans and investors' big worries.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

STEVE YOUNG, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): AT&T's breakup plan was completely overshadowed by worries that its business is unraveling. Yet another earnings warning led SalomonSmith Barney analyst Jack Grubman to downgrade AT&T's to neutral from outperform with a comment, "We believe the business is melting down."

And another analyst used a word seldom heard on Wall Street. Sell.

ANNA-MARIE KOVACS, JANNEY MONTGOMERY SCOTT: Because of the combination of the decline of the business market more rapidly than I had expected as well as the reorganization, I downgraded it to a sell this morning.

YOUNG: Embattled CEO Michael Armstrong all the while was trying to sell what he said was a change in structure, not strategy. The board has approved a breakup into four companies. Armstrong will head the business services company, which will continue to trade under the T symbol. It will license the AT&T name to the others.

AT&T Wireless was spun off earlier this year and already trades as a tracking stock. AT&T Broadband will trade as a tracking stock, too. Within two years they'll both become real stocks with full ownership rights.

As for AT&T's consumer long-distance business, it too will be spun-off into a tracking stock and will stay that way with AT&T Business as its parent. AT&T says the companies will sell each other's services. The combined dividends will be less than what AT&T currently pays, but Armstrong says it's good deal.

MICHAEL ARMSTRONG, CEO, AT&T: Well, it's going to make the pie bigger by providing a foundation and a path to let these businesses realize their value in the marketplace.

YOUNG: At least one competitor welcomes AT&T's decision to wield the carving knife. JO NACCHIO, CEO, QWEST: When a large company changes strategy as dramatically, it's going to force them to take their eye off customers and that's generally good for the rest us.

YOUNG: Armstrong told analysts he's offended by those who say he's abandoned his strategy. One money manager said he's offended by how far AT&T's stock has fallen.

Steve Young, CNN Financial News, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: Well, Steve said Mr. Armstrong is offended at how far AT&T stock has dropped over the past year. It's lost almost half its value.

Joining us now to talk more about the breakup plan, the company's chief executive, Michael Armstrong.

Michael, thanks for joining us tonight.

ARMSTRONG: Hello, Willow.

BAY: Why are you so reluctant to call this a change in strategy?

ARMSTRONG: Well, because -- go back with me to 1998 when we set out on this course and we set a strategy in place. We had basically a company, a long-distance business, a point-to-point domestic long- distance business that in fact was an application, not a business per se. But we had to transform the AT&T company and invest in growth and invest in assets in which to base that growth. In fact, if you look at third-quarter results, and take the voice long-distance and set it aside, those growth businesses grew 20 percent in the first three quarters of this year.

BAY: So then -- but then what's keeping you, what's keeping AT&T from realizing its value? You know the criticisms: Consumers weren't interested in bundled services. Wall Street got impatient. That strategy that you set out with to begin with is flawed. What's holding you back?

ARMSTRONG: Well, the strategy's not flawed. The strategy is being realized in the growth of these businesses that we have put together given the 20 percent growth that we've achieved for the first three quarters in them. And where we've reached is an inflection point where the market value of our company disregards the growth businesses and values us on the long-distance/EPS business.

And so what we're doing is unlocking that value, providing this foundation in a path to the future growth with these new AT&T companies and permitting investors to invest in the growth businesses if that's what they want to invest in or invest in the dividend business if that's what they want to invest.

BAY: The market reaction today was less than enthusiastic. As you know, the stock dropped more than three and some analysts downgraded the company, including one with a sell recommendation. What's the market missing here?

ARMSTRONG: Well, I think, Willow, that the -- first, it was a pretty tough market today. It was a down market in general. I was listening to your comments about the Nasdaq, the tech stocks, and the communications stock.

Second, we did have an adjustment to our outlook. And that outlook adjustment had nothing to do with the growth businesses that are growing and doing well and everything to do with the long-distance business, which is in decline, and that decline accelerated across the industry, not just to AT&T. And we were forthright to predict that that decline is going to affect us. And I think that combination of a tough market and the revised outlook hit us.

BAY: Briefly, if you can, because I know this is a complicated arrangement expected to take about two years, but at the end of this process, will an investor in AT&T have investments in all four of these distinct companies?

ARMSTRONG: Yes, they will. And -- or they can mix and match investment according to their investment interests. Today, they get an enterprise value which is based on EPS. If they'd like to invest in -- a company like Wireless is growing 37 percent, they'll have that opportunity. But yes, we're going to spin these equities to our shareholders.

BAY: Michael Armstrong, thanks for joining us tonight on what is a very interesting day -- Terry.

KEENAN: Well, still to come on MONEYLINE: On the heels of AT&T's makeover plan, another former Wall Street star plans some major surgery. Can Cendant cures its CUC headache?

Plus, fiber-optic shares may be taking a beating, but how long will this punishment last?

And as America's business leaders meet in Boca Raton, what are they saying about the direction of the economy and who will win the White House? All that and much more ahead when MONEYLINE continues.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Cendant today announced a bold move to save its floundering stock. The company said it's spinning off its membership businesses to shareholders. Cendant acquired those businesses, such as travel and restaurant discount clubs, as part of its painful merger with CUC International. The merger uncovered an accounting disaster at CUC, prompting the resignation of top executives and hammering Cendant's stock price. The company is now getting close to settling a multibillion dollar shareholder lawsuit. Cendant stock today closed at 9 3/4, down 25 cents, it is down 63 percent year-to-date.

KEENAN: In tonight's "Tech Watch": telecoms in trouble. After flying high most of this year, most fiber-optic equipment makers are now well off their highs. JDS Uniphase, SDL and Nortel all down 45 percent or more from their peaks. PMC Sierra and Applied Micro Circuits also well off their best levels.

But our next guest says that we are heading toward the end of this brutal market sell-off. Erik Gustafson of Stein Roe & Farnham, welcome back to MONEYLINE.

And, Erik, let me ask you about what's been going on in this market, because we have had Intel, Microsoft, IBM, now Nortel, all warning of sluggish sales, and different portfolio managers that we've had on, including you, time after time say this is the end, and then we get more. What's not to say that we're in a protracted slowdown in tech spending?

ERIK GUSTAFSON, STEIN ROE & FARNHAM: Well, Terry, what we've seen in technology is that one by one, they've gone out and taken and shot each major group. They started with the Internet companies, they went to the semiconductors, they went to the wireless. Today, they tagged the optical companies, via Nortel's announcement last night. So I think what you're seeing is in part a slowdown out there in certain areas of technology.

Look, the Fed was very aggressive, in my eyes, really an overhanded aggressiveness in raising rates and we're seeing some slowdown in some sectors of the economy. We had a Fed governor today, Mr. McTeer, talk about what's a potential weaker GDP number on Friday. So that spending is translating a little bit into technology. But is the game over? Absolutely not. We've been through this before and this shall pass, and technology companies will come back.

KEENAN: You're fortunate to own a handful of stocks that haven't been shot yet and that's kept your portfolio above water this year, including EMC and GE, both trading, though, at extremely high multiples, GE at 45 times earnings. Don't those stocks have to come down to more rational market valuations before this is all over?

GUSTAFSON: Well, Terry, I certainly hope not. We have been fortunate. Our portfolios have performed well in a very tough market, even with owning technology companies. General Electric, I think, is one of the great businesses in the world. I think their earnings are intact and I think they'll continue to grow at 17, maybe even 18 percent a year going forward.

EMC is in the storage business, and storage is one of the few remaining soldiers on the battlefield that hasn't been taken apart, and sure, we're weary, we're worried, we watch it every day. But EMC, run by Mike Ruettgers, has done a great job, so we're sticking there and I think we'll make it through.

KEENAN: What about some of the consumer non-durables, those things we all buy that don't last for too long? Some of the stocks in that group, such as Colgate and Estee Lauder, have been on a real tear in the last couple of weeks. Do you like some of those names?

GUSTAFSON: Interesting point. Clearly, as we've seen technology wobble in places, we've seen investors flee those groups and place capital in more stable groups, if you will. Consumer non-durables, soaps, toothpastes, foods, things like that have been very, very strong performers, as investors have sought defensive areas and have sought shelter. We haven't been aggressive buyers there -- we own a company called Safeway, a large grocery retailer -- we haven't been so aggressive there because they don't have the earnings growth that we do.

KEENAN: OK.

GUSTAFSON: I think as we get through October, we're going to do a lot better here in technology, and that's where I'd be placing capital.

KEENAN: OK, fortunately, only about five or six days left. Thanks, Erik.

GUSTAFSON: OK, thanks, Terry.

KEENAN: Erik Gustafson -- Willow.

BAY: Terry, still to come, U.S. President Bill Clinton takes another try at diplomacy in the Middle East, as the fighting in the streets continues. The story in the MONEYLINE "News Digest," after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: A stinging reply today from the George W. Bush campaign to an attack by Treasury Secretary Larry Summers on the candidate's Social Security plan. John Cogan, a Bush economic adviser and senior fellow at the Hoover Institution, says the statements by Summers are, in Cogan's words, "false and inappropriate." He was responding to an interview which appeared today in the "Washington Post." Summers said that Bush's comments on Social Security "reveal a fundamental misunderstanding of the system." And he insists that money collected now cannot both pay current benefits and be moved into investment accounts." According to Summers, that "is an arithmetic challenge that cannot be met."

For other news outside the world of business, let's check in with Wolf Blitzer from Washington for the "MONEYLINE News Digest" -- Wolf.

WOLF BLITZER, CNN ANCHOR: Thank you, Willow. President Bill Clinton said today he has invited Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat to Washington for a new round of talks aimed at halting the violence. Mr. Clinton said he has proposed meeting separately with the two sides and says he was waiting for their responses.

The fighting meanwhile continued today even as Mr. Clinton urged Barak and Arafat to abide by their agreement from last week's summit at Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt to curb the violence.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAM J. CLINTON, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: A big part of what the parties recognized at Sharm el-Sheikh was that it's impossible to maintain this uneasy status quo where we've come so far in the peace process, but the big and most difficult issues remain. We can't expect there to be a reliable peace process unless we can reduce the violence.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BLITZER: The State Department today warned U.S. citizens to defer all travel to Israel, the West Bank and Gaza. The warning cited a -- quote -- "heightened threat of terrorist incidents."

With 12 days to go before the U.S. presidential election, the candidates both sought help on the campaign trail today. Vice President Al Gore had his Democratic running mate, Joe Lieberman, at his side during an education event in Gore's home state of Tennessee, while George W. Bush was in Florida campaigning with Senator John McCain. Bush's theme today was Social Security reform.

And those are some of the top stories. Join us for more on "THE WORLD TODAY." That's at 8:00 p.m. Eastern, 5:00 p.m. Pacific.

Back to you, Willow.

BAY: Wolf, there was a major development today in the USS Cole story. What can you tell us?

BLITZER: More information that the attack on the Cole may not necessarily have been isolated, that perhaps other terrorist threats were out there. Also one mid-level Defense Department intelligence official we now know has resigned. He says he gave warnings about a possible attack similar to the Cole in the days leading up to that attack, but his superiors apparently ignored those warnings, and as a result, he thought it was a good time to quit -- Willow.

BAY: Wolf, thanks. We'll see you at 8:00 -- Terry.

KEENAN: Well, still ahead on MONEYLINE, with Firestone under attack, is another tire industry giant in trouble over safety?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In tonight's profile, the CEO facing the biggest challenge of his career, AT&T's Michael Armstrong. The 62-year-old Harley Davidson-riding executive spent the first three decades of his career at IBM. In 1993, he ran DirecTV at Hughes Electronics. In '97, he was named to the top post at AT&T and was celebrated as a visionary who could transform the long-distance company. Key to that strategy, Armstrong paid more than $100 billion to buy two cable companies.

AT&T's total market cap today, $87.8 billion.

MONEYLINE will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

KEENAN: The tire safety dispute looming larger as another manufacturer comes under scrutiny: 15 deaths have now been linked to light truck tires made by Goodyear. The problem is allegedly tread separation, similar to the trouble attributed to some Firestone models. Goodyear has not recalled the tires and many remain on the road, including the popular Wrangler AT and HT.

Kelli Arena has more from Washington.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KELLI ARENA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): This Goodyear plant in Gadsden, Alabama was a focal point of an internal investigation into tread separation problems launched in late 1994. Goodyear was responding to customer damage claims, part of its early warning system.

J.C. WHITLEY, VICE PRESIDENT, GOODYEAR: We have a warranty system. That data comes back into a data collection system, and then we have a group called customer engineering that analyzes all of that data.

ARENA: The company says it's aware of 30 accidents and 15 fatalities involving Load Range E tires: those are tires made for large commercial vehicles. But it says there is not anything wrong with them. Lawyers for victims involved in those accidents disagree.

CHRYSTINE SPAGNOLI, PLAINTIFFS ATTORNEY: There are red flags all over the place. The fact that these accidents have happened that we've tracked, the fact that there are documents that Goodyear doesn't want public, there is a problem.

ARENA: Goodyear admits it changed the design of those tires in 1996 by adding what's known as a nylon cap. Court documents suggest complaints fell after the change was made. But Goodyear did not recall tires with the old design and accidents involving those tires continue.

SPAGNOLI: What we're seeing is large vans, large sport utility vehicles, and particularly vans that are carrying school kids, vans that are carrying Air Force and military personnel, sport utility vehicles.

ARENA: Federal safety regulators say they've received 59 complaints about those Goodyear tires. The models include Wrangler AT and HT, the all season, and Kelly-Springfield's Power King and Trailbuster.

Safety advocates say Goodyear's problems, much like Firestone's, indicate a much broader safety risk.

RALPH HOAR, DIRECTOR, SAFETYFORUM.COM: What tire manufacturers and vehicle manufacturers have done is to trade off safety for an improved ride and an improved fuel efficiency.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ARENA: In this age of what Goodyear referred to as a heightened awareness of tires, the company says there are people who might benefit from bringing certain information to the public and it insists there is just absolutely nothing wrong with its tires -- Terry.

KEENAN: OK, thank you very much, Kelli -- Kelli Arena.

Well, it has been a rough year for Goodyear stock. In the past 52 weeks, the stock is down 63 percent and it is no longer a Dow component.

MONEYLINE will return in just a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: MONEYLINE continues. In Los Angeles, Willow Bay; and, sitting in for Stuart Varney in New York, Terry Keenan.

KEENAN: Tonight on MONEYLINE, tech tremors rattle Wall Street, sending the Nasdaq sinking 5 percent.

Setting off the jitters, Nortel, the Canadian fiber-optics powerhouse takes a huge hit after posting disappointing sales. Another factor in the telecom turmoil: AT&T as it warns of weaker profits and unveils a landmark move to split up the company.

BAY: But first, more on tonight's top story. A Wednesday wipeout on Wall Street, with the Nasdaq slumping more than 5 percent after investors sound the alarm over a sales shortfall at Nortel Networks. Worries over the future of tech profits hit the Nasdaq hard, sending the index down more than 200 points lower, before closing down 190 points at 3,229.

The Dow also lost ground in a choppy session, breaking a four-day winning streak, ending off more than 66 at 10,326. In the broader market, the S&P 500 sank more than 33. As you might expect, the biggest movers were on the fiber-optics side: Nortel dropped nearly 18 1/2 or 29 percent; Corning sank more than 16 1/2; JDS Uniphase lost over 24; and SDL, which is being acquired by JDS, plummeted nearly 82; Ciena gave back 27; Applied Micro Circuits, a chip supplier for Nortel, was off more than 50; PMC-Sierra down 37 3/4; and Cisco Systems off 4 1/4.

But the main focus of attention was Nortel, one of telecom's highest fliers. It crashed to earth today after missing revenue forecasts last night, a result that swamped markets on both sides of the U.S.-Canadian border.

Greg Clarkin has been following what went wrong.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): By midday the sell orders for Nortel threatened to overwhelm the Toronto Stock Exchange. The TSE halted trading Nortel just before noon, but the damage was done.

Nortel was down 25 percent. It would lose 29 percent in New York trading. The carnage due to one line in Nortel's earnings release: revenue $7.3 billion below Wall Street's expectations. JOHN ROTH, PRESIDENT & CEO, NORTEL: I think the Street, maybe, had dreams of a much bigger fiber-optic market than reality. You know, we have increased our fiber-optics shipments this quarter by 90 percent on a very, very big number. We're now shipping product at the rate of about $10 billion annualized.

CLARKIN: But analysts say they had unofficially been led to believe Nortel would ring up 12, even $13 billion in fiber-optics sales this year, a figure many used to build revenue models for the next several years.

The revenue shortfall sparked fears the spectacular growth in fiber may have been unsustainable. Nortel said the drop off was from customers over-ordering in the first half, expecting shortages in the second half.

Analysts say they should have been warned.

ARIANE MAHLER, DRESDNER KLEINWORT BENSON: If they had better systems to tell them where growth is coming from, if it's inventory build-up or if it's fundamental demand going up, and then to communicate that to the street instead of telling us that it's just going to be great demand and they're getting the whole market to themselves -- I think they'll find a little bit less damage on days like today.

CLARKIN: The news from Nortel dragged down anything fiber-optic- related. The AMEX Networking Index plunged almost 12 percent.

The selling was called an overreaction by some.

ALEX HENDERSON, SALOMONSMITH BARNEY: The problems at Nortel have very little to do with the end-market demand for optic systems. In fact, it's strictly an inventory draw down from what I can tell.

So shooting these other stocks makes little sense in that context.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CLARKIN: But the momentum players did exit fiber stocks today in a big way; and until Nortel proves this revenue drop was a one-time event, no one expects them to return any time soon -- Willow.

BAY: Greg, thanks.

Today's plunge in Nortel comes after a forgettable fall. The stock peaked over the summer and is off 45 percent over the past three months. A similar story for JDS Uniphase, another Canada-based fiber- optics pioneer. But Ciena had been holding up better, but now it appears to be caught in the downdraft as well -- Terry.

KEENAN: And a dramatic day for one of the most storied names in corporate America, AT&T telephone edged ahead of third quarter earnings estimates, but warned that fourth quarter numbers would fall short of forecasts. And the company released its long-awaited plans to break itself up into four separate units, adding that the combined dividend would be, quote, "substantially less" than the current dividend.

The reaction to the news was fast and furious. Janney Montgomery Scott issuing a rare sell recommendation on the stock; and SalomonSmith Barney's influential telecom analyst Jack Grubman, among others, downgrading AT&T, grubman saying that, quote, "business is melting down."

Well, little relief on the bond side, as Moody's said it may cut the debt rating on AT&T -- the stock sliding 3 1/2. It has lost nearly half of its value, or $70 billion over the last year.

AT&T's decision today to try to split the company into four parts is not the first time AT&T has tried to reinvent itself.

Peter Viles has been reviewing the past and checking out whether history is repeating itself -- Pete.

PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Terry, you're right, this is AT&T's third breakup in just 16 years, another uncertain chapter for a company that, essentially, gave birth to the telephone and to the communications business as we know it.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

VILES (voice-over): 1876, Alexander Graham Bell patents the telephone and sets out to profit from it by forming Bell Telephone, the eventual parent of AT&T. By 1913 AT&T has built a transcontinental network, but the nation's phone system is in chaos. Thousands of small phone companies and no central connecting network. The Wilson administration effectively lets AT&T run the entire system.

STEPHANIE MEHTA, "FORTUNE" MAGAZINE: AT&T, in 1913, convinced the government that phone service was a natural monopoly and that it should be allowed to operate as a natural monopoly with the government's permission.

VILES: 1974, the Justice Department opens a heavyweight battle for the ages: Washington against a popular American icon, Ma Bell, the company that brought phone service to tens of millions.

ELI NOAM, COLUMBIA BUSINESS SCHOOL: It was dependable, it was reliable, it was affordable and it was good; and so why fix it if it ain't broke.

VILES: 1984, Washington wins. The Bell system is dead in the first AT&T break up. AT&T gives up the seven baby Bells, 2/3 of its assets and 2/3 of its employees. 1991, AT&T makes a bold bet on the computer business, paying $7 billion for NCR.

September, 1995, another restructuring.

BOB ALLEN, FORMER AT&T CHAIRMAN: Today we are announcing that AT&T is reinventing itself once again.

VILES: AT&T splits into three companies: a computer company, NCR; an equipment company; and a communications company.

1996, a bright spot: The equipment company, Lucent Technologies takes off in one of the biggest and hottest IPOs ever. 1998, another new strategy.

C. Michael Armstrong makes a huge bet on cable, buying TCI and then Media One.

MEHTA: AT&T had to find a way to get to the home. They had 60 million long-distance customers, none of whom they could touch directly, and the cable strategy was perceived as a way to get directly into the homes of their customers.

VILES: The cable strategy also makes cable kingpin John Malone into AT&T's most influential shareholder. AT&T stock struggles and investors, Malone among them, quickly grow impatient, pushing Armstrong into yet another attempt to reinvented AT&T.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

VILES: The executives have changed, but the central challenge at AT&T really hasn't changed in the past 16 years. At this company's core is a business -- long-distance phone service -- in which prices, margins and profits are on the decline -- Terry.

KEENAN: OK, that's for sure; thank you Pete.

Well, AT&T put a brave face on today's dramatic shift in strategy, but will that fly with long-suffering investors? Our next guest holds AT&T in his clients' accounts and he has some very strong opinions on how the company has handled the move.

I'm joined now by Todd Eberhard, he runs his own investment firm.

Todd, welcome.

TODD EBERHARD, EBERHARD INVESTMENT ADVISORS: Thank you.

KEENAN: Let me ask you the question that's on a lot of people's minds: Mike Armstrong has leveraged up this company, he's broken up this company, he's going to try to break it up again -- so far, disastrous results.

Is his time up at AT&T?

EBERHARD: Well, let's start taking a step back by saying what I saw today on air on FN, which is Michael Armstrong saying he was appalled that people would question his strategy, that it's not working.

And I've got to say I'm appalled, and my clients are appalled and I think most of Wall Street is by the fact that this stock came down from a $61, roughly, share-price, down to a $23 and change. And I think it's time to stop pointing fingers and defending a strategy and start to come up with a new plan.

KEENAN: Is the problem the push into cable?

EBERHARD: I think that's part of the problem, but I think it's also a -- it's reinventing yourself every two or three years and not sticking to a plan or moving forward in one direction.

They're sort of -- it's seen now as AT&T is spreading out into so many different places, doing so many different things, and not doing any of them well.

KEENAN: Let's move onto the market, because a lot of questions about this 5 1/2 percent sell-off in the Nasdaq. We had Nortel light on the revenues yesterday, but it's still…

EBERHARD: Light -- light on the revenues at 90 percent numbers. I don't know where the analysts got these 130 or 150 percent numbers they were expecting. 90 percent revenue growth is incredible, and I would love to be able to talk to my people and say we went up 90 percent.

I think that Wall Street was just overreacting, as Erik, who was on earlier, said. It's an overreaction here. They sold -- throughout the bath water and just sold across the board. And I think it is an overreaction and we'll see a counterbalance.

KEENAN: I know you were buying some Nortel today.

EBERHARD: Right.

KEENAN: Tomorrow, we get JDS Uniphase numbers. Do you expect to see continued selling tomorrow?

EBERHARD: We don't. I mean, we think that -- and look at JDS-U today. It got taken down dramatically as well, but in anticipation -- and I think their numbers are going to come in stronger than expected. I think it's got some strength and it could turn that whole market right around very quickly, as we've seen it happen in the past.

KEENAN: OK. Thanks, Todd, as always.

EBERHARD: My pleasure.

KEENAN: Todd Eberhard -- Willow.

BAY: Terry, up next, we go live to Boca Raton, Florida, where some of the nation's top business leaders are meeting. We'll tell you what they're saying about the state of the economy.

Plus, Sony's PlayStation 2 hits stores tomorrow. We'll tell you what that means for one California company, when MONEYLINE returns in just a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In New York trading today, the euro slid to a fresh record low against the dollar, that on continued speculation central bankers will not step in again to prop up the beleaguered currency. The euro today finished just under 83 cents and is down 17 1/2 percent this year.

KEENAN: Well, the euro's decline seemed to grab more attention in the bond pits than today's economic news. Sales of previously owned homes declined 2.7 percent last month to an annual rate of 5.1 million new units. That was right in-line with economists' forecasts. But bond investors largely ignoring that report and cashed in on some recent run-ups in Treasuries.

The 10-year note fell nearly a half point while the 30-year bond lost more than a half point in price, the yield there moving up to 5.74 percent.

BAY: Executives at some of the nation's top companies today predicted the recent economic slowdown will last well into next year. The Business Council is meeting in Boca Raton, Florida this week and released the results of its survey.

CNN's David Haffenreffer is standing by live with all the details -- David.

DAVID HAFFENREFFER, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Willow, sure. High energy prices, a weak euro and slowing economic growth appear to be the buzz already here in Boca Raton as this year's Business Council meeting gets under way: 100 chairman and CEOs from some of the world's biggest publicly traded companies are gathering here for two days and their outlook for next year is cautious.

A council survey presented by -- this evening by Citigroup chairman Sandy Weill found an overwhelming majority believe U.S. economic growth next year will be lower than this year. Two-thirds of the council believes global economic growth will slow next year as well. And one factor certainly that we've seen eating into corporate bottom lines this season is the weak euro, and about 44 percent of the members expect that currency to weaken even further in the months to come.

Sandy Weill says the slowdown comes thanks to Federal Reserve rate hikes and soaring oil prices.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDY WEILL, CHAIRMAN & CEO, CITIGROUP: We're all seeing the effect in different places, from higher energy prices and the effect that that's having on some service industries, you know, like airlines. And you know, a lot of how long that may go on may be dependent on some political things and not just the economy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HAFFENREFFER: And on the political front, it looks pretty close at this point among the council members: 49 percent believe Al Gore will be the next White House resident and 43 percent believe George Bush will win. But a clear majority believe that the Republicans will maintain control of Congress.

On the agenda for tomorrow, a number of panel discussions on the agenda, including one on global population and demographic trends, and also how technology advances will affect our quality of life -- Willow.

BAY: David, so, that's what they said in the survey and that's what they're doing on the formal agenda. But did you get any sense of what they're chattering about in their downtime?

HAFFENREFFER: As part of the press conference earlier today, which was pretty loose, it seemed as though the week euro certainly was a major topic of discussion, and some jokes, of course, on the political front as well, talking about how, no matter who wins perhaps, we will miss Bill Clinton, at least on the economic front once he departs office.

BAY: David Haffenreffer, thanks.

Could investors score on the launch of Sony's much-anticipated PlayStation 2? We'll look at one game maker looking to cash in, when MONEYLINE returns.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

KEENAN: Wall Street watched for several big names out with their quarterly results today. DuPont managed to meet lowered third-quarter forecasts, earning 51 cents a share. But the Dow component cut its full-year estimates, citing higher raw material costs and the weak euro. Revenues for the quarter were flat from a year ago.

Consumer products maker Clorox cleaned house with its third- quarter numbers. It beat Wall Street estimates, earning 42 cents, or $100 million. And Viacom also reporting better-than-expected results. The media giant, which just recently completed its acquisition of CBS, saw revenue rise 7 percent to $6 billion.

Checking those stocks, DuPont lost a half, Clorox gained more than two, Viacom down 2 1/4 -- Willow.

BAY: Terry, in what's being called the biggest consumer electronic product launch in history, Sony releases the successor to its top-selling PlayStation videogame console. PlayStation 2 is officially hitting store shelves tomorrow with a few select outlets selling the console at midnight tonight.

But before videogame players get their hands on the new unit, investors are already betting on the success of at least one smaller player, videogame-maker Activision.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BAY (voice-over): The anticipated launch of Sony's PlayStation 2 has given another company, the game-maker Activision, a bit of a lift. Its stock has more than doubled in the past 4 months and some on Wall Street predict the stock has further to go. The company hit a pitfall this spring with a dramatic earnings warning and weak industry demand. The stock slump was stunning, more than 66 percent.

But today, Activision is in better shape after a significant reorganization and a new focus on its key brands.

The company reported $144 million in sales last quarter, capturing 9 percent of the U.S. market, up from 2 1/2 percent in September 1999, making it the second-biggest independent game-maker behind electronic arts.

Activision employs 120 people to do nothing other than test its games all day. It's here in the testing center where they fine tune their hit Tony Hawk Pro-Skater.

(on camera): You fairly recently decided to focus on extreme sports. Why? Why not Major League Baseball?

ROBERT KOTICK, CEO, ACTIVISION: We found the extreme sports business was really sort of, you know, virgin territory from a publishing standpoint. It touches the court of popular culture to our consumer more than the mainstream sports do.

BAY (voice-over): And now Activision may really have a "Need for Speed." In addition to Sony, both Microsoft and Nintendo are launching new consoles in 2001. And Kotick says the game-makers will spend about a billion dollars in advertising.

(on camera): Sony PlayStation 2 is shipping only about half of what it expected to ship. Does that hold back your growth?

KOTICK: It doesn't.

BAY: Why not?

KOTICK: Typically what happens is it takes a few years for these new platforms to actually achieve any kind of meaningful installed base. This year, I would say maybe 3 percent of our revenues will come from PlayStation 2.

BAY: Why is the buzz about PlayStation 2 then giving your stock such a boost?

KOTICK: I don't think it's actually given our stock a boost, to be honest with you. I think our financial results, the way we're maximizing sort of the where we are in the transition has really been what people are responding to.

I think what people are enthusiastic about prospectively is that they're saying that they're going to sell a hundred million PlayStation 2s.

BAY: So what would that mean for you if that's true?

KOTICK: That would mean probably at a minimum we would double our revenues in five years.

BAY (voice-over): Despite Kotick's forward-thinking and Activision's recent rebound, analysts caution that at their heart videogames are trendy and trend-picking is never easy.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: Kotick's also looking for growth beyond traditional game consoles. He has a wireless deal with Nokia, which he calls "experimental." It will be five years or so before he expects to see any real revenue from that deal.

Now, analysts expect industry sales to grow around 20 to 25 percent over the next few years as these new game stations roll out. Kotick says he expects Activision's revenues to grow more than 30 percent over the same time period -- Terry.

KEENAN: Not bad. OK, still ahead on MONEYLINE, a merger that could change the way you look at the Dow Jones industrial average. We'll hear from Myron Kandel about that after this break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

KEENAN: GE's takeover of Honeywell will mean a vacancy on the Dow Jones industrial average, and it may trigger some other changes.

Myron Kandel joins us with his thoughts on that -- Myron.

MYRON KANDEL, CNNFN FINANCIAL EDITOR: Well, Terry, the folks at "The Wall Street Journal" take changing the Dow industrial average very seriously, so they really keep it close to the vest. But as a result of the planned takeover of Honeywell, there will be a vacancy. There are a number of companies that have been mentioned as possible replacements, including Cisco Systems, Tyco, Pfizer even AOL-Time Warner once the takeover of our company is completed.

KEENAN: But you think that this merger of Honeywell and GE might trigger some other changes at the Dow Jones?

KANDEL: Well, that's right. The last two times "The Wall Street Journal" has changed the Dow they've done four -- they added four companies and they dropped four the last two times. So this time they may do more than that one -- fill more than that one vacancy. And I have no idea where they're going to go, but I have some speculation. And one of them is dropping AT&T.

KEENAN: Especially if it's divided into four companies.

KANDEL: Exactly.

KEENAN: OK. We will have to see. Thanks, Myron.

Up next, "Ahead of the Curve": Willow and I will be back with some of the news that you need to know tonight before tomorrow's markets open. You're watching MONEYLINE.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Here's a look at a few things that may move the markets tomorrow. Expect big earnings from big tech names like JDS Uniphase, WorldCom, Inktomi and Nextel Communications. Also tomorrow, DaimlerChrysler and AIG. And watch for jobless claims for the week ending October 21st.

KEENAN: And also a quick programming note, tomorrow night we'll be joined by two of the biggest names in telecoms: John Chambers of Cisco Systems and Jozef Straus of JDS Uniphase.

BAY: That's MONEYLINE for this Wednesday. I'm Willow Bay in Los Angeles.

KEENAN: And I'm Terry Keenan in New York. Good night. "CROSSFIRE" is next.

urn:contentItem:5TSF-RJ41-JBSS-S0V7-00000-00Dow falls 500 points, dragged down by Facebook, Apple2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:11ZLexisNexisDow falls 500 points, dragged down by Facebook, Apple

Updated 2:05 p.m. ET with stock data. Dow down 500 points

By Paul R. La Monica, CNN BusinessNEW YORK (CNN Business)

NEW YORK (CNN Business) -- Stocks fell sharply Monday, dragged down by reports of trouble at Apple and Facebook.

The Dow fell more than 500 points and the Nasdaq tumbled 2.8%.

Facebook stock fell more than 5% as the company continues to deal with the fallout from a New York Times article that detailed Facebook's reaction to political scrutiny and its Cambridge Analytica scandal. CEO Mark Zuckerberg has reportedly adopted a more aggressive, "war"-like style, according to the Wall Street Journal.

Alphabet was also down 3.5%. It is now down nearly 20% from its peak in July.

Early in the day, stocks fell on news that Apple's newest line of phones may not be selling as well as Apple or its investors had hoped.

Apple's stock fell once more after the Wall Street Journal reported that Apple has cut orders for its iPhone XR, iPhone XS and iPhone XS Max.

The new iPhones, which Apple unveiled in September, cost more than previous versions. The $749 iPhone XR is the least expensive new iPhone, but it costs $50 more than last year's cheapest model, the iPhone 8.

The iPhone XS Max can cost up to $1,449. The higher prices -- without many more features -- could be driving customers to keep their current phones longer or buy last year's models.

Apple declined to comment about the Journal story or broader concerns about iPhone demand.

Shares of Apple fell 4% and have now plunged about 20% from the all-time high it hit a few months ago, when Apple (AAPL) was worth more than $1 trillion.

The stock ended a 5-day losing skid on Friday after an analyst at Morgan Stanley suggested that the supplier concerns are overdone.

Apple, which is a member of the Dow, was hurting the blue chips too.

Several makers of chips and other components used in iPhones have warned of soft sales and profit in recent weeks, citing sluggish demand for higher-end smartphones.

To that end, shares of Apple suppliers, such as Qorvo (QRVO), Broadcom (AVGO), Cirrus Logic (CRUS) and even Apple's key Anrdoid phone rival Samsung were all lower Monday too. Samsung also makes chips for iPhones.

Investors have other reasons to be concerned about the future of Apple -- as well as other big tech companies for that matter.

Apple CEO Tim Cook said on the "Axios on HBO" show Sunday that he expects Washington to crack down on tech firms in the wake of high-profile privacy scandals, such as the Cambridge Analytica problems that have plagued Facebook (FB).

"I am not a big fan of regulation," Cook said to Axios on HBO. "I'm a big believer in the free market. But we have to admit when the free market is not working. And it hasn't worked here. I think it's inevitable that there will be some level of regulation."

HBO, like CNN, is part of WarnerMedia, which is owned by AT&T (T).

Updated at 4:10 pm with market close numbers Updated 2:57 pm with analyst comments- Updated 2:40 pm with broader market details.

By Paul R. La Monica, CNN BusinessNEW YORK (CNN Business)

NEW YORK (CNN Business) -- Are Apple's glory days behind it? That's probably a stretch. But Wall Street clearly is getting more worried about the company's reliance on the iPhone to generate sales and profit at a time when demand for the newer phones appears to be subpar.

Shares of Apple (AAPL) fell 3% Wednesday and that was one of the big reasons why the Dow, which includes Apple, lost more than 200 points. Apple's stock even dipped into bear market territory, meaning it was down 20% from its all-time high.

It was the fourth straight drop for the Dow, which actually opened the day with a more than 100-point gain after the US government reported that the latest figures for consumer prices were in line with expectations -- a sign that inflation remains mostly in check.

The other big tech stocks in the Dow -- Microsoft (MSFT), IBM (IBM), Intel (INTC) and Cisco (CSCO) -- were all lower too.

The Dow briefly bounced off its lows after UK Prime Minister Theresa May announced that her cabinet had agreed to a Brexit deal.

But the broader market was also hurt by a slide in bank stocks after Democrat Rep. Maxine Waters, who is expected to take over the House Financial Services Committee in January, said in a House hearing Wednesday that the days of more lax regulations for banks "will come to an end."

Still, all eyes were mostly on Apple, which fell for a fifth consecutive day.

The reason for Apple's latest slide? Several companies that produce chips and other components used in iPhones have all issued gloomy forecasts recently, citing sluggish demand for higher-end smartphones.

Although none of these companies, which include Qorvo (QRVO), Lumentum (LITE), Japan Display and IQE, have named Apple as the source of their woes, they are all Apple suppliers.

But it may not be time to throw in the towel on Apple just yet, even though some analysts are cutting their price targets and earnings estimates due to concerns about soft sales for the newer iPhone XR, iPhone XS and iPhone XS Max.

Apple's stock is still up more than 10% this year, making it one of the better performers in the Dow. The company is still worth nearly $900 billion. It remains the most valuable company in the world.

Apple also continues to pay a solid dividend that yields 1.5% -- and the company is likely to keep raising its dividend thanks to its cash stockpile of $237.1 billion.

What's more, Apple's earnings are expected to increase by more than 13% this fiscal year and keep growing at about a 12% clip annually, on average, for the next few years.

So predictions of an Apple iPocalypse, if you will, may be premature. There are other legitimate worries for Apple though.

UBS analyst Tim Arcuri cut his price target on Apple Wednesday. He wrote in a report that the stronger dollar could be hurting iPhone sales in China since currency fluctuations make the already expensive iPhones even pricier in China.

And it does seem like the company needs a new product to get consumers and investors excited again.

Perhaps Apple needs to take a cue from the movie "This Is Spinal Tap" and release a new iPhone that goes to eleven. But would it be the iPhone 11 or iPhone XI?

urn:contentItem:5TKC-6CX1-DY0W-41D4-00000-00Dow Futures Point to Rebound after Dow's 600-Point Slide Yesterday; Tesla Posts Record Profit; Trump on the Campaign Trail; Update on Saudi Journalist; President Trump to Outline Plan to Lower Health Care Costs; Caravan Heading to Border; NYPD Transporting Suspicious Package Found In Lower Manhattan; CIA Hears Khashoggi Tape; Planters' New Nutty Beer; Twitter Earnings Imminent2018-10-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisDow Futures Point to Rebound after Dow's 600-Point Slide Yesterday; Tesla Posts Record Profit; Trump on the Campaign Trail; Update on Saudi Journalist; President Trump to Outline Plan to Lower Health Care Costs; Caravan Heading to Border; NYPD Transporting Suspicious Package Found In Lower Manhattan; CIA Hears Khashoggi Tape; Planters' New Nutty Beer; Twitter Earnings ImminentLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: in fact, today, for the S&P 500, is one of the busiest days of earning season, 80 of the 500 companies in the S&P report earnings today.

And, Elon Musk, quieting his critics, Tesla, reporting a record quarterly profit, and results beating expectations. That's right, Tesla profit. The stock, soaring, it's up double digits in premarket trading.

Searching for a sender, a manhunt, underway for a person, who sent explosive devices to prominent Democrats and CNN, plus authorities trying to track down a package sent to Former Vice President Joe Biden. We have the latest on that.

And a look at the economy, in America, from one of the biggest names in technology, Oracle founder, Larry Ellison, sitting down with Maria Bartiromo, in an exclusive interview, he weighs in on the political environment to the health of the economy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY ELLISON, CO-FOUNDER & EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, ORACLE: I think the economy is doing great, so again, I was Bill Clinton's second largest contributor when he ran for office. You know, I'm neither a Democrat nor a Republican, I tend to be in the middle, which means very lonely. There's (INAUDIBLE) polarized.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: More of Maria's exclusive must-see interview with Larry Ellison, one of the great innovators from this country. You have to hear what he has to say.

All of that and so much more, coming up this morning, the Federalist Commentary Writer, Emily Jashinsky, Rosecliff CEO and Managing Partner, Mike Murphy and the Brewer Group CEO, Former NFL Star, Jack Brewer. Welcome one and all. Let's get right to it.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF: Good morning, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Because I have a lot much I want to talk about with Murphy, over here. To our top story, a potential market rebound this morning, after the Dow and S&P fell into negative territory for the year, yesterday.

This is Twitter. It is set to release its quarterly earnings later this morning, other tech giants on deck, for today, include Amazon and Google's parent company, Alphabet. They report their earnings after the market closed today. Mike, what do you make of these earnings, what does the market need to see to firm up here?

MURPHY: Well, clearly, companies are getting cheaper than they were, a month ago. We hit new highs last month. Now, we have this major drawdown 10 percent, in the markets. Earnings are what I'm looking at.

You see what Microsoft put out yesterday. Those numbers were very good, I won't say outstanding, but enough to not cause a major selloff in the stock, get sold down to $98.00, right after the earnings were announced.

But now, if you see this morning, it's firmed up in the low 100s, that's enough for me to say I want to buy Microsoft on a pullback, and look for the same from Amazon, same from Google. If the growth story is still intact, this is a buying opportunity.

MCDOWELL: If the growth story is still intact. So, it was -- what triggered the selloff to start the month of October. It was to say -- is really a replay in some ways of what we saw earlier this year.

MURPHY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It was worries about inflation, higher wages and rising interest rates. But that hasn't been the story lately, because you saw -- money has been going into treasuries, money went a little bit of money went into treasuries yesterday, the 10-year -- the yield was down slightly.

So what is it, is it worries about global growth and corporate profits? We have been talking about the revenue story, and I was looking at the revenue miss number, so, so far, through the quarter, we have 38 percent of companies that have missed revenue expectations, which is the biggest percentage this year.

MURPHY: There's been a story going on and a lot of people focusing on peak earnings, this is good as it gets. Is it going to get worse from here? So, a lot of people, I think, taking some money off the table after these big run-ups we've seen.

I don't see that. I see solid earnings and it's really the companies that have been -- I'm not focusing on a company like Ford that announced yesterday, I'm focusing on the companies where we've seen the growth. So that's the big tech, that's Microsoft, that's Google, that's Amazon, later today.

MCDOWELL: Well, let me mention Microsoft and Tesla, we -- people, investors love to hate Tesla, so Microsoft, Mike was talking about this, beat revenue and profit estimates based on its cloud-computing growth and Tesla defied Wall Street expectations, posting a record profit.

Just your thoughts on Tesla because they moved up their earnings announcement, so I personally assume that they were going to report a quarterly profit, that they had something to crow about and indeed, they did.

MURPHY: Yes, interesting because, you know, when the -- when Elon Musk announced that he was moving the earnings up, a lot of, like, the talk there, was that he was doing that to attack the Shorts, that a lot of Shorts had bought weekly puts, made weekly bets against his company for next week, when he was going to announce.

In order to do that, you have to pay up a lot for those put options, because there's an earning's announcement coming in there. So, by moving the earnings to this week, a short-seller would immediately lose 70 to 80 percent of the value when the bets he made against Elon Musk's company.

So, bring it forward and then top it off, you have profitability and great numbers. This, to me, Tesla right here, after this huge rally, isn't something you'd want to jump into. Yesterday was the time to buy Tesla.

MCDOWELL: I'm looking at the results, particularly it is cash, people concerned about the level of debt, it's free cash flow came in much higher than expectations.

MURPHY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It's about $881 million, its total cash on hand, its $3 billion. Its accounts payable did also rise, but in terms of -- and I'm going to get to Jack and Emily, but in terms of its financial position, it looks better here.

MURPHY: Looks better. And remember, they have a big bond payment that they have to -- that's coming up. So, you know, early next year, the cash position is going to get more and more focused on, so this is a great start for Elon Musk, but he's going to have to continue this type of movement.

JACK BREWER, CEO, THE BREWER GROUP: So, in regard to Tesla, because obviously, we see everything that's going on outside with Elon Musk and everyone is just going back and forth, for me personally, I don't think this is going to last very long, but how --

MURPHY: back and forth.

BREWER: I don't think -- I don't think the growth of the company is going to continue to last as long. I'm scared about the first quarter of next year, when those convertible notes come due, I wonder how they are going to be able to react there and will they be able to continue with the earnings growth.

But beyond that, in the broader market, here, as you look, and Dagen, you mentioned 38 percent of the companies have missed earnings.

MCDOWELL: Revenue.

BREWER: Revenue, excuse me. I'm seeing a lot of companies that I didn't expect to hit their earnings growth -- hit their earnings growth. So, what does that mean for our economy, is this going to be something as we go into the first of the year, will we see more and more companies that are expected not to grow, actually hitting their earnings numbers?

MURPHY: I think the economy is doing great right now, it's booming, things are moving in the right direction, so that's where you want to be -- if you want to focus on that, that's something to focus on right now, is the economy.

But, when you're investing, you're talking about individual stocks, individual companies within the economy, so I don't want to focus on ones - - not the old-school ones, where they had a good quarter or they're going to put up two good quarters. I want to focus on the long-term growth stories and that's been for the most part, big tech.

BREWER: But do you rebalance, right now? If you're a normal investor, do you -- what do you do if you're --

MCDOWELL: Because the market just rebalanced.

MURPHY: I had a -- I had a few friends reached out to me last night, saying things like, are we going to be OK? What should we do here? That tells me that the selling's probably getting a little bit overdone. If you have a long term plan, leave it alone. If you are retiring in two years or three years, and this pullback has you, losing sleep, rebalance right now.

MCDOWELL: The President keeps talking about the Federal Reserve chief and the Fed, making a mistake, but every time he does that, I keep thinking about all those responsible people, those savers, who basically gotten screwed by the Federal Reserves of cheap and easy money policy over the last -- more than a decade.

And so, I think about them. I'm like, the people are actually -- don't hate higher rates here, in fact, it makes people feel more confident when they see particularly longer-term interest rates going up. I mean, it sounds, kind of, upside down and backwards.

But I want to get to politics, speaking of the President, because he was on the campaign trail last night, in Wisconsin, hitting a number of issues including the mail bombs targeting high-ranking Democrats and CNN.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The Federal government is conducting an aggressive investigation, and we will find those responsible, and we will bring them to justice, hopefully, very quickly. Any acts or threats of political violence are an attack on our democracy itself.

Early voting is now underway, so get out and vote, the decision in this election is so clear all over the country. Republicans are for lower taxes, less regulations and more economic freedom, and that's a good thing. That's a good thing.

The Democrats are for higher taxes, more regulation and more top-down government control. We don't have borders, we don't have a country, and we have the greatest country on earth, OK?

Republicans know that the rule of law is essential to national sovereignty, and we know that immigration enforcement is essential to public safety, National Security and the protection of American jobs, wages and public benefits.

The unemployment rate just fell to the lowest level in over 50 years, 5-0 years, 50. Manufacturing confidence has reached an all-time high in the history of our country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Emily, your take on the President last night and so much happening whether it's the market selloff to potentially impact the midterm elections, now less than two weeks away, and now, these pipe bombs sent to prominent Democrats?

EMILY JASHINSKY, COMMENTARY WRITER, THE FEDERALIST: Right. Two big stories yesterday, and it's -- I was born and raised in Wisconsin. And he was, last night, really deep in the heart of Trump country. What's interesting is, this is the state where Ted Cruz won the Republican primary, where Donald Trump won by less than one percentage point over Hillary Clinton.

And yet he's -- when he's in Wisconsin -- when he's in rural Wisconsin, these are people who were hit hard by trade policies of years past, paper mills have shattered. They're in a lot -- there are a lot of problems up there.

And so, for him to come to the state, at a time when the Wisconsin Senate candidate, Leah Vukmir, is not expected to win, she's, you know, down in the polls.

You risk -- you risk boosting turnout in Milwaukee and Madison and helping Tammy Baldwin, but at the same time, when you see all of these people, in a state like Wisconsin, flock to this New York billionaire, at a rally, it's a really powerful statement and what he's been able to do in some of these rural communities.

MCDOWELL: Right. And these events, though, we don't -- I can't recall a major market selloff like this, right ahead of midterm elections before, not in recent history.

MURPHY: Midterms maybe, but we did selloff going into the last presidential election, if you remember.
