urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D522-00000-00Dow Futures Point to Rebound after Dow's 600-Point Slide Yesterday; Tesla Posts Record Profit; Trump on the Campaign Trail; Update on Saudi Journalist; President Trump to Outline Plan to Lower Health Care Costs; Caravan Heading to Border; NYPD Transporting Suspicious Package Found In Lower Manhattan; CIA Hears Khashoggi Tape; Planters' New Nutty Beer; Twitter Earnings Imminent2018-10-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisDow Futures Point to Rebound after Dow's 600-Point Slide Yesterday; Tesla Posts Record Profit; Trump on the Campaign Trail; Update on Saudi Journalist; President Trump to Outline Plan to Lower Health Care Costs; Caravan Heading to Border; NYPD Transporting Suspicious Package Found In Lower Manhattan; CIA Hears Khashoggi Tape; Planters' New Nutty Beer; Twitter Earnings ImminentLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: in fact, today, for the S&P 500, is one of the busiest days of earning season, 80 of the 500 companies in the S&P report earnings today.

And, Elon Musk, quieting his critics, Tesla, reporting a record quarterly profit, and results beating expectations. That's right, Tesla profit. The stock, soaring, it's up double digits in premarket trading.

Searching for a sender, a manhunt, underway for a person, who sent explosive devices to prominent Democrats and CNN, plus authorities trying to track down a package sent to Former Vice President Joe Biden. We have the latest on that.

And a look at the economy, in America, from one of the biggest names in technology, Oracle founder, Larry Ellison, sitting down with Maria Bartiromo, in an exclusive interview, he weighs in on the political environment to the health of the economy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY ELLISON, CO-FOUNDER & EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, ORACLE: I think the economy is doing great, so again, I was Bill Clinton's second largest contributor when he ran for office. You know, I'm neither a Democrat nor a Republican, I tend to be in the middle, which means very lonely. There's (INAUDIBLE) polarized.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: More of Maria's exclusive must-see interview with Larry Ellison, one of the great innovators from this country. You have to hear what he has to say.

All of that and so much more, coming up this morning, the Federalist Commentary Writer, Emily Jashinsky, Rosecliff CEO and Managing Partner, Mike Murphy and the Brewer Group CEO, Former NFL Star, Jack Brewer. Welcome one and all. Let's get right to it.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF: Good morning, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Because I have a lot much I want to talk about with Murphy, over here. To our top story, a potential market rebound this morning, after the Dow and S&P fell into negative territory for the year, yesterday.

This is Twitter. It is set to release its quarterly earnings later this morning, other tech giants on deck, for today, include Amazon and Google's parent company, Alphabet. They report their earnings after the market closed today. Mike, what do you make of these earnings, what does the market need to see to firm up here?

MURPHY: Well, clearly, companies are getting cheaper than they were, a month ago. We hit new highs last month. Now, we have this major drawdown 10 percent, in the markets. Earnings are what I'm looking at.

You see what Microsoft put out yesterday. Those numbers were very good, I won't say outstanding, but enough to not cause a major selloff in the stock, get sold down to $98.00, right after the earnings were announced.

But now, if you see this morning, it's firmed up in the low 100s, that's enough for me to say I want to buy Microsoft on a pullback, and look for the same from Amazon, same from Google. If the growth story is still intact, this is a buying opportunity.

MCDOWELL: If the growth story is still intact. So, it was -- what triggered the selloff to start the month of October. It was to say -- is really a replay in some ways of what we saw earlier this year.

MURPHY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It was worries about inflation, higher wages and rising interest rates. But that hasn't been the story lately, because you saw -- money has been going into treasuries, money went a little bit of money went into treasuries yesterday, the 10-year -- the yield was down slightly.

So what is it, is it worries about global growth and corporate profits? We have been talking about the revenue story, and I was looking at the revenue miss number, so, so far, through the quarter, we have 38 percent of companies that have missed revenue expectations, which is the biggest percentage this year.

MURPHY: There's been a story going on and a lot of people focusing on peak earnings, this is good as it gets. Is it going to get worse from here? So, a lot of people, I think, taking some money off the table after these big run-ups we've seen.

I don't see that. I see solid earnings and it's really the companies that have been -- I'm not focusing on a company like Ford that announced yesterday, I'm focusing on the companies where we've seen the growth. So that's the big tech, that's Microsoft, that's Google, that's Amazon, later today.

MCDOWELL: Well, let me mention Microsoft and Tesla, we -- people, investors love to hate Tesla, so Microsoft, Mike was talking about this, beat revenue and profit estimates based on its cloud-computing growth and Tesla defied Wall Street expectations, posting a record profit.

Just your thoughts on Tesla because they moved up their earnings announcement, so I personally assume that they were going to report a quarterly profit, that they had something to crow about and indeed, they did.

MURPHY: Yes, interesting because, you know, when the -- when Elon Musk announced that he was moving the earnings up, a lot of, like, the talk there, was that he was doing that to attack the Shorts, that a lot of Shorts had bought weekly puts, made weekly bets against his company for next week, when he was going to announce.

In order to do that, you have to pay up a lot for those put options, because there's an earning's announcement coming in there. So, by moving the earnings to this week, a short-seller would immediately lose 70 to 80 percent of the value when the bets he made against Elon Musk's company.

So, bring it forward and then top it off, you have profitability and great numbers. This, to me, Tesla right here, after this huge rally, isn't something you'd want to jump into. Yesterday was the time to buy Tesla.

MCDOWELL: I'm looking at the results, particularly it is cash, people concerned about the level of debt, it's free cash flow came in much higher than expectations.

MURPHY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It's about $881 million, its total cash on hand, its $3 billion. Its accounts payable did also rise, but in terms of -- and I'm going to get to Jack and Emily, but in terms of its financial position, it looks better here.

MURPHY: Looks better. And remember, they have a big bond payment that they have to -- that's coming up. So, you know, early next year, the cash position is going to get more and more focused on, so this is a great start for Elon Musk, but he's going to have to continue this type of movement.

JACK BREWER, CEO, THE BREWER GROUP: So, in regard to Tesla, because obviously, we see everything that's going on outside with Elon Musk and everyone is just going back and forth, for me personally, I don't think this is going to last very long, but how --

MURPHY: back and forth.

BREWER: I don't think -- I don't think the growth of the company is going to continue to last as long. I'm scared about the first quarter of next year, when those convertible notes come due, I wonder how they are going to be able to react there and will they be able to continue with the earnings growth.

But beyond that, in the broader market, here, as you look, and Dagen, you mentioned 38 percent of the companies have missed earnings.

MCDOWELL: Revenue.

BREWER: Revenue, excuse me. I'm seeing a lot of companies that I didn't expect to hit their earnings growth -- hit their earnings growth. So, what does that mean for our economy, is this going to be something as we go into the first of the year, will we see more and more companies that are expected not to grow, actually hitting their earnings numbers?

MURPHY: I think the economy is doing great right now, it's booming, things are moving in the right direction, so that's where you want to be -- if you want to focus on that, that's something to focus on right now, is the economy.

But, when you're investing, you're talking about individual stocks, individual companies within the economy, so I don't want to focus on ones - - not the old-school ones, where they had a good quarter or they're going to put up two good quarters. I want to focus on the long-term growth stories and that's been for the most part, big tech.

BREWER: But do you rebalance, right now? If you're a normal investor, do you -- what do you do if you're --

MCDOWELL: Because the market just rebalanced.

MURPHY: I had a -- I had a few friends reached out to me last night, saying things like, are we going to be OK? What should we do here? That tells me that the selling's probably getting a little bit overdone. If you have a long term plan, leave it alone. If you are retiring in two years or three years, and this pullback has you, losing sleep, rebalance right now.

MCDOWELL: The President keeps talking about the Federal Reserve chief and the Fed, making a mistake, but every time he does that, I keep thinking about all those responsible people, those savers, who basically gotten screwed by the Federal Reserves of cheap and easy money policy over the last -- more than a decade.

And so, I think about them. I'm like, the people are actually -- don't hate higher rates here, in fact, it makes people feel more confident when they see particularly longer-term interest rates going up. I mean, it sounds, kind of, upside down and backwards.

But I want to get to politics, speaking of the President, because he was on the campaign trail last night, in Wisconsin, hitting a number of issues including the mail bombs targeting high-ranking Democrats and CNN.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The Federal government is conducting an aggressive investigation, and we will find those responsible, and we will bring them to justice, hopefully, very quickly. Any acts or threats of political violence are an attack on our democracy itself.

Early voting is now underway, so get out and vote, the decision in this election is so clear all over the country. Republicans are for lower taxes, less regulations and more economic freedom, and that's a good thing. That's a good thing.

The Democrats are for higher taxes, more regulation and more top-down government control. We don't have borders, we don't have a country, and we have the greatest country on earth, OK?

Republicans know that the rule of law is essential to national sovereignty, and we know that immigration enforcement is essential to public safety, National Security and the protection of American jobs, wages and public benefits.

The unemployment rate just fell to the lowest level in over 50 years, 5-0 years, 50. Manufacturing confidence has reached an all-time high in the history of our country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Emily, your take on the President last night and so much happening whether it's the market selloff to potentially impact the midterm elections, now less than two weeks away, and now, these pipe bombs sent to prominent Democrats?

EMILY JASHINSKY, COMMENTARY WRITER, THE FEDERALIST: Right. Two big stories yesterday, and it's -- I was born and raised in Wisconsin. And he was, last night, really deep in the heart of Trump country. What's interesting is, this is the state where Ted Cruz won the Republican primary, where Donald Trump won by less than one percentage point over Hillary Clinton.

And yet he's -- when he's in Wisconsin -- when he's in rural Wisconsin, these are people who were hit hard by trade policies of years past, paper mills have shattered. They're in a lot -- there are a lot of problems up there.

And so, for him to come to the state, at a time when the Wisconsin Senate candidate, Leah Vukmir, is not expected to win, she's, you know, down in the polls.

You risk -- you risk boosting turnout in Milwaukee and Madison and helping Tammy Baldwin, but at the same time, when you see all of these people, in a state like Wisconsin, flock to this New York billionaire, at a rally, it's a really powerful statement and what he's been able to do in some of these rural communities.

MCDOWELL: Right. And these events, though, we don't -- I can't recall a major market selloff like this, right ahead of midterm elections before, not in recent history.

MURPHY: Midterms maybe, but we did selloff going into the last presidential election, if you remember.

MCDOWELL: Right, we saw -- right, because -- and then again, rally, when it became clear that President Trump was going to win, so pro-growth policies, we will discuss as the morning moves on.

A nationwide manhunt, meantime, underway after explosive devices were sent to prominent Democrats and CNN, we have the latest on the investigation, including what was found inside those packages.

Plus, competition with China, stay with us for Maria's exclusive interview with Oracle Founder Larry Ellison. Hear what he says about protecting American tech.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: An intense nationwide manhunt, underway, after pipe bombs were sent to prominent Democrats as well as CNN. Cheryl Casone has the details. Good morning, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, good morning, Dagen. While at least eight packages were sent in total, one of them addressed to former President Barack Obama. The Secret Service says that the package with an explosive device was intercepted before it could make it to his home in Washington, D.C., as well as another that was sent to former President Bill and Hillary Clinton's New York home. Former Attorney General Eric Holder had one addressed to him, and one bearing the name of John Brennan, the former CIA Director who publicly sparred with the President, that package meant for Brennan was delivered to CNN, prompting the network to evacuate their New York offices at Time Warner Center.

Now, officials say the devices made with PVC pipe were packed with shards of glass. The President condemning the attempted attacks.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Any acts or threats of political violence are an attack on our Democracy itself. No nation can succeed that tolerates violence or the threat of violence as a method of political intimidation, coercion, or control.

CASONE: Police also are looking into suspicious packages mailed to Congresswoman Maxine Waters in Washington and in California, and another one that was addressed to former Vice President Joe Biden. Investigators believe this is related to another, sent to George Soros, a billionaire liberal donor who lives in New York. Now, the FBI says this could be the work of one person or a group because all packages are similar, manila envelopes, forever stamps, and the return address of Democratic Congresswoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz. A lot of intense things happening yesterday. Dagen, over to you.

MCDOWELL: Indeed, Cheryl, thank you for that update, and we'll bring you more as it develops as the morning moves on. But Emily, onto this, because this is -- the Wall Street Journal has an editorial today called the politics of pipe bombs, and they say -- one of the -- one of the things that they note, one that took years literally trying to find out who sent those anthrax-laced letters that killed several people after back in 2001. Especially so close to an election, the public should discount unconfirmed leaks about suspects or motives and the political rhetoric that you're hearing about these explosive devices.

JASHINSKY: Yes, I think that's probably true. But, I mean, I think in general, turning down the volume couldn't hurt anyone -- turning down the volume on the anger and the -- you know, whatever the -- whatever the polarized rhetoric couldn't hurt any of us. But I think it's probably wise at this point, unless, you know, there may be some very clear information that emerges, that could be the case, there were a lot of package that were sent.

MCDOWELL: Right. And because the devices were not detonated, that would make it -- it makes the job of the FBI much easier to track down.

JASHINSKY: And it should be fairly easy. I mean, these are in Virginia right now being analyzed. And so, it should be fairly easy for them to determine whether they were viable to begin with, whether these were things that were actually intended to explode or whether these were fakes, that I mean, they should be able to figure that out soon.

MURPHY: Either way from a political standpoint, like, this is a lunatic, whether whatever political party they are part of, or whatever they were trying to accomplish, it's a crazy person that we -- no one wants to be associated with in any way, shape, or form.

MCDOWELL: Right. And no one wants to wish harm or bring harm to anybody in this country.

JASHINSKY: Nobody asked for that.

MCDOWELL: A rational sane person. Exactly. However, I will point out that Democratic leaders, Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi did put out a statement saying Mr. Trump's words bring hollow until he reverses his statements that condone acts of violence. And The Journal editorial writes, "As if this is a moment to settle political scores." So, some people can't avoid making them political.

BREWER: They can't. And I, you know, I flew in last night, and was watching the various networks, and I was just blown away by the fact that every single person took President Trump's speech and made it as if he was the one inciting all of the violence, disregard the fact that we've had Republicans shot on baseball fields in D.C. I mean, come on, guys, this is both sides. People need to take a step back. But whenever you start to point the blame at someone else like your mom and dad always told you, you got to look back at yourself first.

MCDOWELL: And to quote President Obama after the shooting in Tucson, where Gabby -- the one in which Gabby Giffords or Congresswoman Gabby Giffords was injured, he said the lack of civility in politics was not to blame, and he cautioned against a political impulse to quote, lay the blame for all that ails the world at the feet of those who happened to think differently than we do. So, that bears repeating on this day.

Coming up, airline hack, Cathay Pacific reporting more than 9 million customers may have had their data compromised. The latest, next. Plus, reliability tanking, Tesla reporting better-than-expected -- well, better- than-expected numbers for the quarter. It actually reported earnings with a car company among several that has slipped in customer reliability. We'll bring you that story ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A view from the top, Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison sitting down in an exclusive interview with Maria Bartiromo. Take a listen to what he says about a range of issues including his company, Amazon, and competition with China.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ELLISON: The Oracle database manages most of the world's data. Today, 10 years ago, nothing has changed, all of the world's important valuable data is in the Oracle Database, they're not in Amazon's database. Let me tell you an interesting fact, Amazon does not use AWS to run their business, Amazon runs their entire business on top of Oracle, on top of the Oracle database. They have been unable to migrate to AWS because it's not good enough. We have serious competition going on with China. I'm on team USA, I would like us to be successful, I'd like us to develop and protect our technologies, I think we have to do that. I think we have to invest on -- invest on our economy and grow our economy so we can compete with the first serious -- the first serious threat, if you will, our first serious competitor we've had since the 1930s.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Plus, Maria, also, before she sat down with Larry Ellison, she first spoke with Oracle Co-CEO Mark Hurd, and asked him about growth.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: People are worried about growth, the market is selling off this week, it's been a volatile situation, as people question whether or not these good economic times are sustainable. You've got the leading enterprise companies on Oracle software using Oracle applications, you would know best. What are you seeing, are you seeing a pullback?

MARK HURD, CEO, ORACLE: No, I wouldn't say that. I think there's always concerns that the Fed sometimes -- I think I've heard a stat where 36 -- out of 36 quarters in a row, they've overestimated growth. And sometimes interest rates moves -- sort of moved ahead of the growth, and in some ways, as you know, can constrict growth. And so, I think there's some concern about what happens to interest rates. But still today, if you have good projects people are investing, the economy certainly in this country is good, growth in this country is solid, particularly in small and medium business. We talk a lot about global companies, and companies that reach outside of the United States, but if you look inside the United States, companies' primary business is domestic, those companies are doing quite well.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Be sure to stay with us for Maria's exclusive in-depth interview with Oracle Founder Larry Ellison at 7:00 and 8:00, so in both of those hours. This is a man you never hear from, but who did he choose to sit down with, Maria Bartiromo. You can't miss it.

Coming up, more sweeping reform on the way, President Trump ready to reveal his plan to lower healthcare costs, plus more highlights from his Wisconsin rally last night. And drink up Mr. Ipa-Nut, people are going nuts over this new peanut-flavored beer combo from Planters. We'll show you more, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Thursday, October 25th, your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern.

Looking at a rebound, Futures are showing gains across the board this morning. The Futures have pulled back a little bit, but we still see 157- point gain on the Dow Futures this morning. This, after that major selloff yesterday that put the NASDAQ in correction territory, that's down more than 10 percent from its recent high. The Dow and S&P, both negative now, for the year.

In Europe, we have some gains to report this morning, in France and Germany, the Footsie 100 in England has dipped into negative territory, ever so slightly. And markets in Asia, closing mostly lower overnight, the Shanghai Index up marginally, but the KOSPI in South Korea, down sharply, now in bear market territory.

More big names reporting earnings today, Twitter and Comcast, are both moving ahead of reports. We had Twitter stock. Twitter reports later this hour, up more than two percent, at the moment. We'll bring you the numbers as soon as they come out.

A chilling update on the murder of a Saudi journalist, CIA Director Gina Haspel has reportedly heard audio of the killing of Jamal Khashoggi. We will give you the latest.

Plus, it's the biggest security breach to hit the aviation industry, details on Cathay Pacific hack that's affecting nearly 10 million passengers

And called them old unreliable, consumer reports has a list of the 10 most unreliable cars, you might be shocked to see which vehicles are on that list. Plus, you might want to relax and go nuts with this beer. We'll introduce you to an IPA, with a peanuty twist.

To our top story this half hour, health care in focus, President Trump will outline a plan to lower health care costs this afternoon, ahead of the midterms.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP: Republicans want to create better health care through more choice, lower drug prices and you will see, very soon, drug prices will go plunging downward, you wait, you watch. It's all in motion. And we've created much more competition. Democrats want socialist health care, where private plans are outlawed and abolished.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Recent Fox News Poll shows that health care is, indeed, the number one issue motivating voters, in the upcoming midterm elections.

Joining me now, Democratic Strategist, Jessica Ehrlich, along with Republican Strategist and Former Trump Campaign Data and Strategy Director, Matt Braynard, Jessica, your reaction to the President's plan and that might impact people who are voting based on health care?

JESSICA EHRLICH, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, I would love to see lower health care costs especially lower pharmaceutical costs, I think, everyone would like to see that, but the details of this plan have yet to be revealed.

And the last two years, given the majority in both the House and the Senate that the President has enjoyed, nothing has been done so far, which I'm sure has frustrated Republicans, but it's also frustrated Democrats and voters, in general.

So, I'm highly dubious and skeptical that there's anything, you know -- this is the emperor's new clothes, when it comes to an actual plan that's going to be implemented.

MCDOWELL: Well, Matt, I will point this out, in terms of bringing down prescription drug costs, that this year, the FDA has approved a record number of generic drugs so far this year, and that is another -- delivering on another promise is getting government out of the way.

And this has been one of the things that, for years, health care analysts have been talking about, so there is that, as well, and then, in Obamacare, the, kind of, standard plan in Obamacare, the premium is actually for next year, going to be slightly lower than it was last year.

So, there are some things going on that could influence voters.

MATT BRAYNARD, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Yes. And I need to correct what my colleague here just said. There was tremendous progress made in health care these last two years, because Trump and the Republicans repealed the most egregious violation of individual rights in Obamacare was and getting rid of the individual mandate, that is gone.

So, that is a substantial advance. That was a regressive tax on our poor citizens, and that's no more thanks to this president. I'm very excited to see what this plan is going to bring. We do know that the health care issue was, what cost the Democrats control of Congress in 2010. So, going on the offense on this issue, is only going to yield tremendous dividends for our side.

MCDOWELL: Jessica, I'll get your reaction to that, because a lot of the -- a lot of the ads -- and Democrats have roughly -- half the ads that Democrats have been running in the midterm elections are related to health care and a lot of them focused on Republicans want to repeal the coverage for pre-existing conditions.

It's something that hasn't happened, but nevertheless, they've made that a talking point.

EHRLICH: Well, I mean, I think that's part of the frustration on both sides, right? So, for a lot of Democrats and even a tremendous number of moderate Republicans and independent voters, the repeal of the Obamacare in its full state, the abolition of the pre-existing conditions, as a pre- requisite for your health care.

These are things that get people out to the polls, that have energized people that we're seeing in this, I think, what's going to be record turnouts for midterm elections. Contrary, yes, you can hold on to, oh, they took away, you know, they abolished part of this one aspect of Obamacare.

But the Republicans came in on this wave, with Trump, saying, they were going to appeal it completely and they weren't able to do that, they created a new plan that they could also --

BRAYNARD: With no help from Democrats.

EHRLICH: with their own majority. So, these are the facts. And you can spin them any way you want to, but it's a disappointment to a lot of people, yes, it does get people to the polls and we're going to see that this time around.

MCDOWELL: I'll say this, it's a disappointment that they've got rid of a tax on people, I don't know if people see that as a disappoint, but I'll get your response and I want to move on.

EHRLICH: People who wanted Obamacare abolished were disappointed that it wasn't accomplished.

MCDOWELL: Go ahead, Matt.

BRAYNARD: There was -- there was --Obamacare was not repealed and replaced, the plan that covers pre-existing conditions because of one arrogant Republican senator. We're likely going to be fixing that in this next Congress.

And it's very disingenuous to be running ads saying that Republicans, these horrible Republicans are going to get rid of pre-existing condition coverage, when you just made the point that we've had control for the last two years, so why haven't we done it yet?

These ads are really making the presumption that voters are very stupid and I don't think they're going to succeed.

MCDOWELL: Moving onto immigration, there's a caravan of thousands of migrants heading to the United States from Honduras. The President, saying, that he will send as many troops as possible, to block them from entering our country.

Matt, how does this going to impact voters, because President Trump has really tried to make -- use this and make immigration a more important issue coming up ahead of the midterms?

BRAYNARD: Look, if you want to have the potential to break the land speed record here on earth, ask a Democrat, on camera, what they think about this problem and they'll disappear before your eyes. We've already seen some of their leading candidates like Beto O'Rourke, take a pass on the question.

Republicans around the country need to get footage of this caravan, in their television ads, and make it clear that we are the ones that are going to stop it. The other party is AWOL because they see this as an opportunity to bring in more potential voters.

MCDOWELL: Jessica, your response to that, because I hear a lot of the rhetoric from some Democrats, some people on the left, loud prominent voices, saying that President Trump is trying to stoke fear among the voters, and that he's using these people to basically gin up their fears.

And I pushed back on that. This is really an issue do you believe in open borders or not? So, it's not based on fear, it's based on President Trump asking people if they believe in the rule of law and our immigration laws that are on the books.

BRAYNARD: It's based on footage. They can see with their own eyes.

EHRLICH: I disagree. I think it's the opposite, because contrary to Democrats disappearing on this issue, there was even, you know -- when we were talking about this last night on air, they were showing clips of President Obama, being very strong, actually, that we need to have border security and enforce the laws that are on the books, and that was proven in his record of deportations.

The issue that's happened is that there's rhetoric that's been out there that gins up people. Immigration is an issue and the fear of immigrants flooding into the country uncontrolled, or in some way, lose on the streets, that is an issue with voters, no question.

And it certainly gets out Trump's voters and it encourages them to vote. That's why he's been saying at his rallies, talking about border security in the wall, as well as talking about the Supreme Court nominations. These are things that incite his voters.

However, there's no proof that Democrats want, you know, completely open, fluid borders that that's happened, that that happened under any of the administrations --

BRAYNARD: Other than how they governed in the last eight years.

EHRLICH: What's happened is that we have yet to have anything, again, come out of the last two years that has changed the issue where we continue to have. There is yet to be a piece of legislation from the President's office or from the House or the Senate that are Republican-controlled, that have fixed the problem that we currently have. These people are continuing to come.

MCDOWELL: Matt, I will -- I will hit on that. But I do want to point out that a lot of prominent Democrats talk repeatedly about abolishing ICE. That we went from people being upset about the family separations at the border, to we need to get rid of ICE, which actually stops human and child trafficking.

So, again, to say that some Democrats don't believe in that, that's inaccurate, that some people talk about that repeatedly, who are running for office, but Matt --

EHRLICH: There are people running for office who talk about that.

(CROSSTALK)

BRAYNARD: But you referenced Obama. He is nor running for office. Where's Schumer on the issue? Where's Pelosi on the issue?

EHRLICH: It's the same between -- there are -- the people -- there are Democrats and Republicans on both sides, who say things that are of one extreme or the other.

MCDOWELL: Right. Matt -- I want to get Matt's -- Jessica --

EHRLICH: That is not referred to all Democrats or all Republicans.

MCDOWELL: I want to ask Matt, one final word, with President Trump making immigration an issue, Matt, does it highlight -- because he's not running for re-election, it is -- it is Republicans --

BRAYNARD: He is running for re-election.

MCDOWELL: Oh, well, the people are going to the polls, Matt, in less than two weeks, to vote on people in Congress and in the Senate. Does it highlight the fact that the Republicans haven't done that much on immigration? They have not fully funded his wall and they have not put financial restrictions on funding for sanctuary cities. Does it hurt them potentially, rather than help Republicans in less than two weeks?

BRAYNARD: No, and I want to -- no, not at all. Because we are in, at least, in my lifetime, the third re-alignment of the Republican Party, the Congress that comes back, whether we control both Houses or not, is going to be the Trump Republican Party.

Right now, we are dealing with the dead-enders of the Paul Ryan era, who are basically in the pockets of, you know, China and the Chamber of Commerce. And so, they've been an obstruction in many ways, to this president, but the new Republicans that are coming in, this is the Trump Republican Party, and that's going to change. So, I look forward to that.

MCDOWELL: All right. We've got to -- Matt, we've got to go for breaking news. Thank you both for having a civil conversation.

EHRLICH: Thanks, good morning.

MCDOWELL: Jessica and Matt, good morning to you both. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Breaking news right now, you are looking live at pictures in New York City. That is the New York City Police Department transporting a suspicious package found in lower Manhattan. The neighborhood is the Tribeca Neighborhood, that is north of the World Trade Center, the world financial center. This is in the Tribeca Neighborhood.

This follows a series of explosive devices that were found across the country sent to prominent Democrats and CNN, addressed to John Brennan at CNN. It's not unclear if this is related but the New York City Police Department has responded to reports of a suspicious package. This is in Tribeca in the vicinity of Greenwich and Franklin streets in Tribeca, lower Manhattan. We will bring you more developments as we get it, but this as New Yorkers are going to work this morning.

This package already in transit, this is in -- this is in the transport vehicle used for explosive devices, so it's being transported to, I believe, it's in the Bronx where this facility is, where the NYPD takes these types of packages suspicious. But, again, this was found down in Tribeca, near Greenwich and Franklin. It's worth-noting that this is also not just a residential neighborhood but also a busy financial area, there's one Citigroup building that's across the street from where the suspicious package was said to be found. We will bring you more as we get it. New York City Police Department transporting that suspicious package found in lower Manhattan.

Moving onto this, the Director of the CIA has reportedly heard the audio of the killing Journalist Jamal Khashoggi, Cheryl Casone has details on this developing story, Cheryl.

CASONE: It is developing as well, Dagen, good morning. Again, CIA Director Gina Haspel is Turkey to investigate the murder that took place in the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul. Turkish officials through multiple leaks to the media have touted the existence of audiotape of Khashoggi's killing. While the Washington Post has reported that Haspel has heard it, which a source describes as compelling. And Haspel is due back in Washington today to brief President Trump on what she heard, what she learned. Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman, calling the killing "a heinous crime" that cannot be justified. He made the comments at the Future Investment Initiative, that has been, of course, overshadowed by the murder of Jamal Khashoggi.

Well, another headline we're following for you this morning. A data breach at Cathay Pacific, the Asian airline confirming the hack may have compromised a personal information of nearly 10 million passengers. That data would include e-mail addresses, passport numbers and date of births. Cathay Pacific apologizing, it's contacting passengers who may have been affected and also says there's no evidence, any personal data may have been misused. Taking a look at shares of Cathay Pacific, the stock is actually down 13 percent so far for the year.

Well, American car brands slipping in annual reliability rankings published by consumer reports. Ford is at number 18, that's down three slots from last year, followed by General Motors, Buick brand which fell out of the top 10. G.M., Chevrolet, and Cadillac brands, also losing ground. Tesla fell six places, 27th by the way. Meanwhile Lexus, Toyota's luxury brand, regained its title as the most reliable brand. Shares of Toyota are down about seven percent so far this year.

And then, finally, there was this to leave you with, guys. Mr. Peanut wants you to have your peanuts and drink them at the same time. Planters is teaming up with Chicago's Noon Whistle Brewery to bring you a peanut- flavored beer. It's called Mr. IPA-nut -- there's the can. The new brew is going to have all of the, all of the familiar (INAUDIBLE) you get with an IPA, but it's also going to have Planters iconic honey roasted peanut flavor and a little bit of salt as well. The beer is going to be released on October 27th, just in time for National Beer Day. The catch, you have to head to Illinois if you want a sip, and of course, that day, I already checked, is a Saturday, Dagen, unfortunately for us onset. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Cheryl. Cool car there.

CASONE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, Twitter earnings out in moments. We'll break down the numbers and look at what role social media is playing in the upcoming midterm elections.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Breaking news to bring you. This is a live look at New York City Police Department transporting a suspicious package found in lower Manhattan in the Tribeca neighborhood. This is in the vicinity of Greenwich and Franklin street, this follows a series of explosive devices that were found across the country sent to prominent Democrats and CNN. It's not unclear if this is related but this package was found near the Tribeca Grill, that is the restaurant long associated with Robert de Niro, long owned by Robert de Niro. So, again, that package, suspicious package in transit to the explosive disposal unit of the New York City Police Department.

Moving onto tech earnings, they're in focus this morning. Twitter is set to report its results momentarily. The stock moving up, it's up about 3- 1/2 percent at the moment. Joining me now is Tech Analyst and Big Eyed Wish Founder Ian Wishingrad. Ian, good to see you this morning. What are you watching for in Twitter's earnings?

IAN WISHINGRAD, FOUNDER, BIG EYED WISH: Good to see you this morning, as well. Thanks for having me.

MCDOWELL: Sorry, I didn't mean to skip over good morning.

WISHINGRAD: So, everyone is estimating that they're going to have good numbers from a business standpoint. I think there's just going to be a reality check on what kind of business it really is. There are certain businesses that have billions of users like the Facebook and those Instagram, and those are these incredible unicorns that people really want to be able to put a ton of add dollars into. Twitter, I think, unlike Snapchat, have much smaller user bases, so people are just going to have to reset their expectations, deal with their relatively modest user base and how they're able to monetize.

MCDOWELL: I point at Mike Murphy, because again, but Twitter has tried to right its business in terms of better targeting ads, but all of these social media platforms have been dealing with problems with not securing the user data, but also allegations of going after conservatives -- bias against conservatives.

MURPHY: Yes. I mean, that affects all of them. I think the big story with Twitter is we run venture capital funds, so early stage start-ups are all advertising on Facebook. We never hear someone come in and say, you know, we're allocating our ad dollars that you're giving to us Twitter. So, I think Twitter has to figure out, is it a news source, how does -- what's the best way to monetize its base?

WISHINGRAD: I 100 percent agree with you. I mean, as an investor, I never bought the stock, I can't buy the stock, I enjoy it. The only prominent ad placement is when you see what's trending and then you try to put your sponsored show or whatever you're trying to promote in that section. But, it really seems to me almost more of a public good or news source than it is a great place to drive any revenue.

MCDOWELL: But it's almost as if President Trump has kept this company relevant --

WISHINGRAD: The best thing ever --

MCDOWELL: -- and made it an incredible tool for political communication. Curious to find out how you think that activity on Twitter and other social media platforms will influence the midterm elections, potentially, or how they're using ahead of the midterms?

WISHINGRAD: What I think we've all learned now, you have to do a little more research than just trust necessarily what's trending; they're talk about deep fakes now, I think. The future is going to be really hairy and the more trusted news outlets are going to become more important than ever to tell you what's real and what's fake, because it's not just going to be Twitter, comments and things that are trending. It's literally visuals that are going to look real that might not be real. So, veracity is going to be the biggest theme for the upcoming election, and all of them are going to be vulnerable forever.

MCDOWELL: Real quick, Emily.

JASHINSKY: Well, I mean -- obviously, the implications of the election, what happens in terms of regulation, what are people thinking about, what are the Democrats are thinking about, what Republicans are thinking about, what would the difference be if Democrats take control of the house?

WISHINGRAD: That's a good question. I'm not sure --

MCDOWELL: You don't have to answer if you don't want to.

(LAUGHTER)

WISHINGRAD: I don't think that's necessarily a partisan issue. Neither side necessarily benefits from incorrect information being spread, so I think the regulation is inevitable no matter who's in charge.

MCDOWELL: Ian Wishingrad, good to see you.

WISHINGRAD: Thank you very much.

MCDOWELL: Twitter earnings, they are coming up. Still ahead, rolls on the run, David Schwimmer responds in the best way to the viral photo of a look- alike rob in a liquor store. Next hour, and Maria with Larry Ellison, MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good morning --

END

urn:contentItem:5TK0-MDF1-DXH2-6178-00000-00Dow Futures Point to Rebound after Dow's 600-Point Slide Yesterday; Tesla Posts Record Profit; Trump on the Campaign Trail; Update on Saudi Journalist; President Trump to Outline Plan to Lower Health Care Costs; Caravan Heading to Border; NYPD Transporting Suspicious Package Found In Lower Manhattan; CIA Hears Khashoggi Tape; Planters' New Nutty Beer; Twitter Earnings Imminent2018-10-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTMike Murphy, Jack Brewer, Emily Jashinsky, Jessica Ehrlich, Matt Braynard, Ian WishingradNEWSFinancial102501cb.231Dow Futures Point to Rebound after Dow's 600-Point Slide Yesterday; Tesla Posts Record Profit; Trump on the Campaign Trail; Update on Saudi Journalist; President Trump to Outline Plan to Lower Health Care Costs; Caravan Heading to Border; NYPD Transporting Suspicious Package Found In Lower Manhattan; CIA Hears Khashoggi Tape; Planters' New Nutty Beer; Twitter Earnings ImminentDagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: in fact, today, for the S&P 500, is one of the busiest days of earning season, 80 of the 500 companies in the S&P report earnings today.

And, Elon Musk, quieting his critics, Tesla, reporting a record quarterly profit, and results beating expectations. That's right, Tesla profit. The stock, soaring, it's up double digits in premarket trading.

Searching for a sender, a manhunt, underway for a person, who sent explosive devices to prominent Democrats and CNN, plus authorities trying to track down a package sent to Former Vice President Joe Biden. We have the latest on that.

And a look at the economy, in America, from one of the biggest names in technology, Oracle founder, Larry Ellison, sitting down with Maria Bartiromo, in an exclusive interview, he weighs in on the political environment to the health of the economy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY ELLISON, CO-FOUNDER & EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, ORACLE: I think the economy is doing great, so again, I was Bill Clinton's second largest contributor when he ran for office. You know, I'm neither a Democrat nor a Republican, I tend to be in the middle, which means very lonely. There's (INAUDIBLE) polarized.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: More of Maria's exclusive must-see interview with Larry Ellison, one of the great innovators from this country. You have to hear what he has to say.

All of that and so much more, coming up this morning, the Federalist Commentary Writer, Emily Jashinsky, Rosecliff CEO and Managing Partner, Mike Murphy and the Brewer Group CEO, Former NFL Star, Jack Brewer. Welcome one and all. Let's get right to it.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF: Good morning, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Because I have a lot much I want to talk about with Murphy, over here. To our top story, a potential market rebound this morning, after the Dow and S&P fell into negative territory for the year, yesterday.

This is Twitter. It is set to release its quarterly earnings later this morning, other tech giants on deck, for today, include Amazon and Google's parent company, Alphabet. They report their earnings after the market closed today. Mike, what do you make of these earnings, what does the market need to see to firm up here?

MURPHY: Well, clearly, companies are getting cheaper than they were, a month ago. We hit new highs last month. Now, we have this major drawdown 10 percent, in the markets. Earnings are what I'm looking at.

You see what Microsoft put out yesterday. Those numbers were very good, I won't say outstanding, but enough to not cause a major selloff in the stock, get sold down to $98.00, right after the earnings were announced.

But now, if you see this morning, it's firmed up in the low 100s, that's enough for me to say I want to buy Microsoft on a pullback, and look for the same from Amazon, same from Google. If the growth story is still intact, this is a buying opportunity.

MCDOWELL: If the growth story is still intact. So, it was -- what triggered the selloff to start the month of October. It was to say -- is really a replay in some ways of what we saw earlier this year.

MURPHY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It was worries about inflation, higher wages and rising interest rates. But that hasn't been the story lately, because you saw -- money has been going into treasuries, money went a little bit of money went into treasuries yesterday, the 10-year -- the yield was down slightly.

So what is it, is it worries about global growth and corporate profits? We have been talking about the revenue story, and I was looking at the revenue miss number, so, so far, through the quarter, we have 38 percent of companies that have missed revenue expectations, which is the biggest percentage this year.

MURPHY: There's been a story going on and a lot of people focusing on peak earnings, this is good as it gets. Is it going to get worse from here? So, a lot of people, I think, taking some money off the table after these big run-ups we've seen.

I don't see that. I see solid earnings and it's really the companies that have been -- I'm not focusing on a company like Ford that announced yesterday, I'm focusing on the companies where we've seen the growth. So that's the big tech, that's Microsoft, that's Google, that's Amazon, later today.

MCDOWELL: Well, let me mention Microsoft and Tesla, we -- people, investors love to hate Tesla, so Microsoft, Mike was talking about this, beat revenue and profit estimates based on its cloud-computing growth and Tesla defied Wall Street expectations, posting a record profit.

Just your thoughts on Tesla because they moved up their earnings announcement, so I personally assume that they were going to report a quarterly profit, that they had something to crow about and indeed, they did.

MURPHY: Yes, interesting because, you know, when the -- when Elon Musk announced that he was moving the earnings up, a lot of, like, the talk there, was that he was doing that to attack the Shorts, that a lot of Shorts had bought weekly puts, made weekly bets against his company for next week, when he was going to announce.

In order to do that, you have to pay up a lot for those put options, because there's an earning's announcement coming in there. So, by moving the earnings to this week, a short-seller would immediately lose 70 to 80 percent of the value when the bets he made against Elon Musk's company.

So, bring it forward and then top it off, you have profitability and great numbers. This, to me, Tesla right here, after this huge rally, isn't something you'd want to jump into. Yesterday was the time to buy Tesla.

MCDOWELL: I'm looking at the results, particularly it is cash, people concerned about the level of debt, it's free cash flow came in much higher than expectations.

MURPHY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It's about $881 million, its total cash on hand, its $3 billion. Its accounts payable did also rise, but in terms of -- and I'm going to get to Jack and Emily, but in terms of its financial position, it looks better here.

MURPHY: Looks better. And remember, they have a big bond payment that they have to -- that's coming up. So, you know, early next year, the cash position is going to get more and more focused on, so this is a great start for Elon Musk, but he's going to have to continue this type of movement.

JACK BREWER, CEO, THE BREWER GROUP: So, in regard to Tesla, because obviously, we see everything that's going on outside with Elon Musk and everyone is just going back and forth, for me personally, I don't think this is going to last very long, but how --

MURPHY: back and forth.

BREWER: I don't think -- I don't think the growth of the company is going to continue to last as long. I'm scared about the first quarter of next year, when those convertible notes come due, I wonder how they are going to be able to react there and will they be able to continue with the earnings growth.

But beyond that, in the broader market, here, as you look, and Dagen, you mentioned 38 percent of the companies have missed earnings.

MCDOWELL: Revenue.

BREWER: Revenue, excuse me. I'm seeing a lot of companies that I didn't expect to hit their earnings growth -- hit their earnings growth. So, what does that mean for our economy, is this going to be something as we go into the first of the year, will we see more and more companies that are expected not to grow, actually hitting their earnings numbers?

MURPHY: I think the economy is doing great right now, it's booming, things are moving in the right direction, so that's where you want to be -- if you want to focus on that, that's something to focus on right now, is the economy.

It's literally visuals that are going to look real that might not be real. So, veracity is going to be the biggest theme for the upcoming election, and all of them are going to be vulnerable forever.

MCDOWELL: Real quick, Emily.

JASHINSKY: Well, I mean -- obviously, the implications of the election, what happens in terms of regulation, what are people thinking about, what are the Democrats are thinking about, what Republicans are thinking about, what would the difference be if Democrats take control of the house?

WISHINGRAD: That's a good question. I'm not sure --

MCDOWELL: You don't have to answer if you don't want to.

(LAUGHTER)

WISHINGRAD: I don't think that's necessarily a partisan issue. Neither side necessarily benefits from incorrect information being spread, so I think the regulation is inevitable no matter who's in charge.

MCDOWELL: Ian Wishingrad, good to see you.

WISHINGRAD: Thank you very much.

MCDOWELL: Twitter earnings, they are coming up. Still ahead, rolls on the run, David Schwimmer responds in the best way to the viral photo of a look- alike rob in a liquor store. Next hour, and Maria with Larry Ellison, MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

MCDOWELL: Good morning --

Jul 29, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) US stocks rose Wednesday following a key Federal Reserve policy meeting and congressional testimony from big tech companies including Facebook and Amazon.The Federal Reserve held interest rates near zero, and again pledged to do whatever it takes to aid the US economy in recovery from the pandemic recession.Starbucks and AMD shares climbed after earnings releases. Boeing and General Motors shares also ticked up after earnings reports.Later this week, Apple[1],Amazon[2], andAlphabet[3]are set to report quarterly earnings.Read more on Business Insider.[4] US stocks rose Wednesday after the Federal Reserve signaled it will provide continued stimulus to the economy amid the pandemic recession.The Federal Reserve held interest rates near zero[5] on Wednesday, and reiterated that it would do whatever it takes to support the US economic recovery. In a speech, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said the recent uptick in coronavirus cases is beginning to weigh on the recovery[6]."If anything, there was more mention of fiscal policy than monetary policy in Powell's speech," said Seema Shah, chief strategist at Principal Global Investors. "Certainly, while investors ears were leaning into Powell's comments, their minds will likely also be trained on discussions currently underway in Congress about the forthcoming fiscal cliff."Also on Wednesday, the CEOs of big tech companies including Apple[7], Amazon[8], Facebook[9], and Google parent Alphabet[10] gave testimony before the House Antitrust Subcommittee addressing how they are handling antitrust challenges from regulators.

Tech stocks, which have outperformed this year, held onto gains through the start of the hearing.Here's where US indexes stood at the 4:00 p.m. ET market close on Wednesday: S&P 500[11]: 3,258.60, up 1.25%Dow Jones industrial average[12]: 26,541.97, up 0.61% (163 points)Nasdaq composite[13]: 10,542.95 up 1.35% Read more:Jason Tauber is crushing the market this year by finding the tech companies enabling the biggest disruptions. He told us how he's adjusting his game plan as valuations soar - and 7 of his top picks today.[14]Earnings season continued. Shares of AMD[15] surged Wednesday following a better-than-expected earnings release Tuesday. Starbucks rose[16]after its CEO Kevin Johnson said that same-store sales for open locations turned positive in July, a sign of recovery from pandemic-related lockdowns.General Motors[17] and Boeing[18] also ticked up after releasing quarterly results Wednesday before the opening bell. Shares of Tesla gained about 3% after Morgan Stanley boosted its price target for the second time this month.Eastman Kodak[19] surged more than 500% Wednesday after securing a $765 million government loan[20] to produce drug ingredients in response to the coronavirus pandemic.Investors will be awaiting further earnings report scheduled this week. Apple[21],Amazon[22], andAlphabet[23] are set to report quarterly earnings on Thursday, giving further information about how the companies have fared amid the pandemic, ensuing lockdowns, and a recent uptick in new COVID-19 cases.Read more: 3 Wall Street pros managing $12 billion in assets share their strategies for profiting from the economy's recovery — and explain why investors should be urn:contentItem:5S35-5HM1-JD45-J1SF-00000-00Dow Jones, CAC40, DAX... Donald Trump réveille l'«indice de la peur»2018-04-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisDow Jones, CAC40, DAX... Donald Trump réveille l'«indice de la peur»Jean-Michel Bezat

Chronique. Les boursiers de la planète ont lu avec un peu de gourmandise et beaucoup d'inquiétude le message tweeté par Donald Trump, mercredi 11avril, vers 6heures du matin (heure de Washington): le président américain appelaient les Russes à se tenir «prêts» car ses   «missiles beaux et neufs et “intelligents!"» allaient s'abattre sur leurs alliés syriens pour les punir d'avoir utilisé des armes chimiques contre les rebelles de la Ghouta. Les grandes places ont accusé le coup sans céder à la panique pour autant. New York a clôturé en baisse de 0,9%, Paris de 0,56%, Francfort de 0,83%, alors que Londres restait stable (- 0,13%).

La dégradation des relations de la Russie avec les Occidentaux est, en effet, un facteur de plus de déstabilisation de l'économie mondiale. L'oeil des opérateurs n'est bien sûr pas uniquement braqué sur les troubles politiques. Ils surveillent aussi les tensions commerciales sino-américaines, le retour de l'inflation aux Etats-Unis avec l'augmentation des salaires, la hausse des taux de la Réserve fédérale, la perspective d'une régulation des «Big Tech» après les scandales Facebook, un possible ralentissement de la croissance mondiale…

Mais le climat, marqué en2017 par une forte valorisation des actions dans un marché serein, s'est détérioré depuis février. L'année 2018 s'annonce incertaine, de l'avis de tous les experts. C'est la volatilité - plus qu'une baisse - qui risque de s'emparer des places boursières. Car les trois années (1999, 2003, 2009) où la moyenne de l'indice VIX, qui mesure cette volatilité sur la base de l'évolution du S&P-500, les 500 grandes sociétés cotées aux Etats-Unis, a été la plus forte, ont coïncidé avec des gains d'au moins 20%. Et les perspectives des entreprises restent bonnes.

Un jeu de yoyo

Cet «indice de la peur» est bel et bien orienté à la hausse. Ainsi le S&P500 a-t-il connu huit séances de variation supérieure à 1% depuis début février. Autant que sur toute l'année 2017. La veille des déclarations va-t-en guerre de Trump, le Dow Jones avait gagné 1,79% et le Nasdaq 2,07%. C'était la réponse enthousiaste de Wall Street à la promesse du président chinois Xi Jinping d'ouvrir davantage son pays à ses partenaires économiques. Les deux reculaient dès le lendemain. Et ce jeu de yoyo va continuer, alimenté par les incertitudes du monde.

Début janvier, Ian Bremmer, président de la société d'évaluation des risques Eurasia Group, jugeait que «2018 présente les risques géopolitiques les plus dangereux depuis vingt ans». Il en dressait la liste dans son étude annuelle «Top Risks»: une «guerre froide technologique», la déstabilisation de l'Afrique, les poussées populistes et protectionnistes, les incertitudes après les élections allemandes et italiennes, un Brexit dur, une dénonciation par Washington de l'accord sur le nucléaire iranien, la Corée du Nord… On y ajouterait volontiers le prochain Tweet de Trump.

urn:contentItem:5X0H-DX11-DYTD-9151-00000-00Dow Jones Clears Resistance On China Trade Talks; Lululemon, Coupa, Copart Break Out On Earnings: Weekly Review2019-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisNEWSDow Jones Clears Resistance On China Trade Talks; Lululemon, Coupa, Copart Break Out On Earnings: Weekly ReviewIBD STAFF

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Biz01-review-090619-AP.jpg

The Dow Jones and other major indexes broke out above monthlong range, powering higher on plans for new China trade talks in early October. Lululemon Athletica, Coupa Software and Copart cleared buy points on earnings, while several leaders broke out. But recent software IPOs Slack Technologies and CrowdStrike fell despite beating views, along with Zoom Video Communications.

Meanwhile, U.S. economic data weakened, with the August jobs report showing slowing private hiring while a key manufacturing gauge signaled contraction.

Dow Jones Clears Key Level

The Dow Jones, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite jumped above their 50-day moving averages, a resistance level for several weeks. China trade talks buoyed optimism, though it's unclear if there are reasons for real progress on resolving an escalating tariffs war. Lululemon, Copart and Coupa broke out on earnings. Several other leaders, including Universal Display and Mastercard, also topped buy points. But software earnings were decidedly mixed, with the Zoom Video, CrowdStrike and Slack IPO stocks falling.

Job Growth Slows, Factories Contract

The U.S. added just 130,000 jobs last month, less than expected, as private hiring cooled. The jobless rate held at 3.7% even as labor force participation rose to a six-year high. Average hourly wage growth was 3.2%. Manufacturers added a slim 3,000 jobs. Meanwhile, the ISM manufacturing index unexpectedly fell below the neutral 50 level, as U.S. factories joined a global slump.

Lululemon Jumps On Earnings, Guidance

IBD 50 stock Lululemon Athletica moved into buy zone after the upmarket yogawear maker reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue. The Canadian retailer also stretched its guidance. It raised its full-year EPS target to $4.63-$4.70 from $4.51-$4.58, which was above analyst views.

Software Earnings

Several software makers reported better-than-expected views, but shares went different ways.

Coupa Software reported Q2 profit rose 40% to 7 cents, defying views for a 10-cent loss. Revenue surged 54% to $95 million while billings jumped 57% to $107.7 million, both beating. Results included the acquisitions of Hipperos and Exari. Shares jumped, clearing a buy point.

Slack Technologies reported a smaller-than-expected Q2 loss as revenue swelled 58% to $145 million. But the workplace collaboration software maker sees a wider Q3 loss. It faces increasing competition from Microsoft. Slack stock plunged Thursday morning to a record low, following sharply for the week.

Zoom Video Communications reported adjusted earnings of 8 cents a share, with revenue rising 96% to $145.8 million, topping estimates of 2-cent profit on sales of $130.3 million. For the October quarter, Zoom guided higher. Shares of the April IPO fell nearly 8% Friday.

Cloudera reported Q2 revenue of $196.7 million, up 74% including the merger with Hortonworks, topping estimates of $182.3 million. The company reported an adjusted loss of 2 cents. Analysts had expected a 10-cent per share loss. Cloudera stock skyrocketed.

Smartsheet reported better-than-expected quarterly results, but the project management software maker gave weak guidance. Shares plunged Thursday and Friday.

Cybersecurity

Palo Alto Networks gave weak profit guidance for fiscal 2020 as it shifts to shorter-term contracts, but projected 20% three-year compound annual growth in total billings to around $6 billion and revenue to $5 billion. Continuing an acquisition spree, Palo Alto bought startup Zingbox for $75 million. Shares rose. CrowdStrike reported a narrower loss than expected while revenue leapt 94% to $108.1 million. The June IPO also offered solid guidance. But shares plunged Friday. Earlier in the week, CrowdStrike and Proofpoint struck an integration deal, sending both stocks higher.

Ciena

Ciena reported fiscal Q3 EPS jumped 48% as revenue rose 17% to $960.6 million, as it continues to gain share in the optical communications market. For the current October quarter, Ciena guided revenue estimates slightly higher while gross operating margin fell short of views. It also sees slim revenue growth in fiscal 2020. Shares fell.

States Launch Facebook Probe

New York State Attorney General Letitia James on Friday launched an antitrust probe of Facebook. She said Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Nebraska, North Carolina, Ohio, Tennessee, and the District of Columbia will join the investigation. The states will examine Facebook's data privacy and online ad dominance. The Texas AG said he'll launch a separate Big Tech probe on Monday. The Justice Department recently disclosed a probe of Big Tech dominance. Facebook stock fell Friday.

Facebook launched its online dating service in the U.S., hitting shares in Match Group. Facebook plans to integrate Instagram with the dating feature.

Starbucks Finds Support

Starbucks cut its fiscal 2020 earnings growth outlook to under 10%, down from prior estimates of at least 13% growth. The coffee giant said it's pulling stock buybacks forward into the current FY 2019. Also, 2020 tax rates will be higher than in 2019. But Starbucks said its "operating growth model is intact." Starbucks fell modestly but rebounded from just above their 50-day line. Shares are up sharply in 2019.

Airlines

JetBlue cut its Q3 revenue per available seat mile (RASM) growth amid weaker sales to Puerto Rico and the expected impact of Hurricane Dorian. United Airlines reiterated its prior full-year EPS guidance of $10.50 to $12, though the midpoint is below consensus for $11.73. Delta Air Lines said that it was "on track" for a 6% to 7% increase in revenue this year and a 25% increase in earnings per share growth. The carrier's August revenue seat miles climbed 5% overall, up 5.9% domestically and 3.6% internationally.

News In Brief

The European Union Aviation Safety Agency wants Boeing to perform in-flight maneuvers with the 737 Max's updated flight-control system both on and off. The Boeing 737 Max likely won't fly during the busy holiday travel season as global regulators reportedly want more information about the aerospace giant's proposed software changes.

MongoDB narrowed losses to 26 cents per share from 41 cents a year ago, as revenue vaulted 74% to $99 million. The database software stock saw subscription revenue rise 71% and services revenue grow 15%. MongoDB also gave solid guidance. But shares sold off Thursday.

HealthEquity sold off after the health savings account custodian gave mixed guidance in its first report since acquiring WageWorks at the end of August.

Walmart will stop selling some types of ammunition in the wake of two deadly shootings, with the CEO urging political action. Walmart, Kroger and several other retailers asked customers not to openly carry firearms in their stores.

Copart earnings leapt 43% while revenue grew 21% to $542.6 million, both beating and showing accelerating growth for a second quarter. The IBD 50 salvage car auction specialist soared, clearing a buy point.

urn:contentItem:5WK1-12H1-JCBB-K0S0-00000-00Dow Jones Futures: Amazon Prime Day, Facebook, Citigroup Lead Big Week For Stock Market Rally2019-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisSTOCK MARKET TODAYDow Jones Futures: Amazon Prime Day, Facebook, Citigroup Lead Big Week For Stock Market RallyED CARSON

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/stock-amazon-prime-day-01-shutter.jpg

Dow Jones futures edged higher Monday morning, along with S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq futures, with the current stock market rally at highs. Amazon stock, Facebook stock and Citigroup stock are all in buy zones heading into big events. Amazon.com kicked off Amazon Prime Day on Monday. Facebook, fresh off an FTC settlement, will join Amazon, Apple, and Google parent Alphabet in a House hearing on antitrust on Tuesday, along with cryptocurrency hearings focusing on Facebook Libra. Citigroup reports earnings early Monday, kicking off a big week for financials and earnings generally.

While Amazon, Facebook and Citigroup stock are in buy zones, Apple stock is moving toward a buy point while Google stock is in the process of building the right side of a base.

Dow Jones Futures Today

Dow Jones futures rose 0.1% vs. fair value along with S&P 500 futures climbed 0.1%. Nasdaq 100 futures were up 0.1%. Remember that overnight action in  and elsewhere doesn't necessarily translate into actual trading in the next regular session.

China's economy grew 6.2% in the second quarter vs. a year earlier, the smallest GDP gain since 1992. That was below Q1's 6.4% pace but met analyst estimates. Meanwhile, June data on retail sales and industrial production topped views, raising hopes that stimulus efforts are offsetting China trade war woes.

Current Stock Market Rally

The current stock market rally is looking strong, with the Dow Jones, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite all hitting new highs.

A number of top stocks cleared buy points, including FB stock and AMZN stock, with many others closing in on entries.

Among the , the Innovator IBD 50 ETF rose 1.5% last week to nine-month high. The iShares Expanded Tech-Software Sector ETF advanced 1.7%, setting all-time bests. The VanEck Vectors Semiconductor ETF jumped 3.2%.

The indexes all closed the week at essentially their best levels. So any modest gain Monday morning will set new all-time highs.

Amazon Prime Day

Amazon Prime Day will run on Monday-Tuesday, 12 hours longer than in prior years. Many deals were available Sunday. While Amazon Prime Day is the e-commerce giant's biggest sales event of the year and a reliable boost for new Amazon Prime memberships, the deals themselves tend to be just OK.

Amazon stock hasn't had huge moves during Amazon Prime Day week. In 2016, shares fell 1.3%. In 2017, they climbed 2.35%. Last year, AMZN stock was flat during Prime Day week.

As for last week, Amazon stock rose 3.55% to 2,011, clearing a 1,964.50 buy point from a long base.

AMZN stock rose a fraction early Monday.

Facebook FTC Settlement Lifts FB Stock

Facebook stock rallied 1.8% to 204.47 on Friday. Most of those gains on word of a $5 billion over privacy issues. The Facebook FTC settlement also includes some unspecified conditions, but it appears unlikely to have a big impact on the social giant's business model.

Facebook stock popped 4.3% last week, clearing a 195.50 cup-with-handle pattern. Shares fell a fraction before Monday's open.

Facebook Not In The Clear

But the FTC is still mulling Amazon and Facebook antitrust probes. The Justice Department will take the lead on competition concerns regarding Google and Apple. On Tuesday, those Big Tech giants face a House antitrust panel hearing. Several Democratic presidential candidates, notably Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., have called for breaking up Big Tech companies.

Aside from a June 3 tumble on possible Big Tech antitrust probes, investors don't seem too concerned, given Facebook and Amazon stock surging in recent weeks to buy zones.

Apple stock showed only a modest loss on June 3, with the consumer electronics giant seen as less exposed to antitrust concerns that the internet giants. Apple stock is working toward a 215.41 cup-with-handle buy point. The iPhone giant's handle is now long enough to be its own base. Last week, Apple stock formed a "handle" within that handle. That could offer an early entry of 205.18, but even aggressive investors should insist on a strong move in heavy volume to indicate that is a true resistance point for Apple stock.

Google stock is working a 1,297.07 buy point, but still has long way to go. GOOGL stock rose 1.15% to 1,145.34 last week, reclaiming the 50- and 200-day lines.

Facebook Libra Faces Scrutiny

Meanwhile, Facebook also will take part in congressional hearings on cryptocurrencies, after the tech giant unveiled plans last month for digital currency Libra.

President Trump last week said he was not a fan of Bitcoin or cryptocurrencies generally. With regards to Facebook Libra, Trump said the social giant may need a banking charter. A charter would involve a lot more regulation, oversight and capital requirements. Fed chief Jerome Powell also voiced some skepticism about Facebook Libra last week.

The SEC reportedly is mulling regulating Facebook Libra as a security.

Citigroup Earnings

Citigroup earnings are expected to rise 11% to $1.80 a share with revenue roughly flat at $18.489 billion. JPMorgan Chase, Goldman Sachs and Wells Fargo report Tuesday, with Bank of America on Wednesday and Morgan Stanley on Thursday.

Citigroup stock rose 0.5% to 71.77 last week, extending a move past a 69.06 cup-with-handle entry on a daily chart. On a weekly chart, Citigroup stock shows a 72.04 entry.

The for Citigroup stock has been flat for several months, following a slide from October 2017 to the end of 2018. Longer-term, the RS line has been sliding, reflecting Citi's underperformance vs. the S&P 500 index.

Bank stocks can outperform the market, but usually only for short periods.

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/Stock-bullBearFrankfurt-01-adobe.jpg

Dow Jones futures fell modestly early Wednesday, along with S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq futures, after the Justice Department finally confirmed that it is probing Big Tech, a heightened risk for Amazon.com, Google parent Alphabet, Facebook and Apple. Meanwhile, Chipotle Mexican Grill, Snapchat parent Snap and Texas Instruments topped earnings views late. Chipotle stock, Snap stock and Texas Instruments stock jumped. Amazon stock, Facebook stock, Google stock and Apple stock fell on the Big Tech antitrust probe report.

DOJ Big Tech Antitrust Probe

The DOJ Big Tech probe, announced late Tuesday, will examine the behavior of online platforms that dominate internet search, social media and retail services. The Justice Department's review is above and beyond an early June decision by the DOJ and FTC hashing out which agency will take the lead on Big Tech giants. The DOJ will have lead oversight of Google and Apple, while the FTC will handle Facebook and Amazon.

That on June 3 for Facebook stock, Google stock and Amazon stock, with Apple stock also falling modestly. But that marked a short-term low for those stocks and the bottom for the stock market correction that started in May.

Still, regulatory and political calls to go after Big Tech continue.

The Big Tech giants were all modestly lower overnight, with Facebook stock and Amazon stock just above recent buy points. Facebook, Amazon and Google report later this week.

Dow Jones Futures Today

Dow Jones futures fell 0.4% vs. fair value, extending losses as Boeing and Caterpillar reported disappointing Q2 results. S&P 500 futures fell 0.25% vs. fair value. Nasdaq 100 futures lost 0.25%. Keep in mind that overnight action in , Chipotle stock and more doesn't necessarily translate into actual trading in the next regular session.

Current Stock Market Rally

Plans for new China trade talks fueled a stock market rally Tuesday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.65% after lagging Monday's modest stock market rally. The S&P 500 index advanced 0.7% and the Nasdaq composite 0.6%.

Once again chip stocks led, with the sector sensitive to China trade news. The VanEck Vectors Semiconductor ETF climbed 1.1%, still in buy range from a buy point of 116.06. SMH kept rising late as Texas Instruments earnings lifted TI stock and others. The SMH ETF popped 2% on Monday, when it was .

Among other , the Innovator IBD 50 ETF rose 0.2%. The iShares Expanded Tech-Software Sector ETF fell 0.1%, but closed well off session lows.

Chipotle Earnings

Chipotle earnings rose 39% to $3.99 a share. Revenue grew 13% to $1.4 billion. rose 10%, their sixth straight quarter of accelerating growth.

Analysts expected Chipotle earnings of $3.69 a share on sales of $1.41 billion.

Chipotle stock popped 3.1% to 762.34. Shares dipped 0.4% Tuesday to 739.60. Chipotle stock has been working on a 749.35 buy point.

Snap Earnings Report

Snap lost 6 cents a share vs. a 14-cent loss a year earlier. Revenue rallied 48% to $388 million, the best year-over-year gain in years. Analysts expected a 10-cent per-share loss with revenue up 36% to $356 million.

Snapchat users were much higher than expected. for Q3 revenue.

Snap stock vaulted 10% to 16.32 early Wednesday. Shares already jumped 4.8% to 14.83 on Tuesday. Snap stock cleared its first-ever base in early June and is up 169% so far in 2019. That's much better than Facebook stock and Twitter, which also reports earnings this week.

Texas Instruments Earnings

Texas Instruments earnings earned $1.36 a share on sales of $3.67 billion vs. EPS of $1.37 a year earlier on $4.02 billion in revenue. Analysts expected Texas Instruments earnings of $1.21 a share on sales of $3.6 billion.

Texas Instruments stock rose nearly 6% to 127 before the open, signaling a move well above its January 2018 all-time high of 120.75.

Shares rose 1.6% Tuesday to 120.07, just within range of a 114.44 cup-with-handle entry and hitting an 18-month high intraday.

One Last Reminder

Remember that overnight action for individual stocks and Dow Jones futures may not translate into Wednesday's stock market action. Will investors decide that the DOJ Big Tech probe is no big deal, or a game-changing threat? Will the Snap stock enthusiasm carry over into the morning? Or will it disappear in, well, you know...
