urn:contentItem:6088-PXK1-DYTD-9254-00000-00Dow Jones Futures Signal More Gains For Coronavirus Stock Market Rally; Tesla Surges Again On Strong Deliveries2020-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisSTOCK MARKET TODAYDow Jones Futures Signal More Gains For Coronavirus Stock Market Rally; Tesla Surges Again On Strong DeliveriesED CARSON

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Stock-TeslaModel3-02-company.jpg

Dow Jones futures rose vs. fair value early Thursday, along with S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq futures, ahead of the June jobs report. The coronavirus stock market rally had a solid session Wednesday for growth names, with upbeat economic data and vaccine news. That's despite record new U.S. coronavirus cases as well as fresh Covid-19 restrictions and corporate actions.

All eyes are on Tesla, with TSLA stock continuing to soar early Thursday on second-quarter deliveries data.

FANG stocks Facebook, Amazon.com, Netflix and Google parent Alphabet showed bullish action Wednesday, while Teladoc Health and Okta cleared buy points. Among the FANG internet giants, Amazon stock and Netflix stock hit record highs, with NFLX stock moving back into a buy zone. Facebook stock and Google stock continued to rebound from last Friday's sell-offs, but those are a little murkier.

Teladoc stock and Okta stock offered entries for aggressive investors. Tesla stock is extended.

AMZN stock, TSLA stock and TDOC stock are on IBD Leaderboard, along with Apple stock. Okta stock is on SwingTrader. FB stock and NFLX stock are on the IBD 50 list. Google stock is on the IBD Long-Term Leaders watchlist.

While growth stocks fared well, many "real economy" names continue to lag. It's a stock picker's market. Diversify among leaders, but not across the stock market.

Dow Jones Futures Today

Dow Jones futures rose 0.85% vs. fair value, while S&P 500 futures were up 0.7%. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 0.7%.

Late Wednesday close, news broke that the CEOs of Apple, Facebook, Amazon and Google will appear before a House antitrust panel. That hearing will be the end of the panel's probe, which may result in new legislative proposals to rein in Big Tech. But shares of all four tech giants rose slightly before Thursday's open

The June jobs report will likely swing Dow Jones futures at 8:30 a.m. ET on Friday. Economists expect the mid-month jobs report to show a payrolls gain of 3 million after May's surprising increase of 2.51 million. The unemployment rate should fall to 12.4% from May's 13.3%.

Remember that overnight action in Dow futures and elsewhere doesn't necessarily translate into actual trading in the next regular stock market session. DJIA futures were negative early Tuesday until an upbeat ADP employment report and positive coronavirus vaccine trial data shortly before the open.

Join IBD experts as they analyze actionable stocks in the coronavirus stock market rally on IBD Live.

Coronavirus News

Coronavirus cases worldwide hit 10.83 million. Covid-19 deaths rose above 519,000.

Coronavirus cases in the U.S. have climbed to 2.78 million, with deaths near 131,000. New U.S. Covid-19 cases topped 51,000 on Wednesday, a record high, after clearing 40,000 for six straight days.

Arizona, California, Texas, Florida, Georgia and several other states are hitting record new coronavirus cases. Increased testing is a big factor, but the share of positive tests has spiked in many states as well.

New York halted plans to resume indoor dining amid the nationwide resurgence. That comes a day after New Jersey made the same move. On Tuesday, New York added California and seven other states to its Covid-19 quarantine rule. Travelers to New York from hot spot states must quarantine for 14 days.

Apple is closing 30 more Apple Stores as of Thursday. That's a total of 77 Apple Stores closed down temporarily once again as coronavirus cases soar again in much of the U.S. Apple stock edged lower Wednesday, but it's still near record highs.

Fellow Dow Jones component McDonald's is pausing further re-opening of dine-in service in the U.S. Shares fell late Wednesday but turned slightly higher in Thursday's premarket.

Covid-19 Deaths have continued to trend lower for the past several weeks despite soaring coronavirus cases. However, Arizona did report a daily record for coronavirus deaths, along with a new peak in daily infections. Texas reported its highest daily death toll in six weeks.

A reason for optimism is progress on coronavirus treatments and vaccines. Early Tuesday, Dow Jones giant Pfizer and BioNTech announced positive early Phase 1/2 Trial results for its coronavirus vaccine candidate. But there some side-effects at higher doses and the results haven't been peer reviewed. Pfizer stock pared gains but still closed with a 3.2% gain. BioNTech stock closed down 3.9%.

Coronavirus Stock Market Rally

The coronavirus stock market rally had a modest but upbeat session on the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine news and upbeat economic data. The ISM manufacturing index shot up 9.5 points in June to 52.6, better than expected and back above 50, signaling growth. Before the open, the ADP employment report found that private jobs grew by 2.37 million, less than expected. But May's figures were revised from -2.76 million to a gain of 3.065 million.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average faded into the close, sliding 0.3% in Wednesday's stock market trading. The S&P 500 index rose 0.5%. The Nasdaq composite climbed 0.95%. The big-cap Nasdaq 100 hit a record high, with FANG stocks Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google all contributing, along with Tesla stock.

Among the best ETFs, the Innovator IBD 50 ETF rallied 1.25%. The iShares Expanded Tech-Software Sector ETF jumped 2.1%, hitting a record high. The VanEck Vectors Semiconductor ETF sank 0.6%.

While there are many growth stocks showing bullish action, it's a stock picker's market. Although the Nasdaq is right at record highs, the Dow Jones today is still below its 200-day line.

Tesla Stock Soars On Deliveries

TSLA stock shot up 10% to 1,228 before the open, signaling a new all-time high.

Tesla delivered 90,650 electric vehicles, above estimates of around 88,000. Model 3 and Y deliveries were 80,050, while Model S and X deliveries were 10,600. Overall production from the Fremont and Shanghai plants was 82,272.

In news that broke late Wednesday, another "leaked" Musk email praised staff, "Just amazing how well you executed, especially in such difficult times." Meanwhile, Wedbush analyst Dan Ives raised his TSLA price target to 1,250 from 1,000, and his bull case target to 2,000 from 1,500.

Tesla stock rallied 3.7% to 1,119.63 on Wednesday. That extended Tuesday's 7% surge, clearing a short shelf consolidation, as well as Monday's 5.2% pop. Optimism soared after a "leaked" email Tuesday afternoon from CEO Elon Musk to employees said Tesla was close to being break-even.

At this point, Tesla stock is well extended even from the short consolidation, especially with delivery news on tap. Investors are pricing in a lot of good news for Tesla stock, both short and long term.

Tesla stock does have a potential options play for investors who believe it'll hold above 1,000 over the next several weeks.

In addition to Tesla stock, Chinese rival Nio continued to surge after reporting its Q2 deliveries. EV delivery van startup Workhouse Group and Blink Charging, which have hot stocks in recent days, also are up sharply before the open. The exception is EV and hydrogen truck startup Nikola.

Tesla Earnings?

If Musk wants to report Tesla earnings for the second quarter, he likely can recognize sufficient emission credits and Full Self Driving revenue to make that happen. Another quarter of Tesla earnings could spur TSLA stock's entry into the S&P 500 index.

Also late Wednesday, the NHTSA confirmed to the Los Angeles Times that the safety regulator is probing a possible design flaw in older Model S battery packs. Last week Business Insider said Tesla knew of the flaw that made them at higher risk of fires, but choose not to fix it.

Tesla Deliveries, Production Outlook

Looking ahead to third quarter, Tesla production should be at high voltage. Demand is more of an unknown.

It's unclear how much backlog remains in the U.S. for the Model Y, though price cuts and a lower-priced variant could keep demand going.

Europe potentially could see a boost in Tesla sales, fueled by new subsidies and perhaps limited supply in Q2. However, EV competition is growing in Europe, with the cheaper VW ID.3 finally set to launch in September.

As for China, how much backlog will remain for the relatively new made-in-China Tesla Model 3 LR variant, especially with lower subsidies? Several EV and hybrid rivals are entering the field.

Tesla has now trimmed the China price of imported Model S and Model X vehicles by 1%, offsetting a July 1 price hike for "FSD." In the U.S., Tesla hiked the cost of FSD by $1,000 on July 1 to $8,000.

Amazon Stock Hits High

Amazon stock rose 4.35% on Wednesday, hitting a record high. AMZN stock is acting well but doesn't have an actionable buy point.

Netflix Stock A Buy

Netflix stock advanced 6.7% to 485.64, also setting a new peak. The internet TV streaming giant rose to the top of a "Must Keep TV" list.

NFLX stock cleared a 459.07 buy point on June 22. Shares soon pulled back before Monday's bullish rebound from its 50-day and 10-week moving averages. Actionable entry points include 459.07 but also 474.11, just above the June 23 all-time high.

Facebook Stock, Google Stock Extend Rebounds

Facebook stock rose 4.6% to 237.55 and Google stock 1.7% to 1,442, both continuing to rebound strongly from sharp sell-offs. Both are potentially actionable, after Facebook stock and Google stock suffered serious damage last week.

On Friday, FB stock plunged 8.3% to 216.08 as a Facebook ad boycott grew. That was below its 50-day line and slightly above its original 215.38 cup-with-handle buy point. Monday morning, Facebook stock tumbled to 207.11 intraday. At this point, anyone who bought at an alternative 224.30 entry should have been long gone, while even those who bought near 215.38 probably should have exited. However, FB stock rallied to close higher on Monday, then kept rising.

For investors who hung on to Facebook stock, they can keep holding. Anyone looking to enter or reenter FB stock may want to wait for a move above the 245.19 high. Even better, shares will consolidate for a time before making a new move.

Google stock dived 5.45% on Friday to 1,362.54, below its 50-day line and its 1,145.63 cup-with-handle buy point, according to MarketSmith analysis. GOOGL stock reclaimed its 50-day line and its original entry point on Tuesday.

Google stock never triggered the 7%-8% down automatic sell rule, though investors understandably might have exited the position. GOOGL stock may be forming a new handle with a 1,475.89 entry.

Teladoc Stock

Teladoc stock rose 4.2% to 198.85. Shares hit 201.33 intraday, just clearing a very short trend line. That could provide an early entry for TDOC stock. Investors also could use 208.73 as a high-handle buy point from a recent consolidation.

Okta Stock

Okta stock jumped 5.3% to 210.92, a new high. The cybersecurity leader cleared a short consolidation, though it's too short for a proper base. But aggressive traders might use 205.81 or 206.19 as an entry point.

Coronavirus Stock Market Rally Won't Stop

After last week's sell-off, the expectation was that the coronavirus stock market rally would take a breather, perhaps with a deeper pullback or sideways action over several weeks. That would be normal and healthy, and perhaps overdue. The market rally's ascent has been too fast, too furious to be sustainable long term.

But the stock market rally is going to do what it's going to do. The Nasdaq is at record highs with growth stocks powering ahead. Facebook stock and Google stock looked seriously damaged Monday morning, but now look a lot better. Netflix stock, Okta stock and Teladoc are in or flirting with buy areas, while Tesla stock has taken off like a SpaceX rocket.

Don't try to guess what the stock market trend will be; pay attention to what the market is doing right now. Right now, it's a good time to be invested in growth stocks. But stay engaged and ready to act.

Read The Big Picture every day to stay in sync with the market direction and leading stocks and sectors.

urn:contentItem:5W88-6GK1-DYTD-9000-00000-00Dow Jones Futures: Stock Market Correction Intensifies On Facebook, Google, Amazon — But This Is The Worst Part2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisSTOCK MARKET TODAYDow Jones Futures: Stock Market Correction Intensifies On Facebook, Google, Amazon — But This Is The Worst PartED CARSON

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/stock-bear-night-04-adobe.jpg

Dow Jones futures signaled a rebound Monday morning, along with S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq futures. The current stock market correction intensified Monday as FANG stocks Facebook, Google parent Alphabet and Amazon.com plunged on antitrust fears, while Apple stock reversed lower. More worrisome was the action of the market-leading software sector. From Microsoft to ServiceNow, top software stocks were big losers.

It's nearly impossible for the to advance when the four biggest stocks by market value — Microsoft stock, Amazon stock, Apple and Google stock, along with No. 6 Facebook stock — are selling off fiercely.

Meanwhile, Coupa Software recouped much of Monday's 6.2% overnight after . Business software giant Salesforce.com plunged 4.2% Monday ahead of its Tuesday night earnings.

Dow Jones Futures Today

Dow Jones futures rose 0.55% vs. fair value. S&P 500 futures climbed 0.5%. Nasdaq 100 futures were up 0.5%.

One reason for the rally in stock futures? There's rumbling in Congress that it may oppose the Trump tariffs on Mexico. Many lawmakers say Trump must declare another national emergency to do impose tariffs on Mexico. That would Congress a chance to try block them, with many Senate GOP members opposed to the Mexico tariffs. Administration officials say he already has the statutory authority.

Australia's central bank cut rates to record low on Tuesday and signaled it could do more. Investors are betting on Fed rate cuts, though that sentiment didn't buoy stocks on Monday.

It's going to take a lot more than fractional gains in Dow futures to signal an end to the stock market correction.

Remember that overnight action in  and elsewhere doesn't necessarily translate into actual trading in the next regular session. Dow Jones futures signaled modest, shrinking losses heading into Monday's stock market open. While the major averages briefly traded positive near the open, selling in tech giants and software leaders quickly took hold.

Current Stock Market Correction

The major averages tumbled last month on the escalating China trade war, President Donald Trump's decision to impose tariffs on Mexico, and the potential fallout on the global economy. Big Tech antitrust fears gave the current stock market correction yet another reason to head lower.

The Nasdaq composite lost 1.6% to its worst levels since February, dragged down by Alphabet stock, Facebook stock and Amazon stock. The S&P 500 index fell 0.3%. The Dow Jones eked out a tiny gain, even with Apple stock and Microsoft stock falling.

That's despite St. Louis Fed President James Bullard signaling support for a Fed rate cut, following similar dovish comments from Fed Vice Chairman Richard Clarida last Thursday. A slew of Fed officials speak Tuesday, including Fed chief Jerome Powell.

Markets are , with two more by January.

While the prospect of Fed rate cuts are a positive, those would only occur if the stock market correction continues and economic data worsens, presumably amid an escalating China trade war and Mexican tariffs.

Big Tech Wreck

The Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission have divided up some Big Tech companies for antitrust review. will launch an antitrust probe of Google and will have oversight over Apple. The FTC likely will probe Facebook and will take the lead on Amazon antitrust issues.

Facebook stock plunged 7.5%, Google stock dropped 6.1%, and Amazon stock fell 4.6%. Facebook tested its 200-day line while Amazon stock undercut that key support. The for Google stock fell to its lowest since 2017.

Apple stock, which had been modestly higher until the DOJ antitrust probe news, retreated 1%.

Facebook edged lower early Tuesday, while Google, Amazon and Apple were up, less than Nasdaq futures.

Investors can no longer ignore the mounting regulatory and political risk for Big Tech. At best, they face years of stricter oversight. At worst, they face serious challenges to their business models.

Software Stocks Plunge

The software sector has been the top-performing market sector in 2019. The sector came under some pressure last month, but held up reasonably well during the stock market correction. Growth stocks usually fall more than the broader market in pullbacks, so software's performance was especially notable.

But on Monday, software stocks were big losers, with top-rated names leading the selling. Microsoft stock fell 3.1% after just closing above its 50-day line on Friday. ServiceNow stock fell 5.2%, Twilio lost 5.6%, and MongoDB shed 7%, all knifing below their 50-day lines. Adobe, which ended last week just below its 50-day, fell 4.4%.

The iShares Expanded Tech-Software Sector ETF fell 3.3%, hitting its lowest level since Feb. 8 and approaching its 200-day line.

Microsoft stock and several other software leaders were trading near record levels with RS lines at all-time highs. Monday's stock market action shows that some individual names, groups or sectors can look strong until they suddenly don't.

While the current stock market correction may not end up as painful as the late-2018 bear market, selling is fierce and there are few places to hide. Bottom line: Investors should not be making new buys and should be largely, if not entirely, in cash.

Among other , the Innovator IBD 50 ETF slid 1.8%, even with Kirkland Lake Gold breaking out. The VanEck Vectors Semiconductor ETF dipped 0.1% after a brutal May.

urn:contentItem:5X33-35C1-DYTD-9000-00000-00Dow Jones Futures: Stock Market Steady, Apple In Buy Range After Fed Rate Cut; Microsoft Sets Big Buyback2019-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:11ZLexisNexisSTOCK MARKET TODAYDow Jones Futures: Stock Market Steady, Apple In Buy Range After Fed Rate Cut; Microsoft Sets Big BuybackED CARSON

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/stock-bull-night-03-adobe.jpg

Dow Jones futures fell modestly early Thursday, along with S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq futures. The stock market rally had a volatile day to nowhere. The Federal Reserve cut rates but gave no clear signs for further Fed rate cuts. Stocks fell, but erased losses after Fed chief Jerome Powell signaled flexibility, while Apple stock reclaimed a buy point. After the close, Microsoft announced a big buyback and dividend hike.

Meanwhile, office furniture maker Herman Miller reported earnings and U.S. Steel preannounced. AT&T reportedly is mulling divesting its DirecTV unit. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is meeting with lawmakers this week.

Microsoft stock moved closer to a buy point in late trade, while Herman Miller stock signaled a breakout. AT&T stock rose. U.S. Steel stock tumbled. Facebook stock was active but not moving much.

Dow Jones Futures Today

Dow Jones futures were 0.2% below fair value. S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq 100 futures fell 0.2% as well. Microsoft stock — like Apple — is a member of the Dow Jones, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite.

Remember that overnight action in  and elsewhere doesn't necessarily translate into actual trading in the next regular session. Dow Jones futures have been volatile over the past several weeks.

Crude oil futures rose 2%.

Current Stock Market Rally

The current stock market rally continued to close with modest moves amid big headlines. The Fed meeting concluded with an expected Fed rate cut. But policymakers indicated they see no further Fed rate cuts through 2021. Stocks fell to session lows on that.

But Fed chief Jerome Powell, in his post-Fed meeting press conference, stressed that policymakers have adjusted Fed rate policy several times this year as conditions changed. He suggested that the .

The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed up 0.1% while the S&P 500 index was just above break-even. The Nasdaq composite, down more than 1% intraday, finished off 0.1%.

Apple stock climbed 0.9% to 222.27, back above a 221.47 buy point. Apple stock, at $1.06 trillion, is one of only two members of the $1 trillion club; the other is fellow Dow tech titan Microsoft stock. The for Apple stock is just below its recent 2019 high. Apple stock is on .

The  is within 1% of its all-time high. So is the S&P 500 index. The Nasdaq is 2% below its peak.

Among the , the Innovator IBD 50 ETF was unchanged. The iShares Expanded Tech-Software Sector ETF fell 0.4%. The VanEck Vectors Semiconductor ETF edged up 0.1%.

Microsoft Stock Buyback

Microsoft said it will buy back $40 billion worth of MSFT stock. It'll also hike its quarterly dividend by 11% to 51 cents per share.

Microsoft stock rose 1.3% to 140.31 early Thursday. Shares rose 0.8% on Wednesday to 138.52, after once again testing the 50-day moving average intraday. Microsoft stock is working on a 141.77 flat-base .

While $40 billion is a lot of money, that's slightly less than 4% of Microsoft's $1.058 trillion market cap.

Herman Miller Earnings

Herman Miller earnings rose 22% to 84 cents a share in its fiscal Q1. Revenue climbed 7% to $670.4 million. Analysts expected Herman Miller earnings of 79 cents a share on sales of $662 million.

The furniture maker sees Q2 EPS of 85 to 89 cents on revenue of $685 million to $700 million. Wall Street had forecast Herman Miller earnings of 88 cents a share, but only $685 million in revenue.

Herman Miller stock rose 9% to 48.41 before the open, signaling a move above a 46.39 buy point from a shallow . Shares closed down 6 cents at 44.47.

The RS line for Herman Miller stock has been holding near its best levels since late 2016, but it's trending lower since 2007.

Herman Miller stock has an excellent of 96 out of 99.

U.S. Steel Earnings Warning

U.S. Steel sees an adjusted Q3 loss of 35 cents a share vs. views for a 7-cent loss. The steel giant also expects to cut 2,500 jobs. Rivals Nucor and Steel Dynamics guided low earlier this week.

U.S. Steel stock tumbled 11% early Thursday. Shares fell 3.9% to 12.45 on Wednesday. U.S. Steel stock has been largely tracking its falling 50-day line since March 2018. It hit a three-year low of 10.16 on Aug. 28.

AT&T To Sell DirecTV?

The telecom and media giant is mulling divesting DirecTV, the satellite TV business acquired for $49 billion in 2015, the after the close. That could include a spinoff or a merger with Dish Network. DirecTV subscriber losses have grown as views shift to streaming services.

AT&T stock rose 0.9% premarket. Shares fell 1.1% to 36.76 on Wednesday. AT&T stock hit a 17-month high of 38.75 last week after Elliot Management took a big stake, signaling criticism of the company's Time Warner and other acquisitions.

Facebook's Zuckerberg Goes To Washington

Facebook said CEO Mark Zuckerberg is meeting with U.S. lawmakers Wednesday night and Thursday to "talk about future internet regulation." Zuckerberg also is expected to meet with Trump administration officials. No public events are planned.

The Justice Department is reviewing Big Tech companies' dominance of online platforms, while other federal regulators, states and Congress also are conducting probes. Elizabeth Warren, a rising contender for the Democratic presidential election, favors breaking up Big Tech companies.

Facebook stock were a fraction lower before the open. Shares edged up 6 cents at 188.14 on Wedneday. Facebook stock is in a consolidation, but is stuck below its 50-day line.

urn:contentItem:5WGN-B0H1-JCBB-K3J8-00000-00Dow Jones Futures Turn Lower Ahead Of Jobs Report; Apple, FANGs Near Buy Points2019-07-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisSTOCK MARKET TODAYDow Jones Futures Turn Lower Ahead Of Jobs Report; Apple, FANGs Near Buy PointsED CARSON

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Stock-Fireworks-89-shutt.jpg

Dow Jones futures fell slightly Friday morning, ahead of the June jobs report. S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq futures also were lower. The stock market rally powered ahead Wednesday, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 index setting all-time highs and the Nasdaq composite nearly there. Apple stock is approaching a buy point. So are FANG internet giants Facebook stock, Amazon stock, Netflix stock, while Google stock is trying to bounce back.

Iif and when Apple and FANG stocks such as Facebook, Amazon.com and Netflix break out, which will be stock market rally winners? Sure these stocks, along with Google parent Alphabet, have had enormous runs, but investors should focus on the best stocks today, not past legends. Using the is a good way to determine whether these tech titans, or any other stock, is a leader, laggard, or just tagging along.

Dow Jones Futures Today

Dow Jones futures fell  0.1% vs. fair value. S&P 500 futures dipped 0.15%. Nasdaq 100 futures retreated 0.15%. Remember that overnight action in  and elsewhere doesn't necessarily translate into actual trading in the next regular session.

Dow Jones futures traded normally on the Fourth of July even as U.S. stock markets were closed. Asian markets were mixed Friday for a second straight session. European markets were slightly lower.

Jobs Report Key For Rate Cuts

Meanwhile,  due out at 8:30 a.m. ET will go a long way toward figuring out if a July 31 Fed rate cut will be a quarter point or 50 basis points.

Wall Street estimates the U.S. added 165,000 jobs, with the jobless rate holding at 3.6% and hourly wages picking up to a 3.2% gain.

Markets expect a Fed rate cut on July 31, with a 30% chance that it'll be 50 basis points. There's a 75% chance that policymakers will cut Fed rates by a total of 50 basis points by the September meeting.

Next week's testimony by Fed chief Jerome Powell and minutes from the June policy meeting also will be key

Current Stock Market Rally

The current stock market rally powered to all-time highs for the S&P 500 index and Dow Jones on Wednesday. The Nasdaq composite is less than 0.1% below record highs.

Nasdaq 100 futures, which include Apple stock and all the FANG stocks, suggest that the Nasdaq composite will set an all-time best on Friday.

Among the , the Innovator IBD 50 ETF climbed 0.8% on Wednesday, hitting its best close since Oct. 8. The iShares Expanded Tech-Software Sector ETF rallied 1.1%, hitting a record high. The VanEck Vectors Semiconductor ETF dipped 0.4%.

Facebook Stock

Facebook stock rose 1.1% Wednesday to 197.20. That's just below a 198.58 buy point from a long, deep base. The cup depth of 44% is worrisome. However, the handle itself is long enough to be its own base. By that measure, Facebook stock does not have an unhealthy drop.

The relative strength line for Facebook stock has trended higher since late November. It's just below its handle high, a bullish sign. The RS line, the blue line in the charts below, reflects a stock's performance vs. the S&P 500 index.

Facebook earnings are expected to fall 7% in 2019. But analysts see EPS growth rebounding to a robust 32% in 2020.

One worry for Facebook and Google, and to a lesser extent Apple and Amazon, is the growing push by regulators and politicians to crack down on Big Tech. While Facebook stock and Google stock plunged on antitrust probe fears on June 3, helping to set the recent stock market low, investors haven't been too concerned so far about threats to Big Tech business models.

Amazon Stock

Amazon stock edged up 0.2% to 1,939 on Wednesday. That's just below a 1,964.50 cup-with-handle entry. As with Facebook stock, Amazon's handle is long enough to be its own base.

The RS line for Amazon stock is not far from the handle high, though it hasn't really made much progress in recent weeks.

Amazon earnings are expected to grow 36% in 2019 and 40% in 2020, a rapid pace for a such a large company. Credit Amazon Web Services, the cloud-computing arm. But core e-commerce sales growth has been struggling, with overall sales growth decelerating for the past four quarters.

Netflix Stock

Netflix stock popped 1.7% to 381.72 on Wednesday. Shares are close to a 386.09 buy point. The RS line has moved higher in the past few weeks, but it's been trending slightly lower since mid-January.

Part of that may reflect concern about competition from the upcoming Disney+ streaming service. Walt Disney has soared since unveiling its streaming plans in early April. On Wednesday, Disney stock reclaimed a buy point.

Still, analysts expect adjusted Netflix earnings to rise 28% in 2019 and 72% in 2020.

Apple Stock

Apple stock advanced 0.8% to 204.41. is working toward a 215.41 cup-with-handle buy point, but a little further away than Facebook or Amazon stock. Like those two FANGs, Apple's handle is long enough to be its own base.

The RS line has improved somewhat in the past few weeks, but is still some distance from handle highs.

Apple earnings are expected to fall 4% in the current fiscal year and then rebound, somewhat, to 10% growth in fiscal 2020. Meanwhile, Apple stock and earnings are exposed to the China trade war. If trade talks fall apart, Apple could be a notable loser.

Google Stock

Google stock is the clear laggard in this group. Shares rose 0.9% to 1,122.99 on Wednesday. That's just below the 200-day line with the 50-day line the next hurdle.

While technically in a consolidation, Google stock is still off a potential buy point of 1,297.07. Ironically, Google stock is the only one of these five tech titans that actually hit a record high in 2019, doing so on April 29. But a weak Google earnings report sent shares plunging the next day and beyond.

The RS line is just above June's two-year low. More broadly, Google stock hasn't really outperformed the market for the past three years.

Google earnings are expected to rise just 1% in 2019 but rebound 18% in 2020.

Stock Market Rally Outlook

On a technical basis, investors want to see the stock market rally convincingly clear old highs. But it's still a news-driven market rally.

Renewed China trade talks and expectations of multiple Fed rate cuts have recharged the stock market rally from a June 3 low. It's still unclear if China trade talks will lead to a comprehensive deal. If not, then the China trade war could escalate again in a few months.

Dow Jones, Nasdaq 100, CAC 40, DAX 30 Forecast:The Dow Jones bounced between fundamental drivers last week as trade wars and monetary policy fought for center stage in front of investors Meanwhile, theNasdaq ,DAX 30andCAC 40will look closely to developments from the G-7 Summit Interested in equity markets?Sign up for the Weekly Stock Market Outlook Webinar. Dow Jones, Nasdaq 100,CAC 40, DAX 30 Fundamental ForecastsFriday saw the major equity markets undergo a vicious sell-off as investors fled risk assets amid a deteriorating US-China trade relationship. While many expected Fed Chairman Jerome Powell to strike a dovish tone during his Jackson Hole speech,which he arguably did , President Trump was quick to express his distaste for the pace of expected cuts.

Interested in longer-term trades? Check out our Q3 Forecasts for equities, Gold, oil and more. Shortly thereafter, President Trump announced that the 25% tariff tranche facing China will be increased to 30% on October 1 and the 10% tax scheduled for September 1 will jump to 15% in response to China's retaliatory tariffs totaling $75 billion on US goods that they issued early Friday morning. Together, the fast-paced hikes confirm the economic conflict is more than a mere skirmish. Since President Trump's tariff hike was released to markets after the close, the resultant price action will unfold on Monday. With such a steep escalation, expect risk aversion to grip markets. Meanwhile, uncertainty could ignite further during the G-7 Summit over the weekend. Dow Jones ForecastOutlook: BearishThat said, theDJIAwill have to negotiate the fallout from the US-China trade war flare-up. Given the lack ofscheduled speechesby Fed members, the Industrial Average - and theS P 500- will have to cope with the underlying issues facing the market without the tailwind of persistent dovish commentary. Further, futures suggest investors are nearly certain a 25-basis point cut is coming at the SeptemberFOMCmeeting. Regardless, the Dow Jones may look to threaten key technical supportthat I outlined on Friday. Dow Jones Price Chart: Daily Time Frame (February 2018 - August 2019) (Chart 1) Nasdaq 100 ForecastOutlook: BearishThe Nasdaq will have to cope with similar themes, while also enduring elevated uncertainty over the weekend from the G-7 Summit where French President Macron is expected to meet with President Trump. President Macron has recently discussed a possible tax on US-tech companies which, if pursued, would likely spur retaliation from the Trump administration. Nasdaq 100 Price Chart: Daily Time Frame (March - August) (Chart 2) Coupled with the looming threat of domestic regulation, the big-tech companies that are responsible for large swathes of growth in the current bull market face uncertain times. Consequently, the Nasdaq finds itself in a very precarious position moving forward. CAC 40 ForecastOutlook: NeutralLike the Nasdaq, the CAC 40 will look closely to discussions between the various French and US officials. According to Bloomberg, US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin will meet with France's Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire on the sidelines of the G-7 Summit. Should the officials fail to agree on terms to avoid the new taxes, retaliation should be expected - a potentially devastating development for the CAC 40. Since trade spats have become more common between the United States and France - along with the entirety of the European Union - a potential option for retaliatory tariffs is automobiles. CAC 40 Price Chart: Daily Time Frame (December 2018 - August 2019) (Chart 3) DAX 30 ForecastOutlook: Neutral With that in mind, we turn our attention to the German DAX, which would have the most to lose if the Trump administration decided to impose widespread auto tariffs instead of targeting France specifically. At present, there is nothing to suggest auto tariffs will be the weapon of choice - if a weapon is needed at all. Regardless, the Administration has until November 14 to decide whether to impose the auto levies, which leaves the option on the table. DAX 30 Price Chart: 4 - Hour Time Frame (May - August) (Chart 4) Apart from the fluid fundamental themes over the weekend, next week ispacked with important economic dataranging from German unemployment numbers to US GDP to Chinese manufacturing data. While officials trudge through trade negotiations and monetary policy discussions, markets will look to the hard data for influence - between the various Tweets and talks that will inevitably unfold in the week ahead. urn:contentItem:5V37-M0V1-JD3Y-Y2X4-00000-00-DOW JONES-Regaining Trust Is the No. 1 Issue for Tech in 20192018-12-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexis-DOW JONES-Regaining Trust Is the No. 1 Issue for Tech in 2019

As the tech industry looks back on a difficult 2018 and warily approaches the year to come, one word is increasingly on the lips of Silicon Valley executives: 'Trust is the No. 1 thing you sell,' Jeff Lawson, chief executive of Twilio, told Barron's.



With consumers, legislators, and investors more skeptical of tech than they've been in years, trust could well be an intangible factor next year in how companies compete, recruit new customers, and retain talent. A new Democratic majority in the House of Representatives could also change the regulatory equation in 2019.

'As corporate leaders, we have a responsibility to employees, customers, and society,' Twilio's (ticker: TWLO) Lawson said from the cloud-communications platform company's San Francisco headquarters this month. 'We're a company that determines who we do business with. If the Klan, for instance, tried to use our service to plan an event, we wouldn't allow it.'

Social-media companies spent most of 2018 trying to find a balance between free speech, safety, and running a sticky platform.

Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg initially defended users' right to deny the Holocaust before backtracking. And Apple (AAPL), Spotify Technology (SPOT), Facebook (FB), Twitter (TWTR), and Alphabet 's (GOOGL) YouTube all struggled with how to respond to hate-mongering from Alex Jones and his InfoWars site. Most of these platforms eventually banned Jones, though Twitter decided to hold out for a while, putting the company in the unusual position of defending hate speech. Twilio notes that Jones was never a customer.

Lawson reset Twilio's policy on hate speech after the violent white nationalist rally in Charlottesville, Va., in August 2017. Twilio does not allow any group whose mission or purpose is 'hateful' on its platform, regardless of their activity.

One could argue that Twilio's direct approach helped propel the stock 270% in 2018, even as the Nasdaq Composite fell 4.4%. Twilio's cloud platform is used by companies like Nordstrom (JWN) and U-Haul parent Amerco (UHAL) to engage digitally with costumers.

Salesforce co-CEO Keith Block used the word 'trust' 18 times in a recent 45-minute interview. 'In our business model, everything starts with trust,' Block said. Salesforce.com (CRM) shares are up 32% in 2018.

If there's a deficit of trust these days, Big Tech has itself to blame. Well before the market's late-year selloff, shares of Facebook and Twitter were pummeled for their roles in the 2016 presidential election, the spread of 'fake news,' and their perceived anticonservative bias. Google has also faced questions about its perceived anticonservative bias.

Earlier this year, Barron's argued that a new divide had emerged in tech, with ad-driven giants like Facebook and Google on one side and direct-to-consumer sales models like Apple and Netflix on the other. The ad-dependent, and thus data-driven, names were the ones struggling the most with trust.

Several of Silicon Valley's most-successful chief executives, led by Apple CEO Tim Cook, were critical of how Facebook and Google share consumer data in an almost Faustian bargain with business partners and advertisers. Facebook shares, which peaked at $ 218.62 in late July, closed at $ 134.56 on Thursday-a drop of 38%. Twitter, which reached $ 47.79 in early July, closed at $ 28.68 on Thursday, down 40%.

But even Apple has now been drawn into the privacy debate, in the case over its business dealings in China. And its stock has struggled mightily in the last quarter of the year.

Cook has insisted that Apple has not compromised user privacy in China, despite criticism that its decision to host Chinese users' iCloud accounts in a new data center within the country would give Chinese authorities easier access to text messages, email, and other data.

Investors, and Barron's, continue to debate the importance of trust when it comes to stock prices. In some cases, users have yet to show much concern. Facebook's still massive user base is one example-at last count, Facebook had 2.27 billion active monthly users.

But Silicon Valley executives have other worries, namely keeping talent. Employers are acutely aware that highly-skilled tech workers, already in great demand, have more leverage and feel unencumbered criticizing their bosses. Google employees took umbrage at the company's secret plan to build a censored search engine in China (Google has no plans to relaunch the search engine, CEO Sundar Pichai told a congressional panel on Tuesday, amid increased scrutiny of big tech firms). And Facebook lost the co-founders of Instagram and WhatsApp, which Facebook shelled out some $ 20 billion to buy, earlier this year. They were unhappy with Facebook's direction and left money on the table to make their point.

EDITORS' CHOICE

Working More Magic at Disney

Investors Might Be Paying Too Much for These Index Funds

Vanguard Founder Jack Bogle Says It's Time to Play It Safe

'We're in an era of the empowered tech employee,' Brian Halligan, CEO and co-founder of HubSpot, an inbound marketing and sales software company, said over coffee in San Francisco's financial district recently. 'They expect more from their employers than financial compensation and the products they create. They want a place of good standing in society.'

Mindful of what can happen to a high-profile public company that loses the trust of the public and its workforce, a batch of initial public-offering candidates have adopted greater due diligence, says David Larcker, director of the Corporate Governance Research Initiative at Stanford's Graduate School of Business.

If there's hope for change in 2019, it could come from those new public companies that have the chance to reset the notion of a 21st century tech company. Uber, Lyft, and Slack Technologies are reportedly finishing up their IPO paperwork. Their executives, lawyers, and investors would do well to put trust at their very top of their priority list.

urn:contentItem:5X62-NR01-JCBB-K014-00000-00Dow Jones Today Breaks Support; Last Stand For Stock Market Rally?2019-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisSTOCK MARKET TODAYDow Jones Today Breaks Support; Last Stand For Stock Market Rally?ED CARSON

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/stock-bear-wave-04-adobe.jpg

The Dow Jones today opened sharply lower Wednesday, knifing through its 50-day moving average, as recession risks rise. On Tuesday, the S&P 500 index joined the Nasdaq composite below that key support.

Dow Jones stock Apple fell below its buy point as breakouts struggle. FANG giant Facebook tested support amid Facebook Libra woes. TD Ameritrade joined Charles Schwab in eliminating stock and ETF trading fees. TD Ameritrade stock kept falling, along with other online brokers. Homebuilder Lennar popped on a surprise earnings gain.

The stock market rally has come under heavy pressure as Tuesday's grim U.S. manufacturing report, along with weak reports around the world, heighten recession risks. On top of that, investors must deal with uncertainty from China trade talks, an impeachment inquiry confronting President Donald Trump, increasingly violent Hong Kong unrest, and no-deal Brexit risks.

Dow Jones Today

In morning trade, the Dow Jones fell 1.25%. The S&P 500 retreated 1.3%. The Nasdaq composite sank 1.4%, moving closer to its 200-day moving average than its 50-day.

Asian markets fell Wednesday, with China's Shanghai Composite still closed for several more days. European markets sold off hard.

The ADP Employment report showed private hiring slowed to 135,000 in September, in the range of various estimates. August hiring was revised down by 38,000 to 157,000. The official jobs report is due Friday morning.

Remember that overnight action in  and elsewhere doesn't necessarily translate into actual trading in the next regular session. Tuesday's Dow Jones futures foreshadowed a positive open, but didn't provide any insight into the day's sharp reversal lower.

Apple Stock Struggles To Hold On

Apple stock fell 1.5% to 221.18, just below its 221.47 buy point. The iPhone maker reclaimed that entry on Monday. On Tuesday, Apple stock hit a 2019 high intraday and came close to its all-time high of 233.47 set on Oct. 3, 2018. Shares eventually eked out a gain, closing up 0.3% to 224.59, providing some support for the Dow Jones, S&P 500 and Nasdaq. The for Apple stock hit an 11-month high.

But with bears mauling the stock market rally, other breakouts have faltered. Can Apple stock hold on? Remember that Apple stock looked strong at the start of the late 2018 stock market correction, until suddenly it didn't.

TD Ameritrade Joins No-Fee Stock Trading

TD Ameritrade stock sank 1.1% in volatile morning trade after tumbling 26% to a three-year low on Tuesday. Late Tuesday, bowing to the inevitable, as of Oct. 3, down from $6.95 now. Options trades will no longer have the $6.95 fee but will still pay 65 cents per contract.

Ameritrade stock plunged Tuesday after Charles Schwab moved to zero-fee stock trading. That came a few days after Interactive Brokers announced a zero-fee IBKR Lite service, while its existing low-fee service would be renamed IBKR Pro.

Charles Schwab stock fell 2% early Wednesday after tumbling almost 10% on Tuesday. E-Trade Financial, which for now still has $6.95 stock and ETF trades, fell 1.6% after selling off 16% Tuesday. Interactive Brokers stock also extended losses.

TD Ameritrade stock and other online broker stocks have struggled the past few years as lower stock trading fees took their toll on profits.

The zero-fee Robinhood app has attracted many younger investors in recent years. With Schwab, Ameritrade and other established players adopting zero-fee stock trading, that could hit Robinhood growth and its hoped-for IPO.

Lennar Earnings Surprise

Homebuilder before the open, with per-share earnings up 14% and revenue up 3%, both beating analyst estimates. Lennar stock rose 1.5%. Lennar stock already was slightly extended from a buy point.

Homebuilders like Lennar are benefiting from low mortgage rates and a generally strong U.S. consumer, still insulated from global economic woes.

Facebook Stock, Facebook Libra Falter

In morning action, Facebook stock fell 0.5%, dipping below its 200-day. Facebook stock closed Tuesday just above its 200-day line, an area of support on multiple occasions since late January.

Payment companies that were founding members of the Facebook Libra Association are having second thoughts, according to multiple reports, raising doubts about the stability of the proposed stablecoin. Visa, Mastercard, PayPal and Stripe are worried about angering U.S. and European regulators and politicians that have expressed skepticism or opposition regarding Facebook Libra.

More broadly, Facebook faces threats from regulators and politicians to rein in or break up the social giant. On Tuesday, leaked audio revealed Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg vowing to fight Big Tech breakup proposals, including from rising Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren.

Current Stock Market Rally

The  is still not that far from all-time highs. But the stock market rally is showing severe stress in recent days. The Nasdaq composite actually moved back above its 50-day line Tuesday morning, only to come tumbling back after the ISM manufacturing index. For the S&P 500 index to undercut that key support level on the same day was telling.

This could be the last stand for the stock market rally. If the Dow Jones today closes below its 50-day line, it could mark the start of a stock market correction. If the Dow industrials and perhaps the S&P 500 could close above that key level, it would be a positive sign.

It's a news-driven market. A sudden positive headline or Trump tweet could revive the stock market rally. But negative news could send bulls fleeing.

Please follow Ed Carson on Twitter at  for stock market updates and more.

urn:contentItem:60G8-JB31-JBCM-F00F-00000-00Dow Jumps 150 Points After Federal Reserve Leaves Rates Unchanged Near Zero2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:11ZLexisNexisDow Jumps 150 Points After Federal Reserve Leaves Rates Unchanged Near ZeroSergei KlebnikovForbes Staff

Investors also continued to digest second quarter earnings.

TOPLINE

The market finished higher on Wednesday as investors cheered the Federal Reserve s decision to keep interest rates near zero and shares of Big Tech stocks rallied.

<figure class="embed-base image-embed embed-5">

<figcaption>

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell at a House testimony last month.

Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images

</figcaption> </figure>

KEY FACTS

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.6%, over 150 points, on Wednesday, while the S&P 500 rose 1.3% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite gained 1.4%.

The Federal Reserve, which concluded its two-day policy meeting on Wednesday, kept interest rates unchanged at near zero to continue to support the economy through the coronavirus pandemic.

The CEOs of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google-parent Alphabet testified before the House Antitrust Subcommittee, which gave investors some insight into how Big Tech companies are handling challenges from regulators. 

Shares of all four companies rose more than 1% following the hearings, but while they re among the best-performing stocks so far this year, there are rising concerns on Wall Street thatheavy market concentrationin Big Tech giants could pose downside risks.

The busiest week of the second quarter earnings season continued, with shares of General Electric, Advanced Micro Devices, General Motors and Shopify all rising after the companies reported better-than-expected results.

Boeing and Starbucks, meanwhile, posted wider-than-expected losses last quarter, but both stocks traded higher heading into the market open.

crucial quote

The pace of the recovery may have slowed in recent months as virus cases have surged across the country and the Fed appears to be in no hurry to change the status quo, says Charlie Ripley, senior investment strategist for Allianz Investment Management. Ultimately, the Fed does not intend to upset the applecart until some certainty and clarity can be instilled in the economic outlook as progress is made towards price stability and full employment.

What to watch for

Investors also continued to assess the latest coronavirus relief bill unveiled by Senate Republicans late on Monday, titled the Heath, Economic Assistance, Liability Protection and Schools (HEALS) Act. The GOP proposal for the next round of federal coronavirus aidincludesa second round of $1,200 stimulus checks and more funds for small business loans in the Paycheck Protection Program. The bill would alsoeliminatethe $600-per-week federal unemployment supplement, which expires this week, to be replaced with a 70% wage-replacement program. State labor departments are scrambling to figure out how their systems would handle the payments, however: Kentuckysaysit will take 45 days to build a program and another three weeks to test it and then finally begin making payments.

Key background

The Federal Reserve wrapped up its two-day policy meeting on Wednesday, saying that U.S. economic activity and employment have picked up somewhat in recent months but remain well below their levels at the beginning of the year. The last time Fed officials met in June, they decided to maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at 0% to 0.25%. On Tuesday, the central bank announced that it would extend loan programs through the end of 2020 as it continues to support the U.S. economy amid the pandemic.

TOPLINE The market finished higher on Wednesday as investors cheered the Federal Reserve’s decision to keep interest rates near zero and shares of Big Tech stocks rallied. KEY FACTS The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.6%, over 150 points, on Wednesda...

TOPLINE The market finished higher on Wednesday as investors cheered the Federal Reserve’s decision to keep interest rates near zero and shares of Big Tech stocks rallied. KEY FACTS The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.6%, over 150 points, on Wednesday, while the S&P 500 rose 1.3% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite gained 1.4%. The Federal Reserve, which concluded its two-day policy meeting on Wednesday, kept interest rates unchanged at near zero to continue to support the economy through the coronavirus pandemic. The CEOs of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google-parent Alphabet testified before the House Antitrust Subcommittee, which gave investors some insight into how Big Tech companies are handling challenges from regulators. Shares of all four companies rose following the hearings, but while they’re among the best-performing stocks so far this year, there are rising concerns on Wall Street that heavy market concentration in a small handful of Big Tech names could pose downside risks. The busiest week of the second quarter earnings season continued, with shares of General Electric, Advanced Micro Devices, General Motors and Shopify all rising after the companies reported better-than-expected results. Boeing and Starbucks, meanwhile, posted wider-than-expected losses last quarter, but both stocks traded higher heading into the market open. crucial quote “The pace of the recovery may have slowed in recent months as virus cases have surged across the country and the Fed appears to be in no hurry to change the status quo,” says Charlie Ripley, senior investment strategist for Allianz Investment Management. “Ultimately, the Fed does not intend to upset the applecart until some certainty and clarity can be instilled in the economic outlook as progress is made towards price stability and full employment.” Key background Investors also continued to assess the latest coronavirus relief bill unveiled by Senate Republicans late on Monday, titled the Heath, Economic Assistance, Liability Protection and Schools (HEALS) Act. The GOP proposal for the next round of federal coronavirus aid includes a second round of $1,200 stimulus checks and more funds for small business loans in the Paycheck Protection Program. The bill would also eliminate the $600-per-week federal unemployment supplement, which states stopped paying out this week, to be replaced with a 70% wage-replacement program. Tangent The Federal Reserve wrapped up its two-day policy meeting on Wednesday, saying that U.S. economic activity and employment “have picked up somewhat in recent months but remain well below their levels at the beginning of the year.” The last time Fed officials met in June, they decided to maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at 0% to 0.25%. On Tuesday, the central bank announced that it would extend loan programs through the end of 2020 as it continues to support the U.S. economy amid the pandemic. urn:contentItem:60JV-68J1-DXVP-500F-00000-00Dow Jumps 350 Points After Trump Signs Executive Orders To Extend Coronavirus Relief2020-08-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisDow Jumps 350 Points After Trump Signs Executive Orders To Extend Coronavirus ReliefSergei KlebnikovForbes Staff

The S&P is now just over 1% away from setting a new record high.

TOPLINE

The stock market finished higher on Monday, as coronavirus stimulus talks remained deadlocked and President Trump signed several executive orders over the weekend to extend economic relief to Americans amid the pandemic.

<figure class="embed-base image-embed embed-1">

<figcaption>

The market has had a strong start to August so far.

Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images

</figcaption> </figure>

KEY FACTS

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 1.3%, over 350 points, on Monday, while the S&P 500 rose 0.3% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite lost 0.4%.

Boeing and Nike were among the best-performers in the Dow, while transportation stocks also surged. Shares of Big Tech companies like Microsoft, Netflix and Facebook led the market s declines, dragging the Nasdaq lower.

Shares of airlinessoaredafter federal data showed air travel returning to its highest level in nearly five months: American, Delta and United Airlines all jumped by between 7% and 10%.

After coronavirus stimulus talks between Democrats, Republicans and the White House ended in a stalemate last week, President Trump on Saturday signed several executive orders to extend economic relief programs.

The orders would expand federal unemployment benefits at a reduced rate of $400 per week, defer student loan payments through 2020, extend a federal moratorium on evictions and provide a payroll tax holiday.

Trump s executive action was met with criticism from both parties and is likely to face legal challenges, since continuing the programs would require federal funding from Congress.

Meanwhile, Twitter became the latest company toshow interest in buyingChinese-owned social media app TikTok, although Microsoft is still seen as the most likely candidate to close a deal. 

Shares of Eastman Kodak, on the other hand,plunged by up to 43%on Monday amid news that the company s $765 million federal loan will be put on hold as regulators look into allegations of wrongdoing.

What to watch for

Market sentiment also took a hit from ongoing U.S.-China tensions, which have continued to deteriorate in recent weeks over a range of issues including Hong Kong, technology companies and the coronavirus pandemic. Following afresh round of U.S. sanctionson Chinese officials including Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam last week, China on Mondayimposed sanctionson 11 U.S. citizens, including Sens. Ted Cruz (R-Tex.), Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), Tom Cotton (R-Ark.), Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) and Pat Toomey (R-Pa.).

Crucial quote

Trump s executive orders dominated the weekend news, but these should be considered a political gesture aimed at creating the illusion of action for November rather than a genuine attempt to bolster the economy, says Vital Knowledge founder Adam Crisafulli. It still seems that a negotiated deal on formal fiscal legislation remains more likely than not, and it wouldn t be surprising to see the two sides resume negotiations in the coming days.

Surprising fact

So far, 448 companies in the S&P 500 have reported second quarter earnings, with nearly 82% beating Wall Street expectations the highest rate on record dating back to 1994, according to Refinitiv data. Just over 16% of companies so far have missed expectations.

Key background

Stocks posted strong gains last week to kick off the month of August, with the Dow climbing 3.8%, its biggest weekly gain since June. The S&P moved 2.5% higher, now sitting just over 1% below its record high set back in February. The market s gains were also in large part boosted by continued strength in Big Tech stocks: Shares of Facebook, Apple and Microsoft rallied more than 3% last week.

TOPLINE The stock market finished higher on Monday, as coronavirus stimulus talks remained deadlocked and President Trump signed several executive orders over the weekend to extend economic relief to Americans amid the pandemic. KEY FACTS The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 1.3%, over 350 points, on Monday, while the S&P 500 rose 0.3% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite lost 0.4%. Boeing and Nike were among the best-performers in the Dow, while transportation stocks also surged. Shares of Big Tech companies like Microsoft, Netflix and Facebook led the market’s declines, dragging the Nasdaq lower. Shares of airlines soared after federal data showed air travel returning to its highest level in nearly five months: American, Delta and United Airlines all jumped by between 7% and 10%. After coronavirus stimulus talks between Democrats, Republicans and the White House ended in a stalemate last week, President Trump on Saturday signed several executive orders to extend economic relief programs. The orders would expand federal unemployment benefits—at a reduced rate of $400 per week, defer student loan payments through 2020, extend a federal moratorium on evictions and provide a payroll tax holiday. Trump’s executive action was met with criticism from both parties and is likely to face legal challenges, since continuing the programs would require federal funding from Congress. Meanwhile, Twitter became the latest company to show interest in buying Chinese-owned social media app TikTok, although Microsoft is still seen as the most likely candidate to close a deal. Shares of Eastman Kodak, on the other hand, plunged by up to 43% on Monday amid news that the company’s $765 million federal loan will be put on hold as regulators look into allegations of wrongdoing. What to watch for Market sentiment also took a hit from ongoing U.S.-China tensions, which have continued to deteriorate in recent weeks over a range of issues including Hong Kong, technology companies and the coronavirus pandemic. Following a fresh round of U.S. sanctions on Chinese officials—including Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam—last week, China on Monday imposed sanctions on 11 U.S. citizens, including Sens. Ted Cruz (R-Tex.), Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), Tom Cotton (R-Ark.), Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) and Pat Toomey (R-Pa.). Crucial quote “Trump’s executive orders dominated the weekend news, but these should be considered a political gesture aimed at creating the illusion of action for November rather than a genuine attempt to bolster the economy,” says Vital Knowledge founder Adam Crisafulli. “It still seems that a negotiated deal on formal fiscal legislation remains more likely than not, and it wouldn’t be surprising to see the two sides resume negotiations in the coming days.” Key background Stocks posted strong gains last week to kick off the month of August, with the Dow climbing 3.8%, its biggest weekly gain since June. The S&P moved 2.5% higher, now sitting just over 1% below its record high set back in February. The market’s gains were also in large part boosted by continued strength in Big Tech stocks: Shares of Facebook, Apple and Microsoft rallied more than 3% last week. urn:contentItem:4945-41C0-009B-G146-00000-00Dow Loses 52.17, Closes at 1,0427.67; Nasdaq Down 17.44, Finishes at 1,851.392002-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS MONEYLINE 18:00Michelle Ivy, William Parsons, Susan Bell, Todd Eberhard, Peter BartBusinessSHOW032200CN.V19Dow Loses 52.17, Closes at 1,0427.67; Nasdaq Down 17.44, Finishes at 1,851.39Jan Hopkins, Allan Chernoff, Andrea Koppel, Major Garrett, Ceci Rodgers, Christine Romans, Greg Clarkin, Tim O'Brien, Fred Katayama, Casey Wian, Wolf Blitzer

The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 52.17 points today, closing at 1,0427.67. The Nasdaq was down 17.44, finishing the session at 1,851.39.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

JAN HOPKINS, GUEST HOST: Tonight: Andersen fights for its survival. The company continues to hemorrhage clients. Its overseas units are defecting, and the company still faces criminal charges. Several Andersen employees join us with their thoughts on the future of Andersen.

Being down doesn't mean being out. Iridium planned a universal phone system which failed, and so did the company. But now Iridium is back from the brink. We'll tell you what turned it around.

And for the first time in four decades, the Academy Awards are back in Hollywood. We'll tell you how the city is pinning its rebirth hopes on the Oscars. And "Variety" editor Peter Bart looks at this weekend's possible winners.

ANNOUNCER: This is LOU DOBBS MONEYLINE for Friday, March 22. Sitting in for Lou Dobbs, Jan Hopkins.

HOPKINS: Good evening. An emergency rescue package is in the works tonight for Andersen. Former Fed chairman Paul Volcker, hired to overhaul the firm, has outlined a series of steps to save the company. But time is quickly running out. Andersen's world-wide empire is crumbling. More overseas partners today defected and more clients deserted the firm. Andersen's new Zealand affiliate is the latest to break ranks. It's joining forces with a rival. And in an ironic twist today, Waste Management, which was embroiled in its own Andersen-related accounting scandal two years ago, fired the firm.

Allan Chernoff has the report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ALLAN CHERNOFF, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Volcker's plan is to sweep out Andersen's U.S. management and put his oversight board in power to change the firm.

PAUL VOLCKER, FORMER CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: We feel strongly enough so that we're willing to take control of the firm if some very serious conditions are met. It will certainly involve changes in leadership, may involve some new management.

CHERNOFF: Volcker is hoping his prestige can save Andersen, but his proposal is contingent on conditions that may be impossible to meet: a capping of Andersen's liability in class action lawsuits, a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, dismissal or suspension of the Justice Department suit, and support of most Andersen partners. Anderson partner James Patterson says he's keeping an open mind.

JAMES PATTERSON, NATIONAL PARTNER, ANDERSEN: Well, as our chairman indicated at the outset of this process, the firm would be supportive of recommendations from the Volcker commission. And I look forward to the leadership of our firm Studying those recommendations.

CHERNOFF: Volcker and Andersen are fighting the clock. Defections from Andersen are accelerating. On Friday alone, the firm lost clients Hartford Financial Services, Occidental Petroleum, Apache Corporation, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, ChoicePoint, as well as Waste Management, the firm whose cooked books Andersen had approved several years ago.

And the list of Andersen partnership defections is growing, New Zealand partners saying they'll join with Ernst & Young, following similar defections in Russia, Hong Kong and China.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

At the beginning of the week, Andersen world-wide said its non- U.S. partners were planning to join with KPMG. But as the company's problems mount here in the U.S., the attitude at Andersen offices around the globe appears to be "Every man for himself."

Minutes ago, Andersen released a statement in response to Volcker plan. Quote, "This is a positive and constructive proposal that works to resolve the difficult issues with the SEC, the Department of Justice and other claimants" -- Jan.

HOPKINS: Is there time for it to work?

CHERNOFF: It's really going to be right now up to the Department of Justice and the SEC. Can they work out a deal? Andersen is hoping that Volcker can pressure the DoJ enough that they'll back off. It's a long shot.

HOPKINS: Very interesting. In terms of these overseas partners that are decided that they're going to go with other firms, how easy is it for them to do that?

CHERNOFF: Not at all because there are requirements that the partnerships around the globe put in money every year. And if they want to break away, they're supposed to pay one-and-one-half times their annual revenue just to break away.

HOPKINS: Wow. Thanks, Allan Chernoff.

Andersen employees today staged another rally to protest the government's decision to indict the entire firm for shredding Enron- related documents. The rally took place in Chicago. They were joined by friends and family, just some of the many thousands of Andersen employees who say they had nothing to do with the Enron account.

Three Andersen employees join us tonight. From San Francisco, Bill Parsons. He's a business consulting partner who's been with Andersen for the past 10 years. Also from Chicago, Michelle Ivy. She's an executive assistant at Andersen who has been with the company for two years. She spoke at today's rally. And Susan Bell, an audit partner in Atlanta, who has been with Andersen for nearly 18 years.

Welcome to all of you. Let me start first in Chicago with Michelle. You spoke at rally today in part because you wrote a letter to President Bush. What did you say?

MICHELLE IVY, ANDERSEN: In the letter?

HOPKINS: And at rally.

IVY: Oh. Well, at the rally today, basically, I just explained how I felt, how it was affecting me personally. And I just basically said I had no knowledge of Enron before this whole ordeal began. I didn't even know who they were. But I wanted to let them know how I was being affected, how the kids that I tutor through the Stockton (ph) Reading Day program was affected also and the fact that it was really hard to tell a 3rd-grader that you can't go on a field trip with them any longer because the company might not be around, come that time.

HOPKINS: Let's go to San Francisco and Bill Parsons, a business partner with Andersen, a consulting partner. You sold your own consulting business to Andersen a few years ago. So all of your company's equity is wrapped up in Andersen, right?

WILLIAM PARSONS, ANDERSEN: That would be correct. About 10 years ago, I was the president of an independent consulting practice in Los Angeles. And for a number of reasons, we decided to sell the firm. And I had known a number of Andersen partners and a number of Andersen people in the marketplace and had always been impressed with them and decided that when it was time for us to move on that Andersen would be the ideal place for not only myself but our entire organization to be. And yes, much of our proceeds were put into the organization.

HOPKINS: Did you have anything to do with Enron?

PARSONS: Absolutely not. I've never been there.

HOPKINS: And yet now your whole livelihood is wrapped up in Andersen, and at risk, at this point. That's what you're concerned about, I assume.

PARSONS: No, actually, I'm very upset about it. You know, we all -- in the San Francisco office, all 1,100 people whom I interact with are all very upset, very concerned about our future, about the stability of the organization and about our ability to meet all our obligations. So yes, our future is somewhat uncertain.

HOPKINS: Let's go to Atlanta now and Susan Bell, an audit partner with Andersen. What about the mood in your office in Atlanta? Was Enron a client at all?

SUSAN BELL, ANDERSEN: No. Enron was never a client of Atlanta, and our people don't know anything about Enron. The mood in the office…

HOPKINS: Go he ahead.

BELL: I was just going say the mood in the office is really sad. It's -- people are very scared about what's happening to our firm and what's happening to each of them.

HOPKINS: What about the charges, though, about massive shredding of documents? Doesn't that concern you? Especially in a case that could end up being a criminal case? Susan, you first.

BELL: Well, absolutely, it concerns me. When I first heard it, I was shocked and disappointed. But I truly can't imagine that any of our people shredded documents on purpose. Our people make mistakes sometimes. Our people may make dumb moves. But they are not bad people. They're not criminals. And they just possibly could not have shredded documents on purpose.

HOPKINS: And Michelle, what about in the Chicago office? I mean, what's your response to this massive shredding of documents, which is really the basis of the government's case against Andersen?

IVY: Well, actually, when I heard about it, naturally, I was upset at the fact that I thought first, initially, that they shredded these documents for whatever reason, from what I heard in the media. However, I come to learn that -- well, in my opinion, I don't think, as far as what the interaction I've had with Andersen employees, like she said, that they would have ever done anything on purpose. I don't believe that they shredded documents, knowing that those documents would have been called or they would be involved somehow in a criminal case. I don't think they would have been that stupid, personally.

HOPKINS: Bill Parsons, what about the Paul Volcker plan to save Andersen? Do you think there's time for it to work?

PARSONS: Well, I think we're all very appreciative of Mr. Volcker for lending his credibility and prestige to the firm. Clearly, he's come up with some ideas that seem to make a lot of sense. I think the biggest concern we all have is, is there enough time for our organization to survive in the marketplace, where every day and day out, our integrity, which has now been challenged, is all- important?

I mean, unfortunately, we seem to be guilty before we are proven innocent. And in the professional services world, integrity is really all you have. So if Paul -- if Mr. Volcker can restore that, we would -- we'll be very grateful.

HOPKINS: Thank you all for joining us. Bill Parsons and Michelle Ivy and Susan Bell. Thank you, all.

On Wall Street, stocks finished the session lower, pushing the markets lower for the week. Investors today focused on the outlook for corporate profits, the Dow falling 52 points, the NASDAQ losing 17. The S&P 500 was down nearly 5.

For the week as a whole, the Dow ended a five-week winning streak and it fell nearly 2 percent for the week. The NASDAQ was down nearly 1 percent, and the S&P 500 was down 1.5 percent. Among the most widely held issues today, McDonald's fell more than 1, after it warned about its first quarter results. UAL was up after announcing that United Airlines would add more 2,000 employees to accommodate increased flight schedules. Hewlett-Packard low after the head of its services unit said profits are below forecast. Lucent Technologies fell after Moody's cut its rating for the company.

Looking at some other market movers, shares at Baker Hughes tumbled 2.5. The company slashed its earning estimates, citing a drop in North American drilling activity. Schlumberger fell after a downgrade from SalomonSmith Barney. Nike fell nearly 4. That was despite a 30 percent jump in net income. But Nike warned that orders grew at a slower pace than last year.

Shares of Palm gained 20 percent after returning to profitability after a year of losses. And Travelers Property Casualty gained 1 on its first day of trading, the most actively traded stock on the big board.

My next guest expects trading to remain choppy, saying the recovery will be subtle. For more on the markets, Todd Eberhard joins us now.

The recovery will be subtle, but the markets' response won't necessarily be subtle?

TODD EBERHARD, EBERHARD INVESTMENT ASSOC.: Well, the markets are not being subtle at all in either direction. It depends on the day you pick. But we have great swings on the up side and great swings on the down side, today -- put -- put today aside to some degree.

HOPKINS: So -- and that's what we need to get used to? I mean, one day investors are optimistic that the recovery is here to stay, and the next day, investors are worried about company earnings.

EBERHARD: Exactly. It's a tug-of-war, depending on the day. And what the news is really putting out early on in the day will direct the markets. And if you have earnings that seem OK from one or two companies, the markets overall go higher. If an Andersen story or Enron story come out and that's the focus, we have lower days. And they just go back and forth. It's a great trading market for people doing that. It's not been a great market for investors for the long term yet.

HOPKINS: Well, what should investors for the long term be doing? Because one of the things that happened last week was the Federal Reserve met, and it's pretty clear that rates are going up in the future. Not quite yet. So how do you position yourself for this kind of environment?

EBERHARD: If you're a long-term investor, you have to really look at buying opportunities on those bad days, when the markets are down dramatically, and look for companies that you're interested in buying on the days when we see the pullbacks. And that's what the markets have been doing. We've had terrible days, we're down 150, 200 points, and everybody buys it back up to close to even. And that's a nice thing to see. Maybe we're building a little bit of a base. But because of the recession that we've gone into and theoretically starting to come out of was not so deep, we're not going to have such a great recovery that everybody would expect, like the '91-'92 term.

HOPKINS: So then the market's not going to go much higher?

EBERHARD: Well, it is, but it's going to -- in our opinion, it is. But it's going to take time. And really, it's got to be a building process. It's not dramatic, 500, 600 points here and there every -- every step of the -- of weeks. We'll have days we're up 100, days we're down 100. And really buy those dips. Look for the rises to -- to come through. And just hold those stocks over the longer term, as the market builds upon itself.

HOPKINS: Now, what things should you be looking at? The same things as the last time around? Technology?

EBERHARD: No. We don't think so. We think tech, at this point, is going to be the last one recovering generally from this market. We've talked about a few things, one you just touched on, which are the airlines. We really believe in the airlines right now and have been buying them since the September 11th terrorist attack and really look at those as a recovery point. And truly, you could spend hours discussing why, but a good story today is more jobs being brought back on line for more flights and more people traveling. And…

HOPKINS: So is it clear that people really are coming back? Because I was reading today that the business traveler is not coming back.

EBERHARD: Well, I think it's a little different city to city, and that's something we've looked at. The Northeast corridor has come back dramatically. But California has not so much because, again, the tech stocks who were out there have not recovered so much to spend money to travel. But we're seeing numbers that most of the airlines are off, versus the same point last year, about 17 percent. But their stocks are down 60 percent, on average. So should it be off or the stocks be off that much? We don't think so.

HOPKINS: And then what about hotel stocks and all of the other stocks that are associated with the travel industry?

(CROSSTALK)

EBERHARD: If you're buying that type of area -- and the question is really diversification. If the airlines recover, in theory, so will the hotels, so will gaming stocks. But I'm not sure you want to spread your money into every one of those industries because they are very interrelated.

HOPKINS: Now, we had big news this week on GE. Bill Gross (ph)…

EBERHARD: Yes.

HOPKINS: … from Pemco (ph) raised a lot of questions about GE. Do you think that investors should be careful about this company?

EBERHARD: I like GE. We think it's a very strong company. But again, with all the rumor mills going on about all companies out there and their -- certainly, in GE's case, the debt question, as well as financials in general, I think it's scaring everybody. So everybody's taking a step back, and GE's just become the focus because, truly, they're the big guy on the block.
