urn:contentItem:5TFT-R861-DXH2-60H1-00000-00Dow Plummets 800 Points; Hurricane Michael Slams Florida; Interview With Apalachicola, Florida, Mayor Van Johnson2018-10-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisYOUR WORLD WITH NEIL CAVUTO4:00 PM ESTSteve Harrigan, Catherine Stempien, Van Johnson, Phil Flynn, Melissa Armo, Joe Bastardi, Bob IaccinoNEWSInternational101001cb.140Dow Plummets 800 Points; Hurricane Michael Slams Florida; Interview With Apalachicola, Florida, Mayor Van JohnsonRick Leventhal, Rick Reichmuth, Jeff Flock, John Roberts, Phil Keating, Charles Payne, Neil Cavuto

NEIL CAVUTO, HOST: All right, FOX on top of two storms, and, well, barreling through and hitting investors, and, at the Panhandle, hitting just average folks, who probably weren't too concerned about the right end of your screen.

Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto.

And it has been an awful day weather wise in the Gulf and an awful day at the corner of Wall and Broad and for your 401(k) and investment statements.

We are top of each development, the situation with that hurricane. And it's a doozy, Michael at a Category 4 doing. There's a lot of flooding. There's a lot of wind. There's been reports of a good deal of damage. But it could have been a whole lot worse.

I wish, I wish I could say the same about what happened to the investment community today

We're on top of both dramatic developments.

By the way, I do want to kick off, though, with what happened on the financial side and what could possibly bring us to session lows down better than 3 percent, the worst single-day performance in this market. You would have to go back to early February. And you would have to go back to levels in this market that we had not seen since all the way back in August.

So, do want to step back from all this. And as bad as it was, we are simply revisiting, in the cases of some stock, levels we were last seeing about four to six weeks ago. We will get into the details on that.

But let me suffice it to say that the catalyst for all of this was an improving economy. Now, I know that sounds a little weird. But a lot of this has to do with a backup in interest rates to address that improving economy, and the notion that interest rates are going to have to go back still further and higher.

What happens with the markets is, they never really know how to digest the unexpected or the unknown. And the unknown for them is, how much is too much.

Right now, a 10-year note fetches about 3.75 percent. That is the highest we have seen in about seven years. A two-year note reaching a level today that was the highest we have seen in more than a decade.

But it's what you get used to. There were times when these were double- digit events. So, in other words, when we had a 10-year note at 10 percent or better during the late 1980s, or when we had a two-year note that was routinely double what it is now, for a while triple what it is now.

But it doesn't do much good to say that was then, this is now. It's what we have been getting used to now, better than a decade of near zero percent interest rates set by a Federal Reserve that was trying to get us out of a recession and a meltdown. It did the trick.

Now the trick is unwinding all of that, again, easier said than done.

To Charles Payne at the Nasdaq that was the not-so-pleasant beneficiary of the bulk of that selling.

So, Charles, interesting enough, a lot of those tech names that led us on this parade were the ones getting the most battered, huh?

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: You're absolutely right, Neil.

And it's not just today. These big tech names over the last two or three weeks have been conspicuously weak, very vulnerable, some going back to earnings. Facebook collapsed on its earnings. Netflix didn't have great earnings. Twitter came down.

But then some of the more -- even the larger names. Apple two days ago got a sell rating. That's really rare with a company like that. Amazon has its issues. A lot of this revolving around regulatory concerns, as well, which have creeped into this area because of some of the practices from all of them.

But no one, to your point, was spared. And I will go back to the Dow for a moment, because what we witness now, this year, are the three biggest, largest point losses in the history of the Dow, not percentage losses, of course. Three of the four biggest losses, of course, this year all revolved -- in fact, no, four -- four of the five all revolved around the Federal Reserve.

In February, rates started to go higher. We got a jobs report that looked like it was too hot. Everyone started to panic over what the Fed may do to slow this economy down. That sort of settled down. We were able to deal with 3 percent. But now the velocity of how quickly these rates have gone up again, these yields, again spooking the market.

But I will add, Neil, there was some fundamental news. You and I talked a little bit yesterday. It's not a household name, but Pittsburgh Plate Glass is a 135-year-old company. People know the company. You probably have some of their paint on your car, OK. So they had bad numbers.

They warned of higher prices. Today, Fastenal, again, an industrial name, not a household name, but it led the industrials lower. That was the second-worst performing sector. It was the worst-performing stock in that sector.

So some of this is interest-rate related. Some of this is higher prices. Some of is just speculation that things have been great. Can they continue?

CAVUTO: All right, Charles, thank you very, very much, Charles Payne.

Again, all Dow 30 stocks were down. That is a rarity, but every single one of them down. So you don't see that often.

Also, with an 831-point in the Dow -- if we can go back to showing the Dow, guys -- that 831-point hit represents about a little more than 3 percent in the value of the Dow Jones industrials shredded today.

Now, I should hasten to add, in percentage terms, that -- that's a lot, but it's not what it was in 1987. You might recall, October 19, 1987, October, yes, it tends to be a scary time, we lost a quarter of the Dow's value in one single session, even though it represented 508 points at the time.

So I hasten to add that, just to put it in perspective, not to just gloss over this, but to put it in percentage perspective here, that we are still nominally up on the year. And even though some very big names that have led us here, like an Amazon, for example, not part of the Dow, but part of the technology run-up, that is in correction territory right now.

In other words, it has fallen more than 10 percent from its highs. So you're going to hear a lot about a lot of stocks that have fallen into correction territory or 10 percent or more from their highs. vs. bear market territory, 20 percent or further from their highs.

Now, one out of five S&P 500 stocks are already in that latter camp. So we're keeping an eye on it, as is this next fellow, chief market strategist for path Trading Partners, Bob Iaccino.

Bob, thank you for joining us. What's your take on this day, whether this was overdone or justified, given the alarming run-up we have seen?

BOB IACCINO, PATH TRADING PARTNERS: Good afternoon, Neil.

To me, it's a time when we need to be responsible in terms of being in the financial media reporting on these kind of things, because these are the exact kind of moves people get scared about. They're exaggerated. They're overdone. And they tend to end up being buying opportunities, maybe not today.

But specifically this kind of move prior to earnings, with the headwinds that we see with the stock markets, from tariffs, to higher rates, to the Fed being on this trajectory, the Fed put is no longer in place now, if the Fed is taking this sort of punchbowl away.

But this is a really good time to be going into earnings and get this exaggerated sell-off, if I could point out a silver lining. If we get that 20 percent earnings growth, you're going to have some sectors and some stocks respond to the upside. From the prior levels, we wouldn't necessarily get that. We would kind of get profit-taking.

So not to say this is a good thing. It's never a good thing. You never want to see people's 401(k)s drop like this. But the timing of it, I'm kind of a fan of.

CAVUTO: All right, now, we have been the market leader in the world. We have been leading this parade. In fact, as things stand now, with the European markets in the doldrums and now indications it could get worse with Italy's problems -- I don't want to get on a tangent -- of course, we know what's happened in Asia. We know what has happened to the Chinese market, of course, already well into bear market territory.

Could you envision that for us, or what?

IACCINO: No, I think it's the other way around, Neil. And I think that's why you're pointing it out.

One thing we don't see all that often is stocks and bonds going in the same direction. We do see it, but it usually doesn't sustain. We're actually seeing a little bit of stabilization in the longer end of the curve as I speak to you right now, especially that 10-year-to-30-year sector.

So I think we're actually going to get some relief on the rate side, we're going to get some good earnings, and we are likely to pull the rest of the world up. Now, we do have to see the effect of tariffs in the earnings. We didn't see it in the last earnings report, the last quarter.

We might see the start of it now. But we're also going to see in the in the next quarter some of the positives of the USMCA, some of the positives of the deal with Korea, some of the positives of the deal with -- potentially with Europe. So there might be some balance there.

I think we're actually going to lead the world out of it. The economy here is strong. This sell-off is too fast, but still the timing of it, again, I have to say I'm kind of a fan of just before earnings.

CAVUTO: All right, and it is October after all. Thank you very, very much, my friend.

Again, putting in October in perspective, even though it is not technically the worst month of the year for stocks -- technically, that is September -- September ended up being a pretty good month for stocks, by and large, but the fact of the matter is, whether you're talking 2008 and the financial meltdown, or 1997 and the Asian contagion, or 1987, of course, the memorable stock market crash, or 1929, and the follow-up that brought us the Depression, it has a history of spooking us.

And it does, right?

All right, let's get the latest right now from Phil Keating in Apalachicola, Florida with the very latest on how Hurricane Michael is sorting out there.

Sir.

PHIL KEATING, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Neil.

This is Apalachicola, where it was ferocious for multiple hours today. But this is pretty much -- we're still getting a gust as we speak right now. You can see the wind blowing all this floodwater. Much of that is rainwater. Much of it is storm surge.

The Apalachicola River is adjacent to this street, which is Water Street. So that's very calm now, but you can actually see off into the distance. So straight down below us, this is actually a roadway, but there's no driving on this for now. That is absolutely certain.

And off to your right, the entire parking lot is still underwater. The cars for the hotel patrons here, including our vehicles, are all over there. That was the highest point of the parking lot. And it looks like most of them, at least the far row, survives. Some of them in the lower row there on your screen, I saw windshield wipers going, lights turning on and off, the computers of the cars victims of the storm surge and the flooding waters down here.

A lot of damage of these tin roofs aluminum roots here on these storage buildings. There's a shrimp processing facility down there. A lot of that frozen shrimp off-loaded into 18-wheelers yesterday anticipating everything you see over there was going to be underwater, as it is right now.

And they're actually parked not too far from here. But, of course, their generators aren't running. So all of that shrimp and fish that was frozen slowly will be thawing out, and if it's not rescued in time, it will soon be worthless.

There is a mandatory curfew for everybody in this county, in fact, all of the counties in the Big Bend and the Panhandle, from sunset to sunrise.

From here on out, what's going to be very important right now is for the sheriff's departments in every county, as well as police departments and other emergency responders, to get out and about on those shallow draft boats, their high-profile vehicles, ATVs, and try to figure out how much damage is out there, because everybody has simply hunkered down all day long, including the sheriff of this county, who texted us back saying, "This is the worst I have ever seen."

It was a ferocious, ferocious storm, 155 mile-an-hour winds when it made landfall just northwest of here. Much damage undoubtedly remains to be discovered perhaps as early as tonight, but definitely throughout the day tomorrow and maybe the next day after it.

And that, of course, does include the potential loss of life, because this was absolutely a life-threatening storm and very dangerous. Everyone is under an order right now, do not leave your house. Still under that order. That went into effect at about 7:00 a.m. this morning, when things really started to deteriorate, and right around noon until about 4:00 3:00, it was really something to see, something to experience.

It was one hell of a hurricane, Neil.

CAVUTO: Man, oh, man, it certainly looked like that. I'm glad you're safe, your crew is safe. Phil, thank you very, very much, Phil Keating in Apalachicola, Florida.

And we will be talking to that city's mayor shortly.

An update from the president of the United States.

John Roberts at the White House right now. He's been monitoring these developments very, very closely -- John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: And, Neil, the president just taking off from the White House South Lawn a short time ago on the way to Erie, Pennsylvania.

Some shouted questions at the president about is he concerned about the drop in the markets now, over 800 points? The president didn't answer questions. But I did just get off the phone with a senior White House official, who told me that the feeling around the White House here is that this is a bull market correction. It's nothing to panic about. And, in fact, it's probably a good thing. The market might have been a little bit overheated.

There are some concerns about rising interest rates. However, this person tells me that those concerns are probably overbaked. There's also some concern among some companies that the looming tariffs against China could hurt their bottom line. But the fact is, the economy is roaring ahead. And so that argument really doesn't hold a lot of water.

So it's just -- it's a day, it would seem, according to folks I talk to at the White House here, Neil, that the market got a little bit skittish about some of the indicators that they see out there and some of the potential for some things to happen. But they believe that in the overall this is something that will pass, it's a momentary correction in the market. We are not about to enter a bear market by any stretch of the imagination, according to folks here at the White House. And we will likely see a turnaround sometime in the next few days.

So, nothing to panic about here, is what we're being told as far as the markets go -- Neil.

CAVUTO: Now, when it comes to the hurricane and visiting folks in that region, I think the president had said he hoped to be down in the Florida Panhandle area by Sunday or Monday?

ROBERTS: He did.

Yes, clearly, when something like this passes through as quickly as it as it does, it's not going to have the lingering effect that Hurricane Florence did. But certainly it's going to leave a lot of damage behind, it's going to leave a lot of work for first-responders to attend to.

So the president doesn't want to get in the way of that. Any time you traveled to that true, or at least to an area that's been hard-hit by a hurricane, the facilities there are already overtaxed, and you don't want to add to that by bringing the president down.

But it would seem that the Air Force base down there took the brunt of the hit here from this hurricane. So it may be that the president can get down there a little earlier and take a look at some of the damage. But when he talked about it in the Oval Office, he had either Sunday or Monday as possible times that he could get down there.

So we will see, Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, John Roberts of the White House, thank you very, very much.

We will give you the latest of that storm and some of those mayors in the region directly affected by it. They're breathing a sigh of relief after it.

I don't know if investors feel the same way, but we're on top of both storms, what they mean for the region down there and what they mean for you and your portfolio and investments here.

CAVUTO: All right, no pun intended, but when it rains, it pours.

Certainly, in the case of Hurricane Michael, the worst storm to hit the Panhandle area in the better part of the century, and it could have been a lot worse. That's all we can say.

And the corner of Wall and Broad, certainly the worst sell-off to hit the markets in the better part of six months.

First on the storm with Jeff Flock in Panama City Beach -- Jeff.

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Damage from the sell-off yet to be known, but the damage here starting to be known.

You can see it's not exactly catastrophic, but if you're the guy that owns -- spins around, maybe you see you lose a roof, all kinds of other debris out here.

We're just kind of now assessing what we see, but get through the debris here. Maybe we take you down to the beach. I have not been down here yet. But I want to see what this water looks like.

It doesn't appear there's...

CAVUTO: All right, I apologize for our feed there and for all of his hard reporting here.

Let's dip back in, if it's OK again.

FLOCK: Got you? You still got me there? Sorry.

I know it's probably a little funky, huh, Neil?

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: It is, but I'm getting you, buddy. Keep going.

FLOCK: OK.

Well, we will keep going here. We're just trying to see what the -- what the status is down on the beach.

You OK, Kyle?

As you can see, I mean, is it catastrophic damage? No, I wouldn't say so. But the damage is quite clear. And I will leave you with a shot maybe of the beach. If we walk around here, we can just see it, obviously more -- more of this kind of thing, but the...

CAVUTO: All right, I apologize for that. Certainly not his fault.

These are what you deal with when you're obviously in a situation, and digital's what you rely on.

Apalachicola, Florida, Mayor Van Johnson joins us on the phone right now.

Mayor, you must be breathing a sigh of relief. You're not entirely out of the woods here, and I'm sure you're assessing things, but it could have been worse.

VAN JOHNSON, MAYOR OF APALACHICOLA, FLORIDA: That is true.

I just had a conversation with our chief of police, who is actually out and about now. In a city like Apalachicola that would normally take 15 to 20 minutes to ride the whole town driving about 25 miles an hour, he's finding it difficult just to get from street to street because of all the down power lines and trees.

So, he's out assessing the situation. And it's just -- we're going to have a lot of cleanup to do in the aftermath of this storm.

CAVUTO: Mayor, there was a call on the part of the governor for people to voluntarily evacuate on their own.

We're told, throughout the Panhandle area, about 50 percent took him up on that. What were the percentages in your town?

JOHNSON: It was about 40 percent in my community leading up.

In fact, I was at that press conference when the governor expressed the need to evacuate. And at that time, it was reported about 40 percent of the people from Apalachicola had heeded that call.

Now, as the storm intensified and reached a Category 4 classification, a lot more people took it seriously and started to leave. But I believe about 20 percent just decided to hunker down.

CAVUTO: Any rescues that need being done now?

JOHNSON: None reported. Of course, the call went out that if you decided to stay in your house, don't be roaming out in the streets, to minimize any injury to yourself or the rescue workers or the people that was out there.

So I haven't heard of any calls for rescue, and I thank God for that. I haven't heard whether we had any loss of life yet, and I thank God for that as well.

CAVUTO: Mayor, one of the things that you keep hearing about this storm is that it moved fast. And the good about that is that it didn't have time to hang around and do still more damage.

What was it like by you?

JOHNSON: Well, I'm actually -- I actually evacuated.

I took the governor's call, and I took the heed, my own memo that I sent out. And I evacuated to Destin, which is about 120 miles east of Apalachicola.

But from what I'm understanding, that we had flooding, downed power lines, trees. We had some road closures. In fact, the major thoroughfare out of Apalachicola, Highway 98, is actually washed in two between Eastpoint and Carrabelle.

CAVUTO: What about power outages? We heard a couple hundred thousand people in the area were without power. And that could exponentially grow. I'm sure it will. What is the latest in your area?

JOHNSON: Well, just about all of Franklin County is out of -- without power.

CAVUTO: Hmm.

JOHNSON: Yes.

CAVUTO: And any indication what you're getting from folks and when it will be returned? I know, in the case of most storms, Florence included, they waited weeks.

JOHNSON: Well, I know the governor spoke during his press conference that he had been in contact with Duke Energy, and that they had about 1,900 trucks waiting for when the storm passed to come back into the area and restore power.

I don't know if that has taken place as yet, but it was certainly part of the recovery plan.

CAVUTO: Mayor, I'm glad you're well. I'm glad it appears your folks are well and those around you are well. You dodged a bullet, as they say.

But be well, sir. Thank you.

JOHNSON: Thank you.

CAVUTO: All right.

Not so many investors who might have been getting used to the fact that what goes up, up, up, up can sometimes go down and sometimes go down with a thud.

We should hasten to add here, with this 831-point falloff in the Dow today, it might seem like an eye-popping number. And I don't want to minimize it. It is. But a little bit north of 3 present in value, compare that to what happened on October 19, 1987, when a quarter of the Dow's value was wiped out, it is very, very different.

Having said all of that, though, these are one-day hits to technology stocks that have led this parade. You heard a great deal about the so- called FANG stocks, those that were the largely the technology issues, the Facebooks, the Amazon, the Netflix, the Google Alphabets, that had led a parade that produced disproportionate returns.

If not for those issues, the Nasdaq, for example, wouldn't look nearly as impressive. And today it didn't. From its highs, it's down now about 6.5 to 7 percent. So that's not even correction territory.

However, Amazon is effectively in correction territory, and then some, down 10 percent or more from its highs. But this is an issue that has surged 50 percent over this year. So put that in perspective as well, as does market watcher Melissa Armo.

So, Melissa, your take on today. Is there more of this to come? What do you think?

MELISSA ARMO, THE STOCK SWOOSH: I definitely think we could possibly be lower tomorrow, just because of the huge sell-off today.

But here's the lesson of today, Neil. Don't buy the dip. I was watching yesterday. Everyone says, oh, buy the dip, buy the dip. We fell off last weekend to Monday, and people were buying yesterday. I wasn't surprised at all this morning. I could tell right into the open this morning, five minutes into the open, that we were going to sell off.

And it was straight selling, all down today, because people bought yesterday. When something's falling, when you have a falling knife with, like you said, a thud, you don't buy it because you don't know where it's going to land. Buy strength. Short weakness in the market. That's how you make money, that's how you make profit.

CAVUTO: Now, I'm not a market technician. I think a lot of this stuff that a lot of those fine-tune market folks use is akin to reading chicken entrails and tea leaves.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: Having said that, they say it's generally not a healthy ending to be at your session lows at the ending, that there's a washout period to come.

You alluded to that on your comments earlier. What do you envision tomorrow morning?

ARMO: Tomorrow morning, I think if we open neutral, we drop. If we gap down in the morning, I think we can fall in and hold.

The only way we -- you could buy the market tomorrow is if we had a huge, massive gap up, and I don't think that's going to happen. I think it's a washout until, when, Friday. Friday morning, it's critical for the market.

And here's why. J.P. Morgan Chase reports before the open, Citibank and Wells Fargo. J.P. Morgan Chase is the one you want to watch. If those banks report well, which I don't know, on Friday morning, then we could have a turnaround. Then the market could look a lot different to close the week that it does at the close of today.

Market can change tune here. Remember, we just made brand-new all-time highs again on the Dow. I wouldn't panic. Now, if you're in retirement, you might be panicking because of this big sell-off.

But if you have a long way to retirement -- I'm talking three years, five years, 10 years or more, stay long in the market. i don't think we're anywhere near changing trend. I do think that market is strong. And I said this earlier. I believe the market closes very strong into December, just like we started the year.

We're going into earnings season. I would say be worried if we weren't going into earnings season. But because we are, a lot of these stocks that don't look so good today, all the tech, and even the banks too, could be completely 100 percent different after they report.

CAVUTO: You might be right.

I know they say that history doesn't repeat itself, but it sure can rhyme. And what rhymes here to me is some of what was going on in 1987 the week before the crash, when the Dow was sort of dropping off the days before, and there were hints of trouble to come.

Do you see any hints of trouble? Now, back then, the foundation, as President Ronald Reagan was saying at the time, was sound. This president says the same, it's sound. No one could argue then, no one can argue now both presidents were right.

But markets follow their own kind of weird verbs. Do you see anything that worries you right now?

ARMO: The only concern is the same concern really, Neil, that we have had all year. It's China, China. Nobody knows what's going to happen with China.

They just came out today. This is part of the reason why for the sell-off too. The administration announced they're going to review, the CFIUS Committee is going to review some of these investments, these foreign investments in the U.S.

And that's a bugaboo for China. And that's problematic. China is playing hardball.

CAVUTO: And, by the way, China is officially in a bear market.

ARMO: Oh, they have been. Yes.

CAVUTO: Its market -- it's well into a bear market. We are not. We are not.

In fact, we're up on the year. But the fact of the matter is, that's a worry. The notion is that we could be the stand-alone market, the standout market, which we are, and the stand-alone standout economy, which we are, but can we keep going it alone, if there are all these other headwinds from China, from Italy now barely able to make a budget and concern that it's going to go into a freefall?

What do you think?

ARMO: I think we could. Of course we could. We're the United States of America. And that's the great thing about being here, living here, participating in the market.

Trump is in charge. We will see what he's going to do. I will say one thing. Today's drop-off might stave off the Fed from raising interest rates one more time before the end of the year, when it looked like they might raise them again, which was in question if they would do one more before the end of the year.

This drop-off might stave them off a little bit, which is a good thing for consumers and a good thing for market participants.

CAVUTO: All right, thank you very, very much, Melissa.

The Fed, to which she was alluding, the Federal Reserve, of course, expected to raise rates and four more times before the end of this year and three more times next year.

All of that in response, I must stress, to good economic news. The economy is doing quite well, in fact, generationally, record-level well, but it is that strong economy that is perplexing traders. They realize that interest rates were going to go up, and that was baked into the cake, so to speak.

They didn't realize they would go backing up to the degree they already have, a 10-year note slipping back, a two-year note slipping back. And a lot of people wondering, we don't know where this goes. There's an old saw on Wall Street here. In uncertainty, you sell. You ask questions later.

They're selling. They will deal with the other stuff later.

Right now, the immediate concern in the Panhandle is this storm and Hurricane Michael and how the region dodged a bullet. But it's a very pricey bullet and a very nasty one.

It could have been even nastier -- after this.

CAVUTO: All right.

We are getting word that as many as 320,000 Floridians decided to ride out the storm and never evacuated. We do not know their status.

We also know that millions of Americans were caught in their sell-off. We do know theirs.

CAVUTO: All right, let's get the latest on Michael.

Could have been and probably should have been worse. It is still pretty bad, though.

Rick Leventhal in Panama City with the latest -- Rick.

RICK LEVENTHAL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes.

And, Neil, I apologize for the camera issues. It's gotten fogged up, and it's been getting rained on. We have been getting rained on for hours now.

The rain has slowed down pretty considerably. But the wind is still blowing. And we just got word that there's a rescue mission under way here in Panama City. Panama City Fire and Rescue heading out to try and save someone from some sort of situation.

They had told us that they had encouraged 120,000 people to evacuate before the storm, and that didn't happen. About half the people actually evacuated. The other half stayed. And apparently at least one of those people needs to be rescued.

Neil, this is the kind of stuff, if you can see it, that's flying around out here, or was. It's a piece from the -- from the building next to us, some kind of siding. And it's sort of a tile material. And it's pretty heavy.

And I want to show you one other thing. The damages aren't extensive where we are, but you can see one of the utility poles that basically snapped in half. There is a transformer at the end of that pole. The power is out here and probably will be for sometime.

Damage is not as extensive as some had feared they might be, but a lot of them are still being assessed, Neil, because it's just now starting to clear up.

CAVUTO: All right, Rick, be safe, and your crew as well, Rick Leventhal.

Let's go to WeatherBELL's Joe Bastardi on what he makes of all of this -- Joseph.

JOE BASTARDI, WEATHERBELL CHIEF FORECASTER: Well, Port St. Joe is on the other side of the eye. The eye went ashore southeast of Rick.

And I think that that area is probably going to be devastated. It'll be interesting to see. And hopefully people got out of that area. This came ashore stronger than any hurricane that we have recorded in this area.

The barometric pressure was down at 920 millibars, which was very close to what Andrew hit Miami at. And I'm sure, when the damage is totaled up in those areas, again, the western side of the eyewall was in Panama City.

So the wind blew out toward the Gulf of Mexico, didn't come in from the Gulf of Mexico, and that's going to be a big deal. But this is now into Southwest Georgia. And it's just raising havoc as it goes inland, because it's so very powerful.

You're not going to see storms that get into Georgia with 100-mile-an-hour winds, 120. It's coming -- it's coming down quite a bit. The future path of the storm takes it near Macon tonight around 2:00 in the morning, where winds should gust between 80 and 90, perhaps 100 miles an hour, Augusta tomorrow morning 60, 80 miles an hour.

Go just southeast to Columbia, tomorrow, during the afternoon, tomorrow night, be midway between Fayetteville and Raleigh, and then reach the North Carolina coast near Elizabeth city, it looks, like probably 2:00 a.m. in the morning Friday.

When that happens, what will happen, Neil, is the frictional effects of the storm will diminish, so that the storm will wind back up again. You folks in Virginia Beach -- I have seen his before -- don't be surprised if you have a three- to six-hour period where the winds out of the north gusting to 60, 70 miles an hour, even though the storm will be reported to have less winds.

And they sort of play possum over land, but as soon as they get near the water, they rev back up again. As far as rainfall, widespread three to six locally, 12-inch amounts from where the storm is now all the way into Southeast Virginia. And that includes the area that was devastated by Florence.

That may aggravate the situation in there. There's going to be more power outages with this because it's going to continue to have strong winds inland. And to the east of that track I gave you, there's going to be tornadic activity breaking out tonight into tomorrow.

And that's going to be another problem with this storm. So even though it's weakened and it's inland, we will see what the damage was right where this went ashore. I fear that it's going to look like this storm bulldozed some areas when they get in there.

But we will see. The pressure where this came ashore at 920 millibars is the strongest by far ever in that area between Mobile and Tampa. So this is strongest storm, barometric pressure, likely wind, that we have recorded since back in 1851.

CAVUTO: All right.

I do also know, as you mentioned at the outset, the flooding possibilities, nine rivers that were already surging and had been surged a good deal, I think at least seven of them from Florence, resurge all over again. So that just compounds the problem for the Carolinas, Georgia, et cetera. Right?

BASTARDI: Yes, it does, Neil.

And I will tell you this, folks. I believe the last time we were on, Neil, back in September, I said you will probably see me showing up again in October. You won't see me again with hurricanes when this one's done. You will see me for winter storms. But I believe this is going to be the last impact storm on the United States this season.

CAVUTO: All right. Let's hope you're right on that.

Joe Bastardi, thank you very, very much.

Just a couple of things. The president, of course, has already said earlier in the day that FEMA and anyone else, also meeting with his historical secretary, would provide any emergency help that was necessary. He is going to be heading off to a campaign event tonight in Erie, Pennsylvania, on Friday to Lebanon, Ohio, on Saturday to Richmond, Kentucky.

We are told that he wants to at least get a firsthand view of what's happening the Panhandle probably sometime Sunday, could be Monday. Wants to be as the least disruptive way possible. Easier said than done when any president of the United States visits a region, but he wants to come when it is a good time to come. And he hopes to make that Sunday or Monday.

We will have more after this.

CAVUTO: All right, the latest on Michael now, no longer a Category 4 storm. But it is going to pack serious winds now as it makes its way north into Georgia and the Carolinas.

FOX News Channel's chief meteorologist, Rick Reichmuth, on its path now -- Rick.

RICK REICHMUTH, FOX NEWS CHIEF METEOROLOGIST: Neil, yes, obviously the stronger the storm when it comes offshore, the worse damage on the shore.

But that also means that it's going to take a longer time for those strong winds to go down. So you see it made landfall. We have had recorded wind gusts at 130 miles an hour. Keep in mind we don't have wind meters in every place, and a lot of them get blown offline.

But they had verified at 155 mile-an-hour winds when that was coming right onshore there. Now, you take a look at it, starting to weaken a little bit there. But we're all up in across the northeastern area of Alabama moving in towards Georgia right now.

Still with that well-defined center, and that means those hurricane-force winds now are extending very, very far off towards the north. Radar picture shows the same thing behind it, still some more bands. Likely right along the coast, we're going to calm down a little bit, especially across the western side of this.

On the eastern side, we will still see more moisture that is going to continue to be pulled up onshore. How does this rank compared to other storms? Take a look at this. When you think of all of the big storms we have had in our country over the years, wind wise, this is right below Andrew.

And as far as that central pressure goes, how low the pressure in the center of the storm went, take a look at that. That is the third strongest storm, the third lowest pressure we have ever recorded of a landfalling storm here across the U.S.

This is where we are now, still technically 140-mile-an-hour winds sustained. That will come down, I'm sure, a little bit as we get to that 5:00 advisory that is going to come out shortly.

And it will remain a hurricane for a little bit longer, go in towards tomorrow morning. We still have a tropical storm getting, moving in towards South Carolina. And we're going to very gusty conditions there across the Carolinas. Keep in mind a lot of areas likely have some weakened trees from all of the flooding that was there.

Some of that water is gone. But all of those root systems now are going to be very, very weakened here across the Carolinas. So won't take much to cause more wind to go over and knock some more of those trees out.

Likely strengthening a little bit here once it moves ashore, but we got a couple more days before we're fully done with this storm -- Neil.

CAVUTO: You know, Rick, I didn't realize it got very close to Category 5, didn't it?

REICHMUTH: One mile an hour away from the Cat 5, yes.

CAVUTO: Incredible. Wow.

Rick, thank you very, very much. Rick Reichmuth.

REICHMUTH: Yes.

CAVUTO: Well, this is also Oil Rig Alley, they call it, along the Gulf, when you have so many oil rigs and other facilities set up -- 40 percent of our overall oil output is in this region. So you would think that, immediately, prices would be spiking when it shut down. Just the opposite.

That was a little weird. But a guy who specializes in things that don't make sense, because he quickly make sense of them, is our energy trader and energy watcher, Phil Flynn.

Phil Flynn, why did we go down on oil prices?

PHIL FLYNN, PRICE FUTURES GROUP: Well, a couple of reasons.

The main reason is where the storm actually hit. The track of the storm miss some of the major installations. So all that production that you were talking about that was shut in can be brought online very quickly once the storm passes.

And now the storm has gone away from worrying about how much oil supplies and natural gas supplies we might lose to how much demand we might lose because of the track of the storm. If you take a look at that scary map, when we're going right through Florida into all of those different states, Virginia, Georgia, you name it, a lot of those people, of course, are going to be without power.

They're not going to be able to drive. And so the demand that would usually occur for oil in a normal everyday situation is not going to happen. So now the concern has gone away from, oh, my gosh, we won't have oil to supply the market to, we won't have demand to use it.

Now, the one thing I want to caution everybody is, is that this is called demand destruction when we have a storm like this. It's usually a very short-term phenomena, because I'm afraid that the damage that we're potentially going to see, Neil, from this storm is going to require a lot of energy in the future to rebuild.

So right now, the market is not as concerned about the loss of supply, but a couple of weeks down the road, when we start to rebuild, that oil demand is going to be back, and in a big way.

CAVUTO: All right, thank you, my friend, very much, Phil Flynn.

A couple of developments. There apparently is a tornado watch in effect for locations that in Florida directly affected by this along the Panhandle. That is not unusual after something like this, flash flood warnings given not only from the Panhandle area, but right straight through the Carolinas.

As you can see, that is the trajectory. For those of you listening on radio, this trajectory takes it through Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina, before it goes back out to sea sometime this weekend. But it's going to be around for a while.

Also, Hurricane Michael has forced at least eight cruises to reroute and up to 1,000 flights to and from airports in the area to be outright canceled or reschedule. Airlines affected have dropped all booking fees as a result of changing your plans, as if you had a choice.

We will have more after this.

CAVUTO: All right, after the storm, there's the power that goes invariably during and after the storm. And it usually increases in the hours afterwards.

We're already seeing that now, better than 200,000, we are told, without power now in the region. That could add as the night ensues here.

Catherine Stempien and is with Duke Energy. In fact, she's the Florida president.

Very good to have you with us, Catherine. And thank you for taking the time.

What is the situation there power wise for folks?

CATHERINE STEMPIEN, DUKE ENERGY: So, we're already seeing significant outages all across our system up on the Panhandle. We're predicting about 100,000 to 200,000 households and businesses that are customers of Duke Energy Florida will be losing their power as a result of this system.

Additionally, we expect maybe an additional 100,000 customers from the local electric cooperative, the municipalities who receive their electricity from Duke Energy will also be affected, because we're anticipating significant damage to our transmission system in the area.

CAVUTO: Now, I know it's hard to compare Florence with this and different storms. Florence hung around a while, less so with Michael.

How does that factor into when you get things back up and running?

STEMPIEN: Well, we're currently anticipating it could take days or maybe even more than a week for us to really get customers back online.

This system, with the winds of over 150,000 -- 150 miles per hour, in addition to significant storm surge and flooding, is really impacting, submerging our systems, damaging equipment that are powering entire communities,. We really see that, in some areas, we're going to have to rebuild our entire electrical system. And that's going to take some time.

CAVUTO: Yes, and that's that's a long-haul effort, as you said here.

I'm wondering, too, given the fact that fewer than half those in the affected areas -- or affected areas decided to evacuate, as the governor had urged, does that complicate things for you?

STEMPIEN: Well, it certainly does.

And I would like to thank Governor Scott for his leadership here in declaring a state of emergency for storm-impacted areas. And we're working very closely with the governor and his team to prioritize critical facilities and also working closely with the Department of Transportation to coordinate on road clearing.

But our ability to access some of those areas is really going to depend -- it's really going to hamper our ability to recover and to rebuild the system.

CAVUTO: Having said all of that, Catherine, you can't minimize the work that's ahead of you and your folks and the region.

Are you breathing somewhat of a sigh of relief? It was envisioned to be, certainly when it came in, much worse.

STEMPIEN: Well, we're still seeing impacts of the storm, so I don't think we are through this storm yet. And, of course, it's going to continue to impact areas of Georgia and up through the Carolinas, many of which are the same communities that were just impacted by Hurricane Florence.

CAVUTO: All right.

STEMPIEN: So I don't feel like we're out of the woods yet.

I would like to make sure to encourage people who were in Florida to be safe, to call 911 if they need any critical assistance, and to be communicating with their local EOCs, which they can find information about on FloridaDisaster.org for more information.

CAVUTO: Catherine Stempien, thank you. Wise words, all. We appreciate it.

I'm sure your customers appreciate it.

All right, so about 100,000 to 200,000 without power now. Whether that escalates, some say it will -- you don't know who's right on this. I know, with Florence, it exponentially went on, as the night and the storm went on. That was a slow mover. This is more serious, but faster. So you take your bets.

All right, Hurricane Michael, though, is still barrelling through Florida. And now Georgia is next in its sights. And as a number of folks were warning at FEMA and beyond, do not take this lightly in Georgia, and do not take it lightly if you're well inland. It is still packing a punch -- after this.

CAVUTO: Well, it looks like Michael has Georgia on its mine.

Steve Harrigan is in Macon, Georgia, with the latest.

Hey, Steve.

STEVE HARRIGAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Neil, the storm may have made landfall in Florida about 200 miles away from here, but it's really just beginning in the state of Florida.

It intends to enter the state of Florida as a Category 2 hurricane, then weakened to a Category 1 hurricane, before weakening further to a tropical storm.

That means, across the state of Georgia, we're going to see major structural damage, damage to roofs, buildings, houses, power lines down, electricity out, and perhaps part of the agriculture here devastated, especially that peanut crop.

So they were really taken by surprise a little bit here, because this storm got more powerful very quickly over the Gulf of Mexico. We heard the FEMA administrator say this morning Georgia has to wake up to the danger ahead. It is waking up quickly to that danger. While there are no mandatory evacuations planned, a state of emergency has been declared, and the National Guard has been mobilized -- Neil, back to you.

CAVUTO: Steve Harrigan, thank you very, very much.

Of course, Steve will be watching that as it moves its way into Georgia.

So this thing isn't over. And neither is this sell-off at the corner of Wall and Broad. It was a big one today.

Let's look at where this stacks up against other big hits in the Dow. This is just in point terms, that today's would rank third, but between what happened back in the early days of this year, when we were going through the same sort of conundrum here and were worried about interest rates.

I should add that, in percentage terms, about -- the 3 percent falloff today wouldn't even crack the top 10, dare I say the top 15 of hits to the Dow.

But it is real, it is nasty and it is built on the idea interest rates are going up because the economy keeps moving up. That would normally be a good thing, but not so right now, when people worry about, how high is high?

Tough to get a home loan. Tougher to get a mortgage loan. Tough to get any sort of loan. And, in that environment, they sell.

We will see tonight with futures and foreign trading.

urn:contentItem:5TGB-YXJ1-DY0W-41M5-00000-00Dow Plummets 800 Points; Hurricane Michael Slams Florida; Interview With Apalachicola, Florida, Mayor Van Johnson2018-10-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisDow Plummets 800 Points; Hurricane Michael Slams Florida; Interview With Apalachicola, Florida, Mayor Van JohnsonLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, HOST: All right, FOX on top of two storms, and, well, barreling through and hitting investors, and, at the Panhandle, hitting just average folks, who probably weren't too concerned about the right end of your screen.

Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto.

And it has been an awful day weather wise in the Gulf and an awful day at the corner of Wall and Broad and for your 401(k) and investment statements.

We are top of each development, the situation with that hurricane. And it's a doozy, Michael at a Category 4 doing. There's a lot of flooding. There's a lot of wind. There's been reports of a good deal of damage. But it could have been a whole lot worse.

I wish, I wish I could say the same about what happened to the investment community today

We're on top of both dramatic developments.

By the way, I do want to kick off, though, with what happened on the financial side and what could possibly bring us to session lows down better than 3 percent, the worst single-day performance in this market. You would have to go back to early February. And you would have to go back to levels in this market that we had not seen since all the way back in August.

So, do want to step back from all this. And as bad as it was, we are simply revisiting, in the cases of some stock, levels we were last seeing about four to six weeks ago. We will get into the details on that.

But let me suffice it to say that the catalyst for all of this was an improving economy. Now, I know that sounds a little weird. But a lot of this has to do with a backup in interest rates to address that improving economy, and the notion that interest rates are going to have to go back still further and higher.

What happens with the markets is, they never really know how to digest the unexpected or the unknown. And the unknown for them is, how much is too much.

Right now, a 10-year note fetches about 3.75 percent. That is the highest we have seen in about seven years. A two-year note reaching a level today that was the highest we have seen in more than a decade.

But it's what you get used to. There were times when these were double- digit events. So, in other words, when we had a 10-year note at 10 percent or better during the late 1980s, or when we had a two-year note that was routinely double what it is now, for a while triple what it is now.

But it doesn't do much good to say that was then, this is now. It's what we have been getting used to now, better than a decade of near zero percent interest rates set by a Federal Reserve that was trying to get us out of a recession and a meltdown. It did the trick.

Now the trick is unwinding all of that, again, easier said than done.

To Charles Payne at the Nasdaq that was the not-so-pleasant beneficiary of the bulk of that selling.

So, Charles, interesting enough, a lot of those tech names that led us on this parade were the ones getting the most battered, huh?

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: You're absolutely right, Neil.

And it's not just today. These big tech names over the last two or three weeks have been conspicuously weak, very vulnerable, some going back to earnings. Facebook collapsed on its earnings. Netflix didn't have great earnings. Twitter came down.

But then some of the more -- even the larger names. Apple two days ago got a sell rating. That's really rare with a company like that. Amazon has its issues. A lot of this revolving around regulatory concerns, as well, which have creeped into this area because of some of the practices from all of them.

But no one, to your point, was spared. And I will go back to the Dow for a moment, because what we witness now, this year, are the three biggest, largest point losses in the history of the Dow, not percentage losses, of course. Three of the four biggest losses, of course, this year all revolved -- in fact, no, four -- four of the five all revolved around the Federal Reserve.

In February, rates started to go higher. We got a jobs report that looked like it was too hot. Everyone started to panic over what the Fed may do to slow this economy down. That sort of settled down. We were able to deal with 3 percent. But now the velocity of how quickly these rates have gone up again, these yields, again spooking the market.

But I will add, Neil, there was some fundamental news. You and I talked a little bit yesterday. It's not a household name, but Pittsburgh Plate Glass is a 135-year-old company. People know the company. You probably have some of their paint on your car, OK. So they had bad numbers.

They warned of higher prices. Today, Fastenal, again, an industrial name, not a household name, but it led the industrials lower. That was the second-worst performing sector. It was the worst-performing stock in that sector.

So some of this is interest-rate related. Some of this is higher prices. Some of is just speculation that things have been great. Can they continue?

CAVUTO: All right, Charles, thank you very, very much, Charles Payne.

Again, all Dow 30 stocks were down. That is a rarity, but every single one of them down. So you don't see that often.

Also, with an 831-point in the Dow -- if we can go back to showing the Dow, guys -- that 831-point hit represents about a little more than 3 percent in the value of the Dow Jones industrials shredded today.

Now, I should hasten to add, in percentage terms, that -- that's a lot, but it's not what it was in 1987. You might recall, October 19, 1987, October, yes, it tends to be a scary time, we lost a quarter of the Dow's value in one single session, even though it represented 508 points at the time.

So I hasten to add that, just to put it in perspective, not to just gloss over this, but to put it in percentage perspective here, that we are still nominally up on the year. And even though some very big names that have led us here, like an Amazon, for example, not part of the Dow, but part of the technology run-up, that is in correction territory right now.

In other words, it has fallen more than 10 percent from its highs. So you're going to hear a lot about a lot of stocks that have fallen into correction territory or 10 percent or more from their highs. vs. bear market territory, 20 percent or further from their highs.

Now, one out of five S&P 500 stocks are already in that latter camp. So we're keeping an eye on it, as is this next fellow, chief market strategist for path Trading Partners, Bob Iaccino.

Bob, thank you for joining us. What's your take on this day, whether this was overdone or justified, given the alarming run-up we have seen?

BOB IACCINO, PATH TRADING PARTNERS: Good afternoon, Neil.

To me, it's a time when we need to be responsible in terms of being in the financial media reporting on these kind of things, because these are the exact kind of moves people get scared about. They're exaggerated. They're overdone. And they tend to end up being buying opportunities, maybe not today.

But specifically this kind of move prior to earnings, with the headwinds that we see with the stock markets, from tariffs, to higher rates, to the Fed being on this trajectory, the Fed put is no longer in place now, if the Fed is taking this sort of punchbowl away.

But this is a really good time to be going into earnings and get this exaggerated sell-off, if I could point out a silver lining. If we get that 20 percent earnings growth, you're going to have some sectors and some stocks respond to the upside. From the prior levels, we wouldn't necessarily get that. We would kind of get profit-taking.

They're not going to be able to drive. And so the demand that would usually occur for oil in a normal everyday situation is not going to happen. So now the concern has gone away from, oh, my gosh, we won't have oil to supply the market to, we won't have demand to use it.

Now, the one thing I want to caution everybody is, is that this is called demand destruction when we have a storm like this. It's usually a very short-term phenomena, because I'm afraid that the damage that we're potentially going to see, Neil, from this storm is going to require a lot of energy in the future to rebuild.

So right now, the market is not as concerned about the loss of supply, but a couple of weeks down the road, when we start to rebuild, that oil demand is going to be back, and in a big way.

CAVUTO: All right, thank you, my friend, very much, Phil Flynn.

A couple of developments. There apparently is a tornado watch in effect for locations that in Florida directly affected by this along the Panhandle. That is not unusual after something like this, flash flood warnings given not only from the Panhandle area, but right straight through the Carolinas.

As you can see, that is the trajectory. For those of you listening on radio, this trajectory takes it through Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina, before it goes back out to sea sometime this weekend. But it's going to be around for a while.

Also, Hurricane Michael has forced at least eight cruises to reroute and up to 1,000 flights to and from airports in the area to be outright canceled or reschedule. Airlines affected have dropped all booking fees as a result of changing your plans, as if you had a choice.

We will have more after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: All right, after the storm, there's the power that goes invariably during and after the storm. And it usually increases in the hours afterwards.

We're already seeing that now, better than 200,000, we are told, without power now in the region. That could add as the night ensues here.

Catherine Stempien and is with Duke Energy. In fact, she's the Florida president.

Very good to have you with us, Catherine. And thank you for taking the time.

What is the situation there power wise for folks?

CATHERINE STEMPIEN, DUKE ENERGY: So, we're already seeing significant outages all across our system up on the Panhandle. We're predicting about 100,000 to 200,000 households and businesses that are customers of Duke Energy Florida will be losing their power as a result of this system.

Additionally, we expect maybe an additional 100,000 customers from the local electric cooperative, the municipalities who receive their electricity from Duke Energy will also be affected, because we're anticipating significant damage to our transmission system in the area.

CAVUTO: Now, I know it's hard to compare Florence with this and different storms. Florence hung around a while, less so with Michael.

How does that factor into when you get things back up and running?

STEMPIEN: Well, we're currently anticipating it could take days or maybe even more than a week for us to really get customers back online.

This system, with the winds of over 150,000 -- 150 miles per hour, in addition to significant storm surge and flooding, is really impacting, submerging our systems, damaging equipment that are powering entire communities,. We really see that, in some areas, we're going to have to rebuild our entire electrical system. And that's going to take some time.

CAVUTO: Yes, and that's that's a long-haul effort, as you said here.

I'm wondering, too, given the fact that fewer than half those in the affected areas -- or affected areas decided to evacuate, as the governor had urged, does that complicate things for you?

STEMPIEN: Well, it certainly does.

And I would like to thank Governor Scott for his leadership here in declaring a state of emergency for storm-impacted areas. And we're working very closely with the governor and his team to prioritize critical facilities and also working closely with the Department of Transportation to coordinate on road clearing.

But our ability to access some of those areas is really going to depend -- it's really going to hamper our ability to recover and to rebuild the system.

CAVUTO: Having said all of that, Catherine, you can't minimize the work that's ahead of you and your folks and the region.

Are you breathing somewhat of a sigh of relief? It was envisioned to be, certainly when it came in, much worse.

STEMPIEN: Well, we're still seeing impacts of the storm, so I don't think we are through this storm yet. And, of course, it's going to continue to impact areas of Georgia and up through the Carolinas, many of which are the same communities that were just impacted by Hurricane Florence.

CAVUTO: All right.

STEMPIEN: So I don't feel like we're out of the woods yet.

I would like to make sure to encourage people who were in Florida to be safe, to call 911 if they need any critical assistance, and to be communicating with their local EOCs, which they can find information about on FloridaDisaster.org for more information.

CAVUTO: Catherine Stempien, thank you. Wise words, all. We appreciate it.

I'm sure your customers appreciate it.

All right, so about 100,000 to 200,000 without power now. Whether that escalates, some say it will -- you don't know who's right on this. I know, with Florence, it exponentially went on, as the night and the storm went on. That was a slow mover. This is more serious, but faster. So you take your bets.

All right, Hurricane Michael, though, is still barrelling through Florida. And now Georgia is next in its sights. And as a number of folks were warning at FEMA and beyond, do not take this lightly in Georgia, and do not take it lightly if you're well inland. It is still packing a punch -- after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Well, it looks like Michael has Georgia on its mine.

Steve Harrigan is in Macon, Georgia, with the latest.

Hey, Steve.

STEVE HARRIGAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Neil, the storm may have made landfall in Florida about 200 miles away from here, but it's really just beginning in the state of Florida.

It intends to enter the state of Florida as a Category 2 hurricane, then weakened to a Category 1 hurricane, before weakening further to a tropical storm.

That means, across the state of Georgia, we're going to see major structural damage, damage to roofs, buildings, houses, power lines down, electricity out, and perhaps part of the agriculture here devastated, especially that peanut crop.

So they were really taken by surprise a little bit here, because this storm got more powerful very quickly over the Gulf of Mexico. We heard the FEMA administrator say this morning Georgia has to wake up to the danger ahead. It is waking up quickly to that danger. While there are no mandatory evacuations planned, a state of emergency has been declared, and the National Guard has been mobilized -- Neil, back to you.

CAVUTO: Steve Harrigan, thank you very, very much.

Of course, Steve will be watching that as it moves its way into Georgia.

So this thing isn't over. And neither is this sell-off at the corner of Wall and Broad. It was a big one today.

Let's look at where this stacks up against other big hits in the Dow. This is just in point terms, that today's would rank third, but between what happened back in the early days of this year, when we were going through the same sort of conundrum here and were worried about interest rates.

I should add that, in percentage terms, about -- the 3 percent falloff today wouldn't even crack the top 10, dare I say the top 15 of hits to the Dow.

But it is real, it is nasty and it is built on the idea interest rates are going up because the economy keeps moving up. That would normally be a good thing, but not so right now, when people worry about, how high is high?

Tough to get a home loan. Tougher to get a mortgage loan. Tough to get any sort of loan. And, in that environment, they sell.

We will see tonight with futures and foreign trading.
