urn:contentItem:40F9-BB40-009B-G17B-00000-00Dow Rises 77.29 to 10,812.86; Nasdaq Climbs 82.89 to 3,839.26; Judge Orders Breakup of Microsoft2000-06-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisCNN STREET SWEEP 15:59BusinessSHOW00060700V61Dow Rises 77.29 to 10,812.86; Nasdaq Climbs 82.89 to 3,839.26; Judge Orders Breakup of MicrosoftTerry Keenan, Rhonda Schaffler, John Metaxas, Steve Young, Patricia Sabga, Lou Waters, Stuart Varney, Myron Kandel, Katherine Barrett, Bob Beard, Pat Kiernan, Roger Cossack

The Dow Jones industrial average Wednesday rose 77.29 to 10,812.86 while the Nasdaq climbed 82.89 to 3,839.26. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has ordered that Microsoft be broken up into two companies.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

TERRY KEENAN, CNN ANCHOR: You are looking at live pictures from here at the New York Stock Exchange. We are less than 60 seconds away from the closing bell.

And good afternoon, everyone. I'm Terry Keenan, in for Jan Hopkins.

Let's find out how the markets are doing in this final minute of trading.

RHONDA SCHAFFLER, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Dow Industrials set to close with a pretty respectable gain, even on the day that Wall Street awaits word from Microsoft.

JOHN METAXAS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm John Metaxas at the Nasdaq. The Nasdaq managing a 2 percent gain on a very quiet trading session, but the attention shifts to Microsoft -- the judge's ruling due out in about a half hour.

STEVE YOUNG, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Steve Young, at U.S. District Court in Washington, where indeed Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson is expected in about half an hour to issue the landmark antitrust final judgment breaking up the world's biggest software company, Microsoft.

PATRICIA SABGA, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Patricia Sabga at the JavaOne conference in San Francisco. We spoke with Scott McNealy, CEO of Sun Microsystems and Bill Gates' biggest rival. Hear what he has to say about Microsoft.

KEENAN: And President Clinton orders Medicare to increase its coverage for senior citizens.

It's Wednesday, June 7th, and you're watching STREET SWEEP.

Stocks rose in the last hour of trading today, as investors continued to wait for the historic antitrust ruling against Microsoft. CEO Bill Gates says his company will survive if it's broken up, but that it will slow innovation in the computer industry.

Gates, one of the richest men in the country, just minutes away from finding out the fate as a judge has decided for his company at the U.S. District Courthouse in Washington, D.C. If Microsoft is the 800-pound gorilla of the software business, it doesn't mean there aren't a lot of other smaller meaner predators out there hoping to take a bite out of the business, or take the business away entirely. You might call them the "ABM" crowd: Anyone But Microsoft. And their rallying cry is Java and they are rallying today in San Francisco at JavaOne.

That's where "THE N.E.W. SHOW" anchor Patty Sabga is and she spoke with one of Bill Gates' biggest competitors and critics.

And, Patty, what did he have to say?

SABGA: Hi, Terry.

Well, we're here at JavaOne in San Francisco. Now, outside of the DOJ, this is probably ground zero of anti-Microsoft sentiment. Java, of course, is the programming language that you write once and run anywhere, from a Microsoft Windows PC to a Macintosh. It was developed by Sun Microsystems, released about five years ago, and it is a grenade that was lobbed directly at the heart of the Microsoft- Windows monopoly.

Now, yesterday, we sat down with Scott McNealy. He is the CEO of Sun Microsystems, and we asked him if he thinks Microsoft should be split up.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SCOTT MCNEALY, CHAIRMAN & CEO, SUN MICROSYSTEMS: I would -- yes, I'd get the chainsaw out. But I don't think -- you know, IBM didn't need to be split up. They were very responsible, very willing -- not happy about it, but certainly willing and eager to implement the judge's wishes, if you will, in their antitrust scrutiny.

Microsoft is: to heck with them -- very remorseless. I mean, it's just a very, very different group. So I don't think conduct and cajoling and consent decree kind of remedies will work. I think structural is the only way that it will work with that particular situation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SABGA: And then of course the other question too has to be, if we do get a split with Microsoft, Microsoft's stocks will suffer and it's indisputable. As Microsoft stock heads south, so too does the Nasdaq. And a lot of other big tech names get beaten up as well. So in effect, couldn't the punishment of Microsoft come back and hurt Sun?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCNEALY: I'm not sure I buy that logic. I think Sun has done quite well despite or -- no matter what happens to Microsoft. And I think other companies do very well. I think investors have choice. And they'll go with where the market opportunities are. And sure it was great, and it was a wonderful gravy train to be able to invest in a monopolist. And that is not a great, brilliant investment strategy. It works, but that's not necessarily what I would call, you know, a really insightful investment strategy.

If that's no longer available to them, they'll have to invest in competitive companies. We've proven our ability to actually make money and provide a great return to our shareholders even in the face of a monopolist. I think it will be even better when we have full choice back in the marketplace.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SABGA: Again, Terry, that was from yesterday. And of course that was Scott McNealy's most recent statement to the press as we all await Judge Jackson's final judgment in this landmark case -- Terry.

KEENAN: And somehow, I think he's probably still calling the same tune today, Patty. I know you canvassed the feeling there at JavaOne. What's everyone saying?

SABGA: It's actually sort of a mixed feeling here at JavaOne. Some people feel that innovation has just gone on, and that really Microsoft hasn't really hurt it. Bear in mind, there are over 330 companies that are exhibiting here at JavaOne, and there are over two million programmers who are working with the language that was released just five years ago.

Now others feel, however, that it will actually help innovation, And of course, one person we talked to said, ironically enough, if it weren't for Microsoft, than none of this would have ever taken place. Because Java, remember, was developed to strike right at the heart of the Windows monopoly -- Terry.

KEENAN: OK, thank you, Patty -- Patty Sabga.

Well, as we said, the Microsoft ruling is expected at 4:30 p.m. and we will bring it to you live. The Department of Justice has scheduled a 5:00 p.m. news conference, which will also be seen right here on CNN.

Let's go to our Steve Young, who is at the U.S. District Courthouse, awaiting today's ruling.

And Steve, what can we expect?

YOUNG: Well, Terry, I expect that Judge Jackson is on the second floor at that end of the building behind me, which houses the District Court. It's taken as a given that he's going to order a breakup of the company. The only cliffhanger is whether it will be into two parts or three. He expressed interest in three-part break up, but the government said that would be too intrusive, would take too long to implement. And it asked in its the final, proposed judgment that the company split in two.

Antitrust watchers are looking for something else. It was widely held last week by antitrust experts that the judge may have blundered in cutting short the final, or so-called remedy phase, in not allowing Microsoft to put on witnesses to try to argue against a breakup. The antitrust experts want to see and they're waiting closely to see if the judge attaches a reasoned explanation along with the, really, the boiler plate that was in his word processor, put there by the Department of Justice and the 19 states that are suing the government -- Terry.

KEENAN: OK, thank you very much, Steve. And of course we will be checking back in with you later in the hour -- Steve Young.

It has been more than 100 weeks since this case began and in less than 30 minutes, we will have that final historic antitrust decision on Microsoft.

For some market perspective on today's ruling, I'm joined by Phil Dow. He's the market strategist with Dain Rauscher Wessels. And for the legal viewpoint, we have John Coffee onboard. He is a professor at Columbia University.

And gentlemen, welcome.

Phil, let me start with you, because all through the 1990's, Microsoft was a bellwether stock, and perhaps the quintessential stock of this bull market. It has faltered. It's down 45 percent. How much of that is because of the Justice Department?

PHIL DOW, DAIN RAUSCHER WESSELS: I think a part of it's due to the Justice Department. I think you have emotional content when the government gets involved. But I think we've got to separate Microsoft the stock from Microsoft the company. And my feeling is that the outcome, regardless of what the judges decides, is going to be positive for the stock longer-term. I think investors should own this company.

KEENAN: Interesting, because a lot of negative sentiment -- you think once this cloud is kind of pushed aside, that then the fundamentals of the company can shine through?

DOW: I think first we'll have a little bit of quiet and some of the emotion will die down, but I think people will begin to recognize that this company is going to probably be the one that delivers seamless access to the Internet with your handheld device, with your PC, and is kind of still a solid solution company.

To me the biggest problem the company faces is keeping employees and recruiting employees.

KEENAN: John Coffee, what should we be looking for when we see the judge's ruling? It seems a fairly foregone conclusion that we will see a breakup of the company in the judge's decree. What else should we be looking for?

JOHN COFFEE, COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY LAW SCHOOL: I'd say focus on the conduct remedies because that's where the greatest question marks lie. The divestiture issue is going to have longrun significance, but it's not going affect anything next week or next month. Microsoft could however be significantly changed in its ability to compete. It may have to disclose its source code, may have to give a common price to all equipment manufacturers, may have to change the way in which it markets its Windows, offering a stripped-down, bare bones model as well as a high tech model, with all the applications.

All of that is going to change the nature of competition in this industry, and one of the biggest questions will be whether those conduct remedies go into force next week or whether they're going to be stayed, either by the court or by an appellate court.

KEENAN: OK, hold that thought. Stay put -- to both of you, continue to be with us throughout the program.

We want to go to Midtown Manhattan right now and bring in John Metaxas. He's been following Microsoft's stock today at the Nasdaq marketsite.

And John, we had a little pop to the upside.

METAXAS: That's right. The Microsoft news that's coming out within the half hour, an overhang to the market today, overshadowing what went on today.

We had a very decent two percent gain in the Nasdaq, but it was one of the quieter sessions of the year -- up 82 points to 3839 -- closing with strength, 1.4 billion shares changing hands.

Despite all the concerns about what the remedy for Microsoft will be, the stock managed the rally today, or a mini-rally -- up 7/8's or 1.3 percent. If you take a look at where Microsoft has traded since the beginning of the year, hit its high at just under 120 dollars at the beginning of the year. It's been a downward slope since then, hitting close to $60 a share a few days ago. That would be a decline of 50 percent. The stock has started to come up with rest of the Nasdaq. So the question for investors is, has the market figured in the worse for Microsoft at this point?

Nasdaq was up 82, at 3839. Back to you, Terry.

KEENAN: OK, thanks a lot, John. Just ahead, a rally here on the New York Stock Exchange.

Let's go to Rhonda Schaffler on the floor for the latest -- Rhonda.

SCHAFFLER: Hi there, Terry.

A pretty decent close to the day, all things considering, and Microsoft being one of those things. We had a couple of developments late in the day. Some of the other techs really stepped up to the plate here. Hewlett-Packard and IBM had some pretty decent gains -- Goldman Sachs making some upbeat comments about the prospects for IBM's revenues.

So that helped things out here, along with the fact that financial stocks throughout the day had been performing pretty well. So the Dow did manage to close with a gain. A lot of traders here are saying people are looking forward to getting this Microsoft story -- having a little bit of closure for now on it. People are very curious to see how that stock is going to be performing tomorrow as well -- Terry.

KEENAN: OK, thank you, Rhonda.

We'll have much more on the impending Microsoft decision as we wait for that 4:30 ruling from the judge in Washington. We'll take you there live for that.

And still ahead, President Clinton orders Medicare to beef up its coverage for seniors.

Details and the news headlines up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

KEENAN: Still awaiting the historic Microsoft antitrust ruling, which is due out within minutes. As we continue canvassing reaction from around the country, We go back to San Francisco. This time we bring in computer journalist Michael Fitzgerald of RedHerring.com.

Michael, welcome.

Bottom line, what do you think this ruling will mean for computer users?

MICHAEL FITZGERALD, REDHERRING.COM: Bottom line is we don't think it matters to the average consumer, to you, or me or our parents. You can make some arguments that it might matter to corporate users in certain areas, but it seems to us most of the people who are making those arguments are just a bunch of Cassandras.

KEENAN: What about the competition? Anybody benefit competitionwise?

FITZGERALD: You can argue that if Microsoft takes their eye off the ball because of this or gets distracted that it's going to help Sun or it's going to help Oracle. I think Microsoft has in the database market kept Oracle honest. But, you know, by and large, it certainly doesn't hurt them, let's just put it that way. But I don't think it necessarily helps them either, because you can certainly make a strong case for saying that Microsoft split up this way could be even more aggressive in certain areas than it is right now, depending on what the ruling actually says.

KEENAN: Microsoft all along has taken a very belligerent attitude toward the Justice Department. Steve Ballmer even said back in 1997, "The heck with Janet Reno." Do you think that the company regrets taking such a tough stance?

FITZGERALD: I didn't think so at all. In fact, one of my colleague was arguing that he thinks Microsoft really wants to be broken up; they just don't want to do it themselves. I wouldn't go that far, but I think that you're seeing from Microsoft is this is a company that grew up in the '80s. It's fundamental way of doing business, which is to add things that were not invented here and figure out how to integrate things in its fundamental way of being an operating system company is being challenged, and they're reacting like wounded, cornered animals, and that's what they feel like is happening to them.

KEENAN: You know, Microsoft is one of the earliest users of stock and stock options as compensation for its employees, and of course, as we've just seen, the stock a terrible performer this year, almost cut in half. Do you think that going forward Microsoft is going to have trouble hanging on to its key employees?

FITZGERALD: Well, I think there's a burnout factor, but let's remember, this case is not the only thing affecting their stock. They had a quarterly earnings announcement in the middle of this episode that, you know, where they did their normal kind of gloom-and-doom forecast for future earnings, and for once, the market kind of looked at them and said, you know, they're right, we don't think they're going to be as able to beat our estimates as solidly they had been this past. So I think that that has also factored into what's happening with their stock.

And you know, in terms of a talent perspective, let's not forget the whole Nasdaq was down, you know, a lot of the startups that were throwing, you know, get-rich-quick options at people, don't really have that ability anymore. So that remains to be seen from the options perspective. I don't think they're particularly damaged right now. Despite the drop-off in the stock, it's still a very good stock.

If they really were concerned about it, they could also start paying dividends to people, which clearly makes people more interested in your stock.

KEENAN: All right, thank you very much, Michael, we appreciate it, Michael Fitzgerald of RedHerring.com. We have this quick programming note for you: Be sure to tune in to the "MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR" at 6:30 this evening. Bill Gates will be the guest.

And let's go to Atlanta now and check some other headlines making news this afternoon.

Lou, good afternoon.

LOU WATERS, CNN ANCHOR: Hello, Terry,

An executive order from President Clinton will make it easier for older Americans to take part in clinical trials. The president's directive covers the 40 million Americans now in the Medicare program. It requires the program to reimburse recipients who take part in eligible clinical trials. Under the current policy, Medicare does not cover the costs of chemical trials designed to test new drugs or treatments.

If you are an AT&T customer, your long distance phone bill may be going up -- or it may be going down. AT&T is raising per-minute rates during certain hours for millions of customers who are not on discount plans, but AT&T says it also is lowering its Sunday rates 40 percent. The company also says the savings from a reduction in access fees will be passed along to consumers.

A new concern for cell phone users, if your cell phone can display text messages, it could become victim of a new cyber-virus. The new bug is similar to the ILOVEYOU virus we've been telling you about that recently was spread by e-mail to computer systems around the world. This latest bug was originally written to attack a Spanish-based cell phone network.

A face familiar to Americans during the gulf War Has faded away. The Army general who served as a Desert Storm spokesman for the Pentagon has died. Retired Lt. Gen. Thomas Kelly was 67. He suffered from cancer for about a year. General Kelly earned numerous awards and decorations. More news anytime. I'm Lou Waters.

Now back to Terry in New York.

KEENAN: OK, thank you, Lou.

We are still on alert for the landmark Microsoft ruling. As soon as we have it, you'll have it.

We'll also bring you some of the highlights of today's market action from both the Nasdaq and here at the New York Stock Exchange.

STREET SWEEP continues in just a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

KEENAN: Let's take a quick trip down the stairs to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange and Rhonda Schaffler for a look at some the Big Board movers. And that $8 move in IBM certainly caught my eye.

SCHAFFLER: Yes, it really helped out the Dow here late in the day. First, let's tell you about General Motors Hughes Electronics stock. That one was actually down. We had a brokerage downgrade on the stock, with Soundview lowering the rating to hold from buy. Yesterday, GM set a three-for-one split GMH stock. As far as IBM goes, this was a big contributor to the Dow's advance. Late in the day, some comments coming from Goldman Sachs analysts quite positive about IBM's revenue prospects. The stock really took off late in the session, and it was the best performing Dow stock and also came on a day where some of the other techs were a bit mixed.

One other stock that was a high flier was KLM Royal Dutch Air. This stock a little bit less than 10 percent. It confirmed persistent rumors that it's talking with British Airways about an alliance, just talking, no assurance that a deal will be reached. There is no deal until it is on paper.

Beyond that ING Barings raised KLM to hold from sell. So that stock got a lift on that news -- Terry.

KEENAN: OK, thanks a lot, Rhonda. Rhonda Schaffler. Let's go uptown again to the Nasdaq marketsite and see how Microsoft stock finished out the day. Let's bring in John Metaxas -- John.

METAXAS: Well, Terry, Microsoft stock up 7/8 on the day at 70 1/2. And as we look at the stock in after-hours trading, it's trading up another quarter dollar at 70 3/4. Just moments away -- or I should say minutes away -- from that anticipated ruling from Judge Jackson.

Nasdaq had a very quiet, but good session today. Semiconductor, Internet, many of the financial stocks doing well, including some of the online brokers.

But perhaps the story of the day was the Microsoft competitors, as attention shifts to them. Sun Microsystems -- we just heard Scott McNealy earlier in the program -- creators of the Java programming platform up 4 7/16 today. Oracle, the largest database software company in the world, up nearly $3 a share, a gain of nearly 4 percent on the day. Apple Computer has long been a competitor of Microsoft, with their Mac operating system, basically the only other operating system out there for PCs -- or I should say before Linux came along. But Apple up 4 percent on the day.

But the biggest gains were for those Linux stocks, and we had Red Hat up 17 1/2 percent, one of the leading Linux operating system makers. Corel surging 30 percent, a gain of more than a dollar a share. They are a software vendor for the Linux operating system.

So some good individual moves here, and a decent day for the Nasdaq ahead of that Microsoft announcement.

KEENAN: That's for sure. Thanks, John.

OK, let's check what's going on in after-hours trading. Pat Kiernan is standing by at the Instinet trading desk in midtown Manhattan -- Pat.

KIERNAN: I'm sorry, this picture's going to come into clearer focus about 10 minutes from now, I guess. But we are seeing fairly active trading in Microsoft even before the judge's ruling comes out: 828,000 shares have traded on Instinet since 4 o'clock on Microsoft. And it is about in-line with the close at 4 o'clock. Microsoft up 1/8 right now from the 4 o'clock close at 70 5/8.

You heard John mention some of the competitors. In Instinet trading, Oracle since 4 o'clock has gained 1/16 trading at 80 1/16. And Linux, VA Linux Systems, trading up here after hours, up 3/8 at 38 1/8 -- Terry.

KEENAN: OK, thanks a lot, Pat.

Let's see what "MONEYLINE" has in store for tonight's coverage of the Microsoft decision, in addition to a man who might have something to say about the case, Bill Gates.

Here's our Stuart Varney -- Stuart. STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Well, you're absolutely right, Terry. Tonight on MONEYLINE, we're going to discuss the most successful company in a generation, facing punishment from the government. In the relationship between government and business, there is no bigger case than this one. So we're going to speak directly with Bill Gates about this landmark decision. We're going to find out how he will reassure investors, how he plans to fight back on appeal, and how he feels personally about the potential breakup of the company that he founded.

There are, of course, Microsoft opponents, and we will be speaking to one of them. For him it's payback time. We're going to hear from a former Netscape chief executive, Jim Barksdale. He once predicted that this would be the century's most important ruling, and he will be on our air tonight.

That's "MONEYLINE": 6:30 p.m. Eastern.

Back to you, Terry.

KEENAN: OK, see you then, Stuart. And coming up: just minutes away from the Department of Justice's historic decision. And our financial editor, Myron Kandel, is going to take a look back at some major breakups in American business history.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL EISNER, CHAIRMAN & CEO, WALT DISNEY: I think Microsoft is a great company. I think they've done an unbelievable service to the entire Information Age. They're innovators. I would hope that whatever they end up doing with Microsoft doesn't leave them in a way that they can't continue being that way.

Have they done some things wrong? Has their behavior been a little aggressive? I guess it has, and I guess there should be some retribution for that. But I wouldn't want to bring the whole company down on its knees.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KEENAN: All right, that was comments -- exclusive comments here on CNN -- by Disney CEO Michael Eisner about judgment day for Microsoft. And we're just getting word here that Microsoft will be holding a news conference at 5:00 p.m. Eastern Time, as will the Justice Department following Judge Penfield Jackson's ruling at 4:30 p.m.

Will the Justice Department add Microsoft to the list of companies split up in the past? That answer, of course, is just a couple minutes away. But what is the history of breakups, and what have they brought to giant companies and their founders?

Our Myron Kandel takes a look from our New York studios -- Myron. MYRON KANDEL, CNN FINANCIAL EDITOR: Well, Terry, of course the first great breakup was a Standard Oil Trust, owned by John D. Rockefeller. And what happened then in 1911 under President Teddy Roosevelt and the trust-busters, that company -- that trust was broken up into 34 different companies. Rockefeller became even wealthier, owning all those pieces.

The next one was in the early '80s when AT&T was forced to divest seven "Baby Bells." Investors who held on to those shares did very well in the years ahead. So if that's any portent of what might happen with Microsoft, maybe investors don't have that much to worry about, Terry.

We worked hard. I believe we worked in the public interest, and I believe we did our best.

Today's opinion -- today's order by Judge Jackson, I believe is strong, but yet fair and measured. And that combination, strong, fair and measured, produces a good remedy.

It's strong, because it does break up the company into two companies. It's strong in certain aspects of the conduct relief, but yet it's fair.

It's fair for a number of reasons, let me mention two. One is Microsoft had a lot of warning. They had the FTC proceeding. They had the consent decree proceeding, and then as Judge Jackson found, in spite of that, they had repeated serious violations.

The other reason it's fair is because what the evidence showed that Microsoft, when they were confronted with important and perhaps difficult competition, their resort was to their monopoly; to use that in an illegal way to maintain that monopoly or to use it in other ways. It was not reaching for a better product or for innovation. It was reaching for that crutch -- that illegal crutch. So it's fair in that situation.

And it's measured, because, as was discussed in the May 24 hearing, it could have been more, it could have been stronger, it could have been three companies, it could have been broken up into the baby Bills, but this is the least intrusive of the divestitures that are possible. And that has two important consequences in its measured qualities.

One is that the question of compatibility that some consumers rightly are very concerned about is not put in jeopardy. And secondly, it maintains the highest possible shareholder value, probably increases shareholder value in the opinion of many experts.

I looked at the Wall Street Journal yesterday. It showed what happened to AT&T when it was broken up and the enormous increase in shareholder value. That potential is here as well.

It's the right remedy because of those qualities: strong, fair and measured. Right for consumers. Consumers always benefit by competition, they never benefit by monopoly. Consumers, most of all, will have greater choice, they'll have additional products, they may pay lower prices. They probably will have better service.

KEENAN: All right, you have been listening to the team that spearheaded the U.S. government's case against Microsoft from the Justice Department, a news conference that began with Attorney General Janet Reno wholeheartedly endorsing Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's decision this afternoon to break Microsoft into two separate companies. The attorney general saying that such a move would boost competition in the software industry; other Justice Department lawyers saying that it would stimulate innovation and that both companies if indeed there were to be a divestiture after appeal, both companies would be vibrant and successful firms.

We now want to go back to Washington and our Steve Young, who of course has been following this case all along. And, Steve, to listen to some of the Justice Department lawyers, it sort of sounds like parents scolding a bad child when they speak about Microsoft here?

YOUNG: That's right, Terry. They regard Microsoft as a recidivist. It occurred to me as I was listening Microsoft was the world's biggest software company. If it holds up on appeal, it no longer will be; that will be IBM. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, the man who did this, left the courthouse at about 5:00 straight up Eastern Time with nary a word, he got into his car, and he drove away. He has started the clock ticking. Microsoft has four months from today, no matter what else happens, to come up with a plan to reorganize itself as the government used to say. Now they use the divestiture word, and it has 90 days before further proceedings in this matter -- Terry. KEENAN: All right, thank you very much, Steven. We should just quickly stress that no breakup is imminent. Microsoft does have the right to appeal that portion of this before there are any breakup was put into effect. That's going to do it for our coverage from the New York Stock Exchange on judgment day for Microsoft. For CNN viewers, INSIDE POLITICS is up next. And on CNNfn, "THE N.E.W. SHOW."

urn:contentItem:42VP-2P20-009B-G4BW-00000-00Dow Rises 77.75 to 10,693.58; Nasdaq Climbs 102.70 to 2,182.14; Microsoft Beats Profit Forecasts2001-04-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30Ronald Hill, Bob Herbold, Lakshman AchuthanBusinessSHOW01041900V19Dow Rises 77.75 to 10,693.58; Nasdaq Climbs 102.70 to 2,182.14; Microsoft Beats Profit ForecastsWillow Bay, Susan Lisovicz, Steve Young, Bruce Francis, Bob Franken, Terry Keenan, Jen Rogers, Peter Viles, Allan Dodds Frank, Myron Kandel

A tech rally gave Wall Street a boost today. The Nasdaq gained ground for the seventh time in eight sessions, and even more impressive, stocks today were able to build on yesterday's huge gains that followed the Fed's surprise rate cut.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: The rate-cut rally rolls on for a second straight day. It's Thursday, April 19.

The Nasdaq turns in another explosive rally. Is the bear market over in techs?

Microsoft muscles past profit forecasts, unveiling a winning quarter. We'll pore over the results with Bob Herbold.

And, is New York City facing a California-style power crunch? Could summer heat burn out the Big Apple's electric grid?

ANNOUNCER: This is MONEYLINE. Reporting tonight from New York, Willow Bay.

BAY: Good evening, and welcome to MONEYLINE.

We begin tonight with a supercharged tech rally on Wall Street. The Nasdaq gained ground for the seventh time in eight sessions. Even more impressive, stocks today were able to build on yesterday's huge gains that followed the Fed's surprise rate cut. If Alan Greenspan was holding out to achieve maximum impact, it appears he succeeded.

The Nasdaq today surged another 5 percent, or 102 points, to 2,182, on volume of nearly 2.8 billion shares. And that tech tide helped lift blue chips. After an up-and-down day, the Dow posted a late charge to end 77 points higher at 10,693.

The upswing extended to the broader market, the S&P 500 gaining 15 points, or more than 1 percent. The recent run-up in techs is so strong, it has some on Wall Street wondering if this is the birth of a new bull market.

Susan Lisovicz reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): If Alan Greenspan was the catalyst for Wall Street's mid-week bull run, technology profits were the force behind the follow-through.

Strong reports from IBM, Apple Computer, and Advanced Micro Devices sent investors on a tech buying spree. Chip stocks like PMC Sierra soared 8, while Applied Materials jumped 5. But it was strength in tech stocks across the board that encouraged many observers.

JIM GLICKENHAUS, GLICKENHAUS & CO.: Some of the information we're getting out of Intel, out of Altera, out of other tech companies is saying maybe, maybe, maybe there's light at the end of the tunnel. I'm more hopeful.

LISOVICZ: That improving sentiment has been apparent for most of this month, propelling the Nasdaq 33 percent higher from its April 4th low, which, by some yardsticks, confirms the onset of a bull market.

MICHAEL BALOG, BANC OF AMERICA SECURITIES: That's very much reminiscent of the bullish days that you saw a lot in the '90s -- the sense that people are around to buy stocks on the weakness is back a little bit in the marketplace.

LISOVICZ: And some of the biggest beneficiaries of recent buying: Apple Computer up 83 percent from its 52-week low. EMC up 70 percent. Oracle up 54 percent, and IBM up 33 percent.

But the index which measures most tech stocks, the Nasdaq composite, is still down nearly 12 percent year-to-date, and off nearly 57 percent since its high last March.

JOE BATTIPAGLIA, GRUNTAL & CO.: There are those who are looking for a capitulation to come into the market, for a huge bear sentiment, etcetera, etcetera. But I like to point out that we've had one of the most destructive losses of paper capital, $4 trillion, over the last year, which is indeed pain and suffering, no matter how you want to define it.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LISOVICZ: Some analysts say investors were waiting for two pieces of the puzzle to come together: signs that the economy wasn't falling off a cliff, and evidence that there is demand for products and services that tech companies provide.

Investors got what they were waiting for this week with the Fed's intervention and some solid corporate earnings, but there are still plenty of more report cards in the offing that could quickly undo that newfound optimism -- Willow.

BAY: Yeah, a note of caution. Thank you.

LISOVICZ: Sure.

BAY: Well, more good news for the tech sector came after the bell when Microsoft blew past a Street forecast. The software titan said it earned 44 cents a share, or nearly $2.5 billion in the quarter.

In after-hours action, Microsoft is up more than 3.5, at 71.70, after gaining more than $2 in the regular session.

Now, Steve Young has been listening to the conference call, and he joins us now -- Steve.

STEVE YOUNG, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Willow, Microsoft didn't exactly beat its breast in triumph, but it had reason to crow, and the company does say it's pleased.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

YOUNG (voice-over): In its latest financial results, Microsoft scored a respectable triple, but hardly a home run. Its earnings were two cents better than expected. Sales gained 14 percent, a bit more than many had thought. And the outlook was somewhat reassuring, but the company cautioned that could change. And new business isn't picking up as fast as before.

GREG VOGEL, BANC OF AMERICA SECURITIES: They knocked the cover off the ball, is a very positive quarter. It's still slower growth than what, over the last few years, Microsoft has been growing at. But that's to be expected.

YOUNG: The economic slowdown is hurting chip and PC companies, but Microsoft benefited from the sale of software upgrades for computers already sold. It said results were strong across all businesses, especially growing demand for Windows 2000 and its server software for the business community.

Looking ahead, the company projects sales in its next and final quarter of its fiscal year will be flat to slightly down, which could mean sales will grow about only 10 percent this year. But Microsoft is usually conservative, and results might top that.

MARK HERSKOVITZ, DREYFUS PREMIER FUNDS: They're going to come out with a new operating system, Windows XP. The outloook is good there. We've heard promising comments from Dell, from Intel, that there is some increase in demand for PCs. That's very, very helpful to Microsoft.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

YOUNG: On its conference call, the company said, though, the ad market is soft, it's racked up single-digit growth in online ad dollars. And it claimed its dot-net strategy to be a power seller of Internet services, is gaining developer support, and buying share -- Willow.

BAY: Steve, what about cautionary notes? Any at all?

YOUNG: Almost none. CFO John Conner was asked about the general economy. He said if it doesn't pick up even more, there may be a slower uptake, but he did not seem overly concerned.

BAY: Interesting. Steve Young, thanks.

After the after-hours, the news was not all positive. Nortel Networks announced that it lost 12 cents a share, or $385 million in the quarter, in line with forecasts. But the Canadian Telecom equipment supplier said it would cut an additional 5,000 jobs on top of previously announced layoffs of 15,000.

And more bad news from Gateway, which reported a first-quarter loss of $503 million and took a charge of more than a half billion dollars. The PC maker said it expected to break even in the second quarter and get back to profitability in the second half of the year. Neither stock, though, making much of a move after hours.

But for now, tech investors have been focused on the positive. As of today, the Nasdaq has surged 33 percent over the past sessions. So are tech stocks out of the woods? For some perspective, we are joined by Ron Hill, equity strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman.

Ron, welcome.

RONALD HILL, BROWN BROTHERS HARRIMAN: Nice to be here, Willow.

BAY: Did the Fed cut yesterday officially usher in a bull market?

HILL: I think they sort of got us all started here. We would have liked to see more volume, I think, on the New York Stock Exchange in a big, sort of more breadth, nine-to-one kind of day.

BAY: That volume is something you've been looking for for a while, correct?

HILL: Indeed. So we were hoping to get more. And again, today, volume was off a little bit, but the price action's been pretty good. It's always nice to close at the highs of the day.

BAY: So are you saying yes?

HILL: I'm saying -- yes, I think the bottom has been made. I'm not sure that the first big upthrust of the bull market is still somewhere out in front of us.

BAY: And other than volume, what do we need to see to get us to that first big the upthrust?

HILL: A lot of Positive breadths. A lot of positive breadths. Nine to one, upside volume to downside volume on a good day would really mean that the whole emphasis has gone on the buy side. The sellers are in retreat, essentially.

BAY: What do you think it'll take for us to get to that breadth?

HILL: Well, we're starting to get through the earning season. We're getting more good news than we had before. So we priced in too much bad news, Now we're pricing in some good news. But like we said earlier in the program, there are still more earnings to come, and they're starting to get -- the good stuff comes out early. The bad stuff tends to come later, so let's see if we can get into that.

BAY: As Susan was saying, a note of caution, because we've had quite a number of bright spots. But overall, obviously, the earnings picture this quarter is bleak? HILL: Indeed. Down over double digits, relative to year over year, and probably still going to be pretty bleak in the second quarter. I think when we get the second-quarter earnings, we're going to start getting guidance that things are indeed getting better and that things are on the upswing. The economy will be doing better. That's when I think people will really get convinced. But we'll probably be buying ahead of that.

BAY: You'll be buying ahead of that. And actually, your outlook is quite positive. You expect the S&P to, what, hit -- is it 1,450 by the end of the year?

HILL: 1,450 by the end of the year. That's about 30 percent off the lows.

BAY: So why so positive?

HILL: Well, when they get a big liquidity lift, and when Fed has these -- generates a lot of new cash into this economy, that liquidity comes under this market like a fuel, and you get sort of a lift-off day. And that's usually good for 30 percent off the bottom in the first year. That gets you to 1,450, and that's a poor-quality market. Often, the average is 40 percent gains in the first year.

BAY: So what should investors be doing? You said you were going to be buying ahead of a turnaround. Is that what you think investors should be doing?

HILL: Indeed. I think you should be getting your position -- your portfolio more cyclically orientated. That means looking at some retailers, looking at early cyclical technology stocks, like semiconductor equipment makers and semiconductors. Maybe some software as well.

BAY: All right. So give us some names, some retailers that you like.

HILL: Retailers -- Lowe's, for example, in the home-building area. We also like BJ's, the sort of warehouse retailer. And for high growths, or department store, Kohl's will be a nice one.

BAY: Kohl's is a name that actually comes up often.

And then what about in the techs? You said semis and software?

HILL: Yes, and the equipment makers. Applied Materials, KLA- Tencor have been on fire in this rally. They should be leading you into a whole big tech outperformance. They're starting to do that.

BAY: We know where you come down in this whole chip debate.

HILL: Yes, yes, we think it's going to turn very, very nice here within the next six months or so.

BAY: Ron Hill, thanks for joining us.

HILL: Thank you.

BAY: Next on MONEYLINE: a good news, bad news report from Sun Microsystems, beating estimates on profits, but missing on sales. Bruce Francis will take a look for us.

A brighter picture for Sun's arch rival: inside Microsoft, after the bell report, and the dramatic late-day reaction. We'll talk with Veteran Executive Bob Herbold.

And, New York, racing against time to prevent a replay of the California power crisis. Will they succeed? We'll have a special report.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Wrapping some of tonight's major profit reports: McDonald's suffering from lingering mad cow concerns, profits there tumbling 16 percent. This marks the second consecutive quarter of decline for McDonald's bottom line. Still, CEO Jack Greenberg says he's "cautiously optimistic" for a recovery this year.

Profits plunged at Ford, but following in the footsteps of rival GM, the auto maker did beat expectations. Sears met lowered estimates, but the retailer warned profits will continue to decline in the second quarter.

Data storage king EMC also met lowered expectations. Profits, which surged more than 50 percent last year, climbed a less impressive 20 percent to about 400 million.

A surprise report from Xerox: the beleaguered copier wasn't expected to reveal its numbers until later this month. Xerox posted a narrower-than-expected loss, and said it expects to climb back to profitability this year.

Checking investor reaction: McDonald's, Ford and Sears all lost ground, while EMC added more than 6, and Xerox jumped over $2, or nearly 40 percent.

And another closely watched report came after the bell: Sun Microsystems. It issued quarterly numbers that left tech analysts scratching their heads. At first glance, Sun seemed to beat the Street by one penny, earning eight cents a share, or $263 million, a 43 percent drop from one year ago. But one penny of that came from an accounting change.

In after-hours activity, Sun off a penny, although it was down as much as $1. It's been a rough year for Sun stock, down by about two- thirds from its high.

Bruce Francis listened in on the company's conference call, and has a close look at the numbers. Tell us about it, Bruce.

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Sun is clearly not celebrating this end of the tech recession here. Sun met reduced financial targets by slashing costs, including pay for employees. Now, since many employees get paid on how Sun performs, those costs dropped as Sun's revenue growth rate dropped to polar temperature levels. As for the outlook, many clouds remain. Sun says it isn't calling the bottom yet in its business, unlike competitor H-P. Sun believes that earnings per share will be flat or down in the current quarter, Sun's fourth. Until now, analysts were expecting 10 cents a share.

For fiscal 2002, which begins in June, Sun sees revenue growth of just 15 percent, less than half of what the company was pumping out at the beginning of the current fiscal year. But Sun says that lower growth will come mostly in the back half. That means that Sun is expecting continued weak business condition for much of the next eight months.

Now, analysts say that could -- emphasize "could" -- blunt some of the recent enthusiasm for Sun stock.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEORGE ELLING, LEHMAN BROTHERS: The stock has rallied lately. And I guess -- I mean, I basically thought that they would have to guide down numbers, it was a question of how much. And they did guide down, and they're now looking for only 15 percent growth next year, and that's all going to come in the second half. So, it is going to be somewhat of a sober mood.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FRANCIS: Sun says that it itself is no exception to the trends that are causing their customers to hold back on purchases. CEO Scott McNealy said on that conference call that he too is cutting back on some of Sun's technology projects. So, sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander.

BAY: Now, you noted, Bruce, that H-P did call a bottom and Sun did not. So, what does that mean?

FRANCIS: I think we can be too soon in saying, this was it. Nevertheless, Sun (sic) marketed heavily to telecom and Internet companies. Those were the biggest drops in spending. Sun might be a different case, I think the jury is still going to be out on this one.

BAY: The jury is still going to be out, and what do we need to see to get a sense of conviction about this from Sun?

FRANCIS: I think you need them to come out and say: "OK, we've finally seen a bottom, we are really beginning to see a turnaround. We see less hesitation by big corporate customers on buying." Haven't seen that yet.

BAY: In other words, you need a bit of a consensus out there on this?

FRANCIS: You need a consensus, exactly. BAY: Bruce Francis, thanks.

Coming up: the Mississippi keeps on rising, threatening levees in several states. We'll get the latest on flood conditions with a live report.

Plus, we'll hear from a Microsoft executive Bob Herbold on what drove the software titan past analysts' forecasts.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In tonight's "Tech Watch": some late-breaking news from E- bay. The online auctioneer posted a surge in profits, beating the Street by three cents a share, while revenues nearly doubled $154 million. Topping off the good news, E-bay raised revenue guidance for the second and third quarters, saying the economic downturn is not slowing its growth. In after-hours trading, the stock is up sharply, gaining more than 3 to $53.25.

Just ahead: Mr. Greenspan works his magic on Wall Street, but is he too late to save the economy? We'll talk to one economic forecaster who says we're headed for a recession, and there's nothing the Fed can do about it.

Plus: the latest on flood conditions along the Mississippi, how the levees there are holding up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: As we mentioned, Microsoft powered past market forecasts for both profits and revenue. The company said it earned 44 cents a share, 2 cents ahead of forecasts on a nearly 3 percent rise in profits, and a big rise in revenue, up 14 percent from one year ago.

Microsoft stock, which has had a rough year, has recovered much of its lost ground. It's up more than $3 in after hours trading. In tonight's tech watch we are joined by Microsoft's Bob Herbold, from the company's offices in Redmond, Washington.

Bob, welcome back.

BOB HERBOLD, MICROSOFT: Hi, Willow.

BAY: You had good news on both the top and the bottom line. The PC sector is still, as far as we can tell, struggling. So how did you do it?

HERBOLD: I have to tell you, we have a very broad-based business at this point, and we're benefiting from that. urn:contentItem:42CC-HDY0-009B-G3JV-00000-00Dow Rises 95.61 to 10,891.02; Nasdaq Climbs 61.51 to 2,552.91; Nortel and Dell Announce Layoffs2001-02-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:12ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30Gary Smith, Susan Byrne, Dan NilesBusinessSHOW01021500V19Dow Rises 95.61 to 10,891.02; Nasdaq Climbs 61.51 to 2,552.91; Nortel and Dell Announce LayoffsStuart Varney, Willow Bay, Bruce Francis, Allan Chernoff, Greg Clarkin, Greta Van Susteren, Fred Katayama, Wolf Blitzer, Susan Lisovicz, John Metaxas, Steve Young, Peter Viles, Myron Kandel

The Dow Jones industrial average Thursday rose 95.61 points to 10,891. 02 while the Nasdaq climbed 61.51 to 2,552.91. America's biggest PC maker today said it was slashing 1,700 jobs: This is the first time Dell has cut its work force. The company fell short of profit expectations that were lowered late last month.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight, job cuts at two tech giants: Nortel slashing 10,000 and Dell announcing its first layoffs ever.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: Holding Amazon shares? One analyst has one word of advice: sell. We'll tell you why you don't hear that advice often on Wall Street.

VARNEY: Did Marc Rich conspire to buy a presidential pardon? That explosive question now at the heart of a criminal probe.

BAY: And, the revolving door in the corner office: top execs back in their old jobs to help a company in distress.

ANNOUNCER: Live from coast to coast, this is MONEYLINE.

BAY: Welcome to MONEYLINE. I'm Willow Bay in Los Angeles.

VARNEY: Hello, Willow, and hello, everyone, I'm Stuart Varney in New York.

BAY: Our top story: techs in trouble. Disturbing news late in the day from Nortel, Hewlett-Packard and Dell. We begin with an unprecedented move from Dell, one of the pioneers of the digital age.

America's biggest PC maker today said it was slashing 1,700 jobs: This is the first time Dell has cut its work force. And then there was more bad news after the bell. The company fell short of profit expectations that were lowered late last month. The stock up during the regular session is down more than $1 in after hours trading. Bruce Francis has more on Dell in the doldrums -- Bruce.

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Willow, Dell can't say when those doldrums will end. Dell says that this quarter will be slightly weaker than analyst are expecting, and that beyond that, the company wouldn't provide any guidance.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS (voice-over): The last hold out in the PC industry in layoffs, Dell gave in to declining PC growth rates and announced the firing of 1,700 people, the first layoffs in its 16-year history.

MICHAEL DELL, CHAIRMAN & CEO, DELL COMPUTER: We had some excess facility and those combined together are the charters you see taken in the fourth quarter.

FRANCIS: A look at Dell's plummeting growth rates explains what the company is up against. After growing at around 50 percent for years, Dell's sales increased just 26 percent this year, and estimates call for even less growth next year. Analysts say the company has to adjust accordingly.

ROBERT CIHRA, ING BARINGS: It probably is a wise move, because heading in to a year where demand is certainly uncertain, at best, I think keeping your cost as low as possible is the smartest thing to do.

FRANCIS: Dell also reported earnings that were in line with lower projections, but still a penny short of what Wall Street analysts hoped for. Revenue grew 28 percent. But, as the company slashed prices in PCs, net income rose 16 percent.

CIHRA: The problem is, really the way Dell was able to really grow its top line, was through extremely aggressive pricing, and that cost 3 them about 3 points of margin, which I think is the issue going forward here.

FRANCIS: The PC business is so challenging right now that Dell won't forecast beyond the first quarter, the one we're in now. Dell is projecting 5 percent less revenue and 10 percent less in earnings than analysts currently are expecting.

DELL: Our first quarter guidance is going to be about 8 billion in revenues and roughly 17 cents a share, which on a operating margin percent basis is pretty flat with the fourth quarter.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: Dell said in its earnings report that their performance was in stark contrast with that of the rest of the industry. But that may be damning with faint praise. As analyst Andy Neff likes to point out, Dell right now is the best house in a tough neighborhood -- Stuart.

VARNEY: All right, Bruce Francis reporting. Thanks, Bruce.

Also struggling with sluggish PC sales: Hewlett-Packard. After the bell, that company missed sales targets by more than $400 million. The company did meet already lowered expectations of 37 cents a share, down from a year ago. And those revenues which fell short of analysts estimates, grew only 2 percent from a year ago.

Up nearly 2 points in the regular session, Hewlett-Packard down $1.85 in after hours trading.

Shares of Nortel plunging after hours. Late today, the company said it will layoff as many as 10,000 employees. That's an increase from the 4,000 originally announced in January. The telecom equipment maker also guided 2001 revenue and earnings forecasts sharply lower. Nortel says, an economic downturn in the U.S. will hurt business well into the fourth quarter. In after hours, shares of Nortel down more than 7 1/2 points. Nortel stock is currently off 65 percent from its 52-week high.

BAY: During regular trading, one of Nortel's competitors, Ciena, set off a tech buying binge after issuing a rosy profit report. The blue chips stocks advanced today as well, erasing most of yesterday's losses. The Dow gained 95 points to end at 10,891. The Nasdaq surged more than a hundred points at its high today, closing up 61 1/2 to end just under 2553. The S&P rose 10 to 1326.

The single biggest driver in today's tech rally, as we mentioned: Ciena, which enjoyed the kind of eye-popping gain that we used to see regularly a year ago when the Nasdaq was nearing its peak. Allan Chernoff joins us now with more on just what Ciena said to give investors the green light to buy -- Allan.

ALLAN CHERNOFF, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Willow, Ciena delivered what Wall Street was looking for, and then some. Exactly the kind of bullish news investors wanted to grasp on to.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CHERNOFF (voice-over): After hearing company after company warn of the effects of a slowdown in telecom equipment spending, Ciena's financials lit up Wall Street's switchboard. Revenues actually rose from the prior quarter, up 22 percent. Ciena earned 18 cents a share during its first quarter, up 500 percent from the year-ago period, and three-cents better than the consensus forecast.

And the company raised its forecast for the entire year: 73 to 75 cents a share, which would be more than 260 percent last year's earnings. Ciena's equipment raises the capacity of fiber optic data networks. The company's stock soared more than 12 points to 89, though it's still well off its high of 151 hit last October.

Fiber optics firms jumped in unison, Corning, the top maker of fiber optic cable, JDS Uniphase, the number maker of fiber components, even competitors Lucent and Nortel closed higher.

TRACY EICHLER, PAINEWEBBER: Expectations have come down that when a company reported better than expected earnings and showed that guidance going forward is actually stronger than expected, it gave technology the boost it needed.

CHERNOFF: Data networking shares shot up on optimism from Ciena's results. Extreme, Redback, Network Appliance, Cisco and Juniper. All these stocks have been severely depressed, still trading at fractions of their 52-week highs.

ANGEL MATA, LEGG MASON: I think people want to believe that the worst is over, and that now we can slowly start picking away and buying some of these stocks that have been hammered. Yes, I agree with the fact that, if Ciena's going to do well, then obviously that bodes well for similar stocks.

FRANCIS: And companies providing components for high speed data connectivity through networking joined the party: Emulex, Brocade and Qlogic. (END VIDEOTAPE)

CHERNOFF: Just as Ciena's multiplexers magnify the power of fiber optic cable, Ciena's earnings had a multiplier effect on the Nasdaq. Analysts say, that's partly because the Nasdaq had been deeply oversold. But they warn it'll take more bullish news like Ciena's to keep driving the Nasdaq significantly higher. And Willow, of course we did not get that after the bell.

BAY: No. But Allan, let me ask you, how do you account for the fact that Ciena's business is so robust, yet we get this terrible news today from Nortel?

CHERNOFF: Well, Ciena is very targeted and they are very cost efficient, especially in this type of a market, where people are looking to reduce their expenses, Ciena's business actually helps companies to be very efficient because their equipment helps to, in fact, have that multiplyer effect for fiber optic cable -- to get more bang for the buck from the cable.

BAY: Good job, Allan, thank you.

Well, later in the broadcast, we'll talk with the president of Ciena, Gary Smith, on the company's banner day -- Stuart.

VARNEY: All right, Willow, in political news today the furor over the Marc Rich pardon continues to escalate. U.S. Attorney Mary Jo White confirmed that her office, along with the FBI, has launched a criminal investigation into just why a fugitive trader received a presidential pardon. Greg Clarkin has the latest on the scandal that's the talk of Wall Street and Washington.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GREG CLARKIN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Federal prosecutors in New York today confirmed an investigation into former president Clinton's last minute pardon of Marc Rich and his business partner Pincus Green. Mary Jo White, U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, issued a statement saying:

"Various questions have been raised concerning the activities and pardons of Marc Rich and Pincus Green. The United States attorney's office and the FBI New York office have opened an investigation to determine whether there have been any violations of federal law. There will be no further comment"

In a statement released yesterday, Clinton denied the pardon was bought. In New York today, he put the best face under the investigation.

QUESTION: Mr. Clinton what's your reaction to the Mary Jo White investigation, sir?

CLARKIN: But it may not be so good if federal prosecutors determine money donated to Clinton's library fund and other Democratic causes came from Marc Rich, a fugitive living in Switzerland. Prosecutors will be looking at the role of Denise Rich, Marc Rich's ex-wife, and a major contributor to the Democrats. A former assistant U.S. attorney, says prosecutors, will be examining phone and bank records and anything else that may link donations Denise Rich made to the granting of the pardon.

RANDY MASTRO, GIBSON, DUNN & CRUTCHER: It's always difficult to prove, in a bribery investigation, a quid pro quo relationship. It's also made more difficult in this situation, because, potentially, you're trying to track down funds that come from overseas sources, including Switzerland, which has tough bank secrecy laws.

CLARKIN: But a congressional critic of the pardon says such cases can be built.

SEN. JEFF SESSIONS (R), ALABAMA: I've prosecuted mayors, judges, city councilmen, county commissioners for bribery and extortion under federal statutes. It's not impossible to prove. If money changed hands and people interviewed who are involved with that, their conversations are inquired into. If there's no connection, the facts will so show.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CLARKIN: And key to the federal investigation will be the timing of Denise Rich's contributions. Legal experts say it could take months for prosecutors to comb through the various records to see what, if any, link exists between those donations and this pardon -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Greg Clarkin, thank you very much.

Now, for a closer look at the legal issues at the heart of the Marc Rich uproar, let's go to CNN's legal analyst Greta Van Susteren.

Greta, welcome to MONEYLINE.

GRETA VAN SUSTEREN, CNN LEGAL ANALYST: Thank you, Stuart.

VARNEY: There seems to be some dispute about whether you can actually pin down bribery in a case like this without any doubt whatsoever. What's your opinion on that?

VAN SUSTEREN: Well, first of all, to prove a case of bribery, it doesn't have to be 100 percent certain. It just has to be beyond a reasonable doubt. And in order to prove that, a prosecutor has to produce evidence to that would show a criminal intent and that's very difficult id it's simply an exchange money that may be even date coincident with some decision made by another person.

Very difficult without something more than a transaction with money. It's not impossible, but you must show it's a quid pro quo, that there's criminal intent. It's hard to do, and at this point, this is only an investigation. It is only being looked at. There is no evidence that has been, at least not in the public domain, of an actual crime. VARNEY: The implications for this are presumably more political than they are legal because Mr. Clinton has an absolute right to pardon whomsoever he pleases?

VAN SUSTEREN: That's right. The Constitution gives the president of the United States the power to pardon. But even the political ramification is sort of interesting. Remember, the Constitution has also -- he's also limited to two terms as president of the United States.

So, you know, in some ways, this is going to be probably be an issue that's going to get lot of play in the media. If there's never a crime charged against anyone, against Denise Rich or Marc Rich or anybody else, it's going to get a lot of play. We're going to learn an awful lot about pardons in the next few months. So at the very least, we're going get a huge civic education.

VARNEY: Greta, may I ask you, do you think that Marc Rich will ever return to the United States? If you were his lawyer, would you advise him to return now?

VAN SUSTEREN: Absolutely not, because there's some question, Stuart, whether or not he's an American citizen. If he's an American citizen, he may have some tax obligations stemming from 1983 or 1984 when he may have stopped paying taxes.

I mean, so there are lots of tax issues. It's not this particular question. Last night on CNN, Shawn Tully of "Fortune" magazine was on the air and he said he doesn't even want to come back. He just wants the freedom to travel to other countries where the United States could extradite him while he's under indictment.

VARNEY: Greta Van Susteren, CNN's legal analyst. Greta, we'll see you tonight on "THE POINT." Thanks for being with us.

VAN SUSTEREN: Thanks, Stuart.

VARNEY: Next on MONEYLINE, dueling tax plans on Capitol Hill. The Democrats sketch out what they view is fair tax relief.

And later the four letter word among analysts, sell. We'll look at how Amazon got slapped with a recommendation that's a rarity on Wall Street.

And a report -- a profit, I should say. A profit letdown, and first-ever layoffs direct from Dell. Much more on today's developments with top analyst Dan Niles. Willow and I will be back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: The tax debate is heating up on Capitol Hill. Today, Democratic leaders unveiled the framework of the tax plan they're working on.

Fred Katayama reports from Washington. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

FRED KATAYAMA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): When it comes to cutting taxes, the Democrats say smaller is safer. They announced that are taking a fiscally conservative approach in drafting their tax plan.

The Democrats want to divide the surplus outside of Social Security and Medicare in three: one-third of it, or $900 billion, for tax cuts, roughly half that of Mr. Bush's plan; another third to pay down the national debt and reform Medicare and Social Security; and the last third to spend on programs like education, prescription drugs and defense.

The Democrats say when drafted, their plan will be more fair and responsible than that of Mr. Bush.

REP. RICHARD GEPHARDT (D-MO), MINORITY LEADER: His plan is part of a budget that gives excessive priority to cutting tax rates for those at the top while we need critical investments in Social Security, education, and health care.

KATAYAMA: Conservatives say the Democrats are leaning toward a package that's a spending plan in disguise.

STEPHEN MOORE, THE CLUB FOR GROWTH: This is really an indication that what the Democrats truly want to do is spend a substantial amount of the surplus. They're talking about an additional $1 trillion of spending.

KATAYAMA: Liberal economists argue that the Democrats are acting in a more responsible way, since a projected surplus of $5.6 trillion may not materialize.

HENRY AARON, THE BROOKINGS INSTITUTE: We can afford some tax cut, but smaller is better. We will have no difficulty at all two years from now, if our hopes are being fulfilled, cutting taxes again. But if they are dashed, if our hopes are dashed, and we've committed a lot to tax cuts that appear to be excessive, two years from now, we'll have a hell of a time trying to reverse that.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KATAYAMA: To back their contention that Mr. Bush's plan favors the rich, the Democrats brought out Senator Jon Corzine, the former chairman of Goldman Sachs. Senator Corzine said the Bush plan would save him one million dollars in taxes, calling it a "windfall for me, but bad for the country." He said he favors tax cut should be more targeted to those who need it the most, the low and middle income families.

By the way, two Republicans senators said they could not support Mr. Bush's tax cut plan, saying it was too costly. And now the president getting messages from Capitol Hill that he may still lack the votes needed to pass his tax cut plan and that more work needs to be done -- Stuart. Well, Willow, rather. BAY: It's Willow, Fred. Thank you. Thanks, Fred.

Coming up next, the details on today's double digit jump from Ciena. We will talk with the company's president when we return.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: In tonight's "Tech Watch": More on that supercharged rally from Ciena. This morning, the fiberoptics equipment maker beat the street, posting a 131 percent jump in revenue. Way off its 52-week high of 151, Ciena is still up nearly 80 percent in the last 12 months.

Joining us with more on his company's earnings, Gary Smith, Ciena's president. Gary, welcome back to MONEYLINE.

GARY SMITH, PRESIDENT & COO, CIENA: Good evening.

BAY: Investors certainly liked what they heard today, but I wonder if you could explain how in the midst of all of this bad news from your customers and your competitors -- just tonight, some more bad news from Nortel -- your business is booming?

SMITH: I think the story that's really going on here is the shift in the spending away from the legacy kind of voice architecture that most of carriers have, which is really not dealing well with data traffic.

And that's why they're operating costs and their capital cost are going up so much, really to this next generation of networks, which has is really been evangelized and led by Ciena into its next generation networking that has much lower operating costs, lower capital costs, and much more intelligence on the networks to basically create new services.

And I think what you're seeing here is really some of the more legacy-orientated vendors who helped build the voice networks are seeing some softness in demand and we, frankly, are not.

BAY: So while spending is down overall, companies are spending money on the kind of equipment that you make that makes them more efficient, essentially?

SMITH: That's exactly it. I mean, so, you've really got to look at where the dollars are going, and I think there's a real shift towards the kind of products that Ciena has been bringing to the market.

BAY: The question, of course, is how long that shift will continue. I know that you raised your outlook for 2001, but not all analysts have such rosy expectations. One in particular, from Dresner, downgraded you today and one of the things that she was concerned about is that there's a contraction in spending at least through the first half of 2001, and she's just not convinced that you're immune or will be immune. Are you? SMITH: Well, I don't think we're -- we don't pretend to be immune from the macroeconomics, but I think we are better position than virtually all of our competitors to be able to survive the kind of, you know, sort of short-term economic clamp-down that's going on.

And in fact, you know, it's actually helping in some way because the carriers have been forced to look at very carefully how they're spending their dollars, not just continuing to do that that they've done before. So, I think this very much plays to our story and I would say that we believe we have better visibility than we've ever had, and that's obviously why we upped our expectations for the year.

BAY: What effect do you think this will have on your stock price, still way off its highs, as we mentioned?

SMITH: Well, obviously, you know, we can't speculate on what's going to happen in the stock market. What we can speculate on is what's going to happen in our business, and I think we feel very bullish about the move that's going on here. We've been evangelizing this through for about the last two years and I think you're starting to see real evidence of this in the financial performance both our legacy competitors and also in some of these tier-one carriers that are moving to this next generation.

BAY: Gary Smith, I'll let that be the last word. Thanks for joining us tonight with your rosy outlook from Ciena.

SMITH: Thank you.

BAY: Coming up, was the USS Greeneville out of bounds when it hit and sank a Japanese boat? Fresh information on last week's sub accident in our "News Digest." Stuart and I will be back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: New information today about last Friday's submarine accident from the Pentagon and from civilians who were onboard during the collision. Wolf Blitzer has more on that now in the MONEYLINE "News Digest" -- Wolf.

WOLF BLITZER, CNN ANCHOR: Thank you, Stuart. Navy officials today confirmed the USS Greeneville was inside its assigned operating area, but outside a training area marked on maritime charts when it hit a Japanese trawler. That word came in a Pentagon briefing.

Officials also said they'd given the names of 16 civilians who were on board the sub to federal safety investigators. Those names are not being made public, and Navy brass defended the sub's helmsman, who supervised a civilian guest in his position during the sub's ascent.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REAR ADM. STEVE PIETROPAOLI, U.S. NAVY: I would defy you under any circumstances to explain to me how anything that helmsman could have done would have materially affected the outcome of this tragedy. (END VIDEO CLIP)

BLITZER: Earlier today, two of the civilians appeared on a news program. One, John Hall, described the moment of collision.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN HALL, CIVILIAN ON USS GREENEVILLE: There was a very loud noise and the entire submarine shuttered.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What did the captain say at that point?

HALL: I remember his words pretty vivid. He said Jesus, what the hell was that?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BLITZER: The Coast Guard tonight called off its active search for the nine people missing from the fishing boat. The Navy search continues.

In Israel, outgoing Prime Minister Ehud Barak has conditionally agreed to join the national unity government of his successor, Ariel Sharon. Barak will reportedly stay on as defense minister.

Finally, after an appearance today at the State Department, President Bush heads to Mexico tomorrow for a one-day summit. Among the subjects he'll discuss with Mexican President Vicente Fox, developing Mexico's energy market, and fighting drug traffickers.

I'll have much more ahead on the day's top stories on "WOLF BLITZER REPORTS." That's at 8:00 p.m. Eastern, 5:00 on the West Coast. MONEYLINE will be back after this break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: In tonight's headlines, a computer trailblazer falls short of already lowered forecasts, Dell disappoints on profits, a few hours after slashing its work force for the first time ever.

And even bigger layoffs coming at Nortel, the Canadian fiber optics power house says it's cutting 10,000 jobs.

Plus, a shocking slap in the face for Amazon.com. As one Wall Street house advises investors to sell that stock.

BAY: Our top story tonight: tech stocks in a world of trouble. After the bell tonight, a trio of tech heavyweights unleashed bad news, starting with Dell. The PC maker reporting profits of 18 cents a share, or $508 million, less than lowered forecasts. And it said it will fire 1,700 employees, 4 percent of its work force.

And Nortel Networks, the Canadian fiber optics giant, said it was cutting 10,000 jobs and warned it would lose money in the first quarter because of a sharp slowdown in the U.S. market. It also slashed its 2001 sales forecast. And Hewlett-Packard matched its already lowered profit forecasts, earning $727 million, down 33 percent from one year ago. Revenue rose by only 2 percent. Last month, H-P warned that the slowing economy would weigh on results. Checking the after hours reaction: Dell down more than 1; Nortel off more than 7 1/2 and H-P slipping $1.85. More on this later. Dan Niles will join us after the Dell conference call.

VARNEY: And more trouble today for another new economy pioneer, as the rarest of birds swooped down on Amazon.com, when a prudential securities advised investors to sell the stock, a rarity indeed. Susan Lisovicz has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): A slowing economy and the Internet implosion are just two factors weighing on the world's largest Internet retailer. Investors have abandoned Amazon.com. Its stock has plunged 80 percent over the past year. And weaker revenue figures and the companies lower targets point to rougher times ahead. Yet Prudential securities analyst Mark Rowen is the only analyst at a major brokerage to put an actual sell rating on Amazon. He says, the stocks valuation is too high.

MARK ROWEN, PRUDENTIAL: In our view, the problem is the valuation and even though the stock is off 87 percent from its high, we think there's still significant down side risk here.

LISOVICZ: Analysts often question the stock's valuation, but that rarely prompts them to put a sell rating on a stock. In fact, even in these challenging times, 29 percent of all recommendations in the S&P 500 are strong buys; 39 percent are buys; 31 percent are rated as holds, and only .4 percent are rated as sells, the same fraction are rated as strong sells.

LISOVICZ (on camera): The subtleties of analysts' recommendations have long been misunderstood by the investing public. Analysts know that a downgrade to a sell will, in many cases, upset portfolio managers, shareholders, and the company itself. So, a recommendation of a hold is in many cases a de facto sell.

Experts say it's important to remember that research analyst have their own self interest to consider.

MITCH ZACKS, ZACKS INVESTMENT: The analyst's own worth, and the analyst's compensation is based on how he's perceived by these portfolio managers, the more in esteem he's held by the portfolio managers, the higher salary he can command, and the more valuable he is to his brokerage firm.

LISOVICZ: Further inhibiting a sell rating, many brokerage firms have an investment banking division that may do business with the company in question, which just underscores one of the fundamentals in Investing 101. Before buying a stock, do some research yourself. Susan Lisovicz, CNN financial news, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE) VARNEY: Shares of Amazon traded lower today, but then bounced back. Perhaps investors are betting that this sell call is a sign of a bottom. Shares of Amazon closed up fractionally at 14 1/2, but Amazon is off 83 percent from its 52-week high -- Willow.

BAY: Stuart, still to come, we'll get the latest on what drove tech stocks to a second straight rally. We'll check in with John Metaxas at the Nasdaq.

Plus, we'll hear from money manager Susan Byrne on why all this volatility may haunt us for months to come.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Two in a row; another strong rally for the Nasdaq. Let's go to John Metaxas who followed the action all day long at the Nasdaq market site.

JOHN METAXAS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Willow, Ciena's results better than expected in earnings, were what drove the market higher. But, perhaps, more important was the fact that they raised revenue expectations for their upcoming performance, and in this environment, that's not something investors are used to.

The result was a strong surge in Ciena shares today, which brought the rest of the market higher. Ciena up $12 on the day. Fiber optic components makers followed in its wake. JDS Uniphase, SDL -- Sycamore, rather, and Juniper among the gainers. JDS Uniphase, the largest fiber optics component maker, rising despite the fact that Merrill Lynch cut their quarterly and their yearly estimates on that stock.

But it wasn't just the networkers and the fiber optics. Recovery continuing in the semiconductors today, and some analysts say that's a good sign for this market. Prudential telling us we can expect one more wave of downward earnings revisions. But they say Intel presents good risk forward. Intel among the gainers, along with Xilinx, Vitesse, Broadcom, and PMC-Sierra. In other words, Prudential says it's OK to buy the chips right now.

Networkers, as we told you, were up. Cisco riding the wave, up 5 percent. The other big caps gaining: Oracle up 2 percent; Sun up 2 percent; Microsoft managing a small gain. Look at this gain for Dell Computer -- up 9 percent after announcing those layoffs today, after the bell. They fail to meet expectations and they guided lower. VARNEY: Can you give me a name that you really like in natural gas and name you really like in electric utilities?

VARNEY: Are you so cautious that for the small investor who could really move into any asset category they want, would you say move a lot of it into cash because you're so cautious?

JEFFREY GARTEN, AUTHOR, THE MIND OF THE C.E.O.": There's a sense that being a CEO today, particularly of a big global company, is extraordinarily difficult, much more difficult than it's ever been before. And as a result, there aren't that many people who look like good candidates.

VILES: Corporate America's comeback kids include: Henry Schacht at Lucent; Paul Allaire at Xerox; John Pepper, back as chairman at Procter & Gamble; Leonard Hadley at Maytag; and David Johnson at Campbell Soup.

JAMES CITRIN, SPENCER STUART: Spencer Stuart's working with a Fortune 100 company as we speak on a succession strategy, and they shared with me very recently that they have a contingency plan whereas if the current, sitting CEO were to be recruited away, or God forbid, if anything happened to him, they have now engineered a plan to bring back the retired, well-regarded CEO into the saddle for an interim basis.

VILES: But bringing back the old boss doesn't always right a listing ship.
